or cash bond" shall mean United States currency; traveler's checks issued by major banks or express companies which, alone or in combination with
currency total the exact amount required to be deposited as bond; and negotiable drafts on major credit card companies, under conditions approved by
the chief of police or such person as may be designated by the chief of police to have the authority to approve or establish the conditions for the
acceptance of negotiable drafts on credit card companies.
C. Bond To Be Applied To Fines Imposed: The village's administrative hearing officer is hereby authorized to apply any bond posted to satisfy all or a
portion of any fine(s) imposed against the defendant or respondent for a violation proven and after a finding of liable.
D. Bond To Be Returned For Violations Not Proven: Any bond posted shall be returned to the defendant or respondent after a finding of not liable or
dismissal of the violation charged. (Ord. 2010-16, 8-5-2010)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 37/498
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD
2-1-1: CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP:
There is hereby authorized and established the planning and zoning board of the village. The planning and zoning board shall consist of seven (7)
members including its chairman to be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. All members of the planning
and zoning board shall reside within the village or within territory contiguous to the village and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles beyond the
corporate limits and not included within any other municipality. The village president shall be a member ex officio of said planning and zoning board. (Ord.
2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
A. Regular Members: The regular members of the planning and zoning board shall serve respectively for the following terms: one for one year; two (2) for
two (2) years; two (2) for three (3) years; and two (2) for four (4) years. The successor (or reappointment) for each term shall serve for a term of four (4)
years. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-2-1: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
A. The village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees may appoint three (3) alternate members of the planning and zoning board.
The president shall designate a first alternate, second alternate and third alternate member. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their
designation. All appointments for alternate members shall be for a period of four (4) years.
B. Alternate members must conform to the same requirements for residency as regular members of the planning and zoning board.
C. When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the planning and zoning board, any alternate shall have such powers
and may exercise such duties as a regularly appointed member.
D. When there is a vacancy of a regular member and a new appointment is to be made, the alternate member who has been designated first alternate
shall then be appointed as a regular member. When the first alternate member is appointed as a regular member, the second alternate member shall
become the first alternate member, the third alternate member shall become the second alternative member and the new appointment shall be the third
alternate member. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-3: ORGANIZATION AND RECORDS:
The members of the planning and zoning board shall elect a vice chairman, who shall so serve during the period of his or her term, and such other officers
as they deem necessary. The secretary to the planning and zoning board shall be appointed and need not be a member of the planning and zoning board.
The planning and zoning board shall keep written records of its proceedings, which shall at all times be open to inspection by the board of trustees. (Ord.
2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-4: COMPENSATION:
The chairman and members of the planning and zoning board shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-5: QUORUM:
Except as may otherwise be provided by law, four (4) members of the planning and zoning board shall constitute a quorum. No meeting (or hearing) shall
be conducted without a quorum being present. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The planning and zoning board shall have the following powers and duties:
A. To initiate, direct, draft and review the comprehensive plan for the village and each subsequently proposed amendment thereto, which, upon the
adoption by the president and board of trustees, shall become the "official comprehensive plan" of the village.
B. To act in the capacity of, and discharge the duties conferred upon the planning and zoning board referred to in the subdivision control ordinance of the
village, the zoning ordinance of the village, this code and the state statutes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 38/498
C. To hear and review all matters upon which it is required to recommend under this code and such other matters as may from time to time be referred to
it, consistent with this code. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-7: MEETINGS AND RULES:
A. Open Hearings And Meetings: All planning and zoning board hearings and meetings shall be open to the public.
B. Calls And Quorum: In addition to regular meeting dates, special meetings shall be held at the call of the board of trustees, the chairman, or in his/her
absence, the vice chairman, or at the request of three (3) members. Except as provided by law, four (4) members of the planning and zoning board
shall be necessary for a quorum at each meeting.
C. Testimony: All testimony by witnesses at any public hearing shall be given under oath. The chairman, vice chairman or acting chairman may administer
oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses.
D. Minutes And Records: The planning and zoning board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon every question, or
if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact. The minutes of all hearings and meetings of the planning and zoning board shall be filed in the office of
the village clerk and shall be open to public inspection during normal business hours.
E. Rules Of Procedure: The planning and zoning board shall adopt its own rules of procedure not in conflict with title 10, "Land Subdivisions", title 11,
"Zoning", of this code or other provisions of this code. An official copy of these rules shall be filed in the office of the village clerk where they shall be
open to the public inspection during normal business hours.
F. Publish Meeting Dates: The planning and zoning board shall annually cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the village a
listing of regular meeting dates for that year. Said list shall be kept on file in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-1-8: JURISDICTION:
For the purpose of title 10, chapter 7, "Administration And Enforcement" and title 11, chapter 13, "Administration And Enforcement" of this code, the
planning and zoning board is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and authority:
A. Map Amendments: To hear and make recommendations to the board of trustees on all applications or requests for amendments to the zoning map
which make up title 11, "Zoning", of this code.
B. Planned Unit Developments: To hear and make recommendations to the board of trustees on all applications for planned unit developments.
C. Annexations: To hear and make recommendations to the board of trustees on all applications for annexations to the village.
D. Review Of Comprehensive Plan: To review on a regular basis the comprehensive plan and to hear and make recommendations to the board of trustees
regarding any proposed changes.
E. Review Of Zoning Ordinance: To review the zoning ordinance (title 11 of this code) on a continuing basis and to hear and make recommendations to the
board of trustees to improve its effectiveness.
F. Appeals: To hear and decide appeals in which it is alleged there is an error in any order, requirement, decision, interpretation or determination made by
the community development director as set forth in this chapter.
G. Special Uses: To hear and report to the board of trustees on special uses as set forth in section 11-13-8 of this code.
H. Text Amendments: To hear and report to the board of trustees on requests for amendments to the text provisions of the zoning ordinance (title 11 of this
code).
I. Variations: To hear and make recommendations to the board of trustees on requests for variations for the requirements of the zoning ordinance (title 11
of this code) in the manner and subject to the standards set forth in this chapter and to file with the board of trustees findings of fact and
recommendations on said requests.
J. Other Matters: To hear and make recommendations upon all other matters referred to it by the board of trustees or upon which it is required to pass
under the zoning ordinance (title 11 of this code). (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
Chapter 2
COMMUNITY RELATIONS COMMISSION
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 39/498
2-2-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the village of Streamwood "community relations commission", hereinafter referred to as
"commission". (Ord. 2003-21, 5-1-2003)
2-2-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
It shall be the intent and purpose of the community relations commission to be a recommending commission only and:
A. To promote fair and equal treatment and opportunity under the law to all persons, regardless of their economic, sex, age, racial, religious or ethnic
background;
B. To promote social harmony in the community of the village, and through education and action, including dispute resolution, to help deter prejudice,
discrimination and intolerance in whatever form these shall appear;
C. To develop services and projects which will assist residents in meeting practical problems and in adjusting to the changing circumstances, to enrich the
social and intellectual life of all residents;
D. To foster accord and cooperation among individuals or groups of different races, ethnic backgrounds or religious beliefs in order to improve the living
environment of all residents;
E. To provide a forum during regular meetings where citizens are encouraged to come forward with their human relations concerns and to make an honest
attempt to deal with those concerns in a constructive manner;
F. To safeguard the rights of all citizens as defined by the ordinances of the village and state and federal laws and constitutions;
G. To make comment to the village board regarding problems and issues affecting a culturally diverse community and make recommendations which may
be present in agenda items under consideration;
H. To be aware of human relations dilemmas nationally and worldwide, and to attempt to devise ways to positively address those dilemmas. (Ord. 2003-
21, 5-1-2003)
2-2-3: COMMISSIONERS, APPOINTMENT, TERMS, VACANCY, QUORUM:
The commission shall be composed of no less than nine (9) members who shall be known as commissioners. The commissioners shall be appointed by
the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees.
A. At least three (3) of the commissioners shall be representatives from each of the following public entities: one park district, one library district, and one
township. (Ord. 2005-57, 11-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
B. One commissioner shall be named as chairman and one commissioner shall be named as vice chairman. The chairman and vice chairman shall serve
for a period of one year and may be reappointed to successive terms.
C. It shall not be a requirement for appointment as a commissioner to be a resident of the village.
D. The initial members of the commission shall be appointed to staggered terms. Thereafter, their successors shall be appointed for two (2) year terms.
E. If for any reason a commissioner is unable to serve, the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a replacement to
fill the unexpired term.
F. A majority of the then sitting commissioners shall constitute a quorum. (Ord. 2005-57, 11-17-2005)
2-2-4: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
A. The president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees may appoint two (2) alternate members of the commission. The president shall
designate a first alternate and second alternate. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their designation. All appointments for alternate
members shall be for a period of two (2) years.
B. When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the commission, any alternate shall have such powers and may exercise
such duties as a regularly appointed member.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 40/498
C. When there is a vacancy of a regular member and a new appointment is to be made, the alternate member who has been designated first alternate
shall then be appointed as a regular member. When the first alternate member is appointed as a regular member, the second alternate member shall
become the first alternate member and the new appointment shall be the second alternate member. (Ord. 2003-21, 5-1-2003)
2-2-5: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman, but not less frequently than once per quarter. (Ord.
2003-21, 5-1-2003)
B. Special Meetings: The chairman or any four (4) commissioners may call special meetings of the commission by the filing of a written notice with the
secretary of the commission. This notice shall contain the time and place of the special meeting and a brief statement of the business to be submitted
for the consideration of the commission at such special meeting, and no other business shall be considered at such special meeting. Notice of special
meetings to commissioners shall be given orally or in writing at least forty eight (48) hours in advance of the meeting. (Ord. 2004-6, 2-19-2004)
2-2-6: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the commission to make recommendations to the village board of trustees on programs to improve human relations in the village,
while recognizing, valuing and respecting the diverse cultures in our community, including, but not limited to:
A. Promoting diversity in our schools (winter_spring).
B. Community beautification awards program (spring_summer).
C. Diversity outreach (autumn_winter).
D. Community based programming. (Ord. 2003-21, 5-1-2003)
2-2-7: ADOPTION OF PROCEDURAL RULES:
The commission may adopt bylaws containing procedural rules and such substantive regulations as it deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of this
chapter. (Ord. 2003-21, 5-1-2003)
Chapter 3
COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
2-3-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the village of Streamwood "community and economic development commission",
hereinafter referred to as "commission". (Ord. 1998-13, 3-5-1998)
2-3-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
It shall be the intent and purpose of the community and economic development commission to be an advisory commission to the village board to assist in
the attraction, retention, maintenance and revitalization of economic and community growth within the village by assuring opportunities for development
and redevelopment, attracting sound, stable commercial growth and developing strategies to assist in the preservation and support of existing
development. (Ord. 1998-13, 3-5-1998)
2-3-3: COMMISSIONERS; APPOINTMENT, TERM, VACANCY, QUORUM:
The commission shall be composed of nine (9) members who shall be known as commissioners. The commissioners shall be appointed by the village
president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The president shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, one
commissioner to serve as chairman and one commissioner to serve as vice chairman. The chairman and vice chairman shall serve for a period of one
year and may be reappointed to successive terms.
It shall not be a requirement for appointment as a commissioner to be a resident of the village.
The nine (9) members of the commission shall be appointed to staggered terms. Five (5) members shall be appointed for two (2) years; four (4) members
shall be appointed for three (3) years. Thereafter, their successors shall be appointed for two (2) year terms. (Ord. 1998-13, 3-5-1998)
If for any reason a commissioner is unable to attend any meeting or meetings, that commissioner may appoint a designee to attend in his or her absence.
Appointed designees shall be counted for purposes of a quorum and shall have the right to vote in lieu of the absent commissioner. (Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-
2015)
Any five (5) commissioners shall constitute a quorum. (Ord. 1998-13, 3-5-1998)

2-3-4: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman, but not less frequently than once per quarter. (Ord.
1998-13, 3-5-1998)
B. Special Meetings: The chairman or any three (3) commissioners may call special meetings of the commission by the filing of a written notice with the
secretary of the commission. This notice shall contain the time and place of the special meeting and a brief statement of the business to be submitted
for the consideration of the commission at such special meeting, and no other business shall be considered at such special meeting. Notice of special

Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)

The commission may adopt bylaws containing procedural rules and such substantive regulations as it deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of this
chapter. (Ord. 1998-13, 3-5-1998)
Chapter 4
VETERANS COMMISSION
2-4-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the "Streamwood Veterans Commission" hereinafter referred to as "Commission." (1994
Code)
2-4-2: COMMISSIONERS; APPOINTMENT, TERMS, VACANCY, QUORUM:
The Commission shall be composed of seven (7) members who shall be known as Commissioners. The Commissioners shall be appointed by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees. One Commissioner shall be named as chairman and one Commissioner shall be named
as vice chairman at the time of his/her appointment. The chairman shall appoint a secretary of the Commission. Appointments shall be limited to veterans
of the United States and individuals who at the time of their appointment are on active duty with the United States military.
The terms of new appointments to the Veterans Commission shall be staggered so that the terms of the chairman and three (3) members of the
Commission shall expire December 31, 1992. The terms of the three (3) remaining members of the Commission shall expire June 30, 1993. All
subsequent appointments shall be for a term of two (2) years.
If for any reason a Commissioner is unable to serve, the President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint a replacement to fill
the unexpired term.
Any four (4) Commissioners shall constitute a quorum. (1994 Code)
2-4-3: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the Commission shall be held not less than monthly at such times as determined by the Commission; at the call
of the chairman.
B. Special Meetings: The chairman or any three (3) Commissioners may call special meetings of the Commission by the filing of a written notice with the
secretary of the Commission. This notice shall contain the time and place of the special meeting and a brief statement of the business to be submitted
for the consideration of the Commission at such special meeting and no other business shall be considered at such special meeting. Notice of special
meetings to Commissioners shall be given orally or in writing at least twenty four (24) hours in advance of the meeting. (1994 Code)
2-4-4: DUTIES:
To make recommendations to the Village Board of Trustees on matters pertaining to:
A. The presentation and enhancement of the Veterans Memorial.
B. The interactivity of the Veterans Memorial and the community.
C. All events to be held at the Veterans Memorial.
D. Funding for the maintenance of and/or addition to the Veterans Memorial. (1994 Code)
2-4-5: ADOPTION OF PROCEDURAL RULES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 42/498
The Commission may adopt bylaws containing procedural rules and such substantive regulations as it deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of
this Chapter. (1994 Code)
2-4-6: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
A. The President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, may appoint two (2) alternate members to the Veterans Commission. The
President shall designate a first alternate and second alternate member. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their designation and shall be
required to have the same qualifications as regular Commission members.
B. The term of the new appointments to alternate members of the Veterans Commission shall be staggered so that the term of the individual appointed as
the first alternate shall expire on June 30, 1995 and the term of the individual appointed as second alternate shall expire on July 30, 1996. All
subsequent appointments shall be for a term of two (2) years.
C. When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the Veterans Commission, an alternate member shall have such powers
and may exercise such duties as a regularly appointed member.
D. When there is a vacancy of a regular member and a new appointment is to be made, the alternate member who has been designated first alternate
shall then be appointed as a regular member. When the first alternate member is appointed as a regular member, the second alternate member shall
become the first alternate member and the new appointment shall be the second alternate member. (1994 Code)
Chapter 5
BLOOD COMMISSION
2-5-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created the Streamwood blood commission which shall consist of a chairman and six (6) members appointed by the village president with
the consent of the village board. (1994 Code)
2-5-2: TERM:
The chairman and members of said blood commission shall serve for two (2) year staggered terms without compensation. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-7,
5-7-2015)
2-5-2-1: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
A. The president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees may appoint two (2) alternate members of the blood commission. The president shall
designate a first alternate and second alternate member. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their designation. All appointments for alternate
members shall be for a period of two (2) years. (Ord. 2008-22, 9-4-2008; amd. Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
B. Alternate members must conform to the same requirements for residency as regular members of the blood commission.
C. When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the blood commission, any alternate shall have such powers and may
exercise such duties as a regularly appointed member. (Ord. 2008-22, 9-4-2008)
2-5-3: DUTIES:
At such time as the village enters into a valid contract with an agency licensed and authorized to extract blood for medical purposes, the Streamwood
blood commission shall be authorized to perform the duties hereinafter set forth. Each such contract shall contain a provision indemnifying and holding the
village, its officers, agents and employees harmless from any and all liability which may result from the activity of said agency in extracting, storing,
processing, typing, selling or otherwise distributing whole blood or plasma received through any program of donations conducted within the corporate limits
of the village.
The duties of the Streamwood blood commission shall be as follows:
A. Encourage, through means of advertising and promotion, a blood donor program wherein citizens of the village are encouraged to give donations of
blood for medical purposes.
B. Secure and provide available space wherein blood donations can be accomplished by licensed and accredited agencies.
C. Provide clerical assistance needed to implement and carry out the program. (1994 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 43/498
2-5-4: LIMITATIONS:
The Streamwood blood commission shall be subject to the following limitations:
A. No expenditure of municipal funds shall be made by the blood commission unless said expenditures have been budgeted and approved by the village
finance director.
B. The blood commission shall not in any manner engage in the actual extraction of blood from donors. (1994 Code)
Chapter 6
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-6-1: BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created a Streamwood Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, which Board shall consist of three (3) members to be appointed by the
Village President, with the consent of the Village Trustees. (1994 Code)
2-6-2: TERMS AND QUALIFICATIONS:
Members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall serve for a term of three (3) years, and of the three (3) members, one shall be a
representative citizen of the employee class, one shall be a representative citizen of the employer class and one shall be a representative citizen not
identified with either the employee or employer class. (1994 Code)
2-6-3: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners to make appointments to Police and Fire Departments of the Village where applicable,
and said Board shall conduct and hold all entrance and promotional examinations and exercise such other powers and duties as provided by law. (1994
Code)
2-6-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall publish a set of rules to be known as the Rules and Regulations of the Streamwood, Illinois Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners. Within those rules and regulations the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may provide for a probationary period for
promoted positions in the Village Police Department under their jurisdiction. Said rules are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this Chapter by
reference. (1994 Code)
Chapter 7
BOARD OF TRUSTEES, POLICE PENSION FUND
2-7-1: BOARD CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund of the Village. Such Board shall consist of five (5) members, two
(2) of said members to be appointed by the President with the concurrence of the Board of Trustees, and two (2) members of said Board shall be elected
from the Village police force by the active members of said police force, and the fifth member of said Board shall be elected from the beneficiaries of the
Police Pension Fund by such beneficiaries, according to law. (1994 Code)
2-7-2: TERM:
The members of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund shall serve for a term of two (2) years, as provided by law. (1994 Code)
2-7-3: DUTIES:
It shall be the duties of the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund to manage, invest and control the Police Pension Fund and all monies pertaining
thereto, all as is set forth in detail in the applicable Illinois statutes. (1994 Code)

BOARD OF TRUSTEES, FIREMEN'S PENSION FUND

There is hereby created and established a board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund of the village. Beginning on the third Monday in April 2006, the

Chapter 9
STREAMWOOD EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the Village of Streamwood Emergency Management Agency ("SEMA"), established to prevent, minimize, repair damage and
alleviate injury resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile actions or from natural or man-made disaster, all in accordance
with "The Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act", as amended. The SEMA shall consist of the Director, who shall be appointed by the Village
President, and serve as SEMA Director, and the Coordinator, as designated by the Director. The Coordinator shall be under the authority, command, and
control of the SEMA Director. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-2: DIRECTOR:
A. Duties: Under the supervision of the Village President, the Director shall have the responsibility for the management of Streamwood Emergency
Management Agency, including the Coordinator and support staff. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-2-1: VACANCY IN OFFICE:
In the event of the absence, temporary absence, resignation, death, or inability to serve as the Director of SEMA, the Village President or individual
designated by the Village President, shall be and act as Director until a new appointment is made as provided in this chapter or until the appointed Director
is able to resume the role of Director. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-2-2: COORDINATOR:
A. Duties: Under the supervision of the Director of SEMA, the Coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the planning, coordination, and operation of
emergency management activity in the Village. The Coordinator shall maintain liaison with the State and Federal authorities and the authorities of other
nearby political subdivisions to ensure the most effective operation of the emergency operations plan. The Coordinator's duties shall include, but not be
limited to, the following:
1. Volunteer Recruitment: Coordinating the recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel and facilities of the Village for
emergency management purposes.
2. Use Of Village Facilities: Development and coordination of plans for the immediate use of all Village facilities, equipment, manpower and other
resources for the purposes of minimizing or preventing damage to persons and property and protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental
services and public utilities necessary for the public health, safety and welfare.
3. Use Of Buildings: Negotiating and concluding agreements with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such
buildings or other property for emergency management purposes, and designating suitable buildings as public shelters.
4. Public Practice Alerts: Conducting public practice alerts to ensure the efficient operation of emergency management regulations, procedures, and
operations.
5. Coordinating Public And Private Agencies: Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any emergency management
activity.
6. Assuming Authority And Conducting Activities: Assuming such authority and conducting such activities as the Director may direct to promote and
execute the emergency operations plan.
7. Vacancy In Office: In the event of the absence, temporary absence, resignation, death, or inability to serve as the Coordinator, the Director or any
person designated by the Director, shall be and act as Coordinator or Temporary Coordinator in the case of an absence or temporary absence until a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 45/498
new appointment is made as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-3: MEMBERSHIP WITH THE JOINT EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:
The Village is a member of the joint emergency management system ("JEMS"), a regional agreement between neighboring municipalities for emergency
management support. The joint emergency management system is overseen by a governing board which is composed of its Chief Administrative Officer,
or its designee, and members from each of the member communities. The board is led by a Chairman and Vice-Chairman, who are elected by the board
members. As a member of JEMS, the Village of Streamwood shall coordinate its Emergency Management Program activities with the JEMS Coordinator
in order to establish regional standardization. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-4: JOINT EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM COORDINATOR:
A. Duties: In cooperation with the Director, the JEMS Coordinator will have the responsibility for planning, training and exercise coordination of the
emergency management activity in the Village. The JEMS Coordinator's duties shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
1. Maintain, coordinate, and recommend for adoption or amendment, an emergency operations plan (EOP).
2. Be on-call 24-hours a day, seven (7) days a week.
3. Monitor news and severe weather.
4. Maintain, update and monitor the subscriber community continuity of operations plan (COOP).
5. Serve as the liaison for subscribers to State emergency management agencies and emergency service and disaster agencies.
6. Act as the NIMS Compliance Officer under the national incident management system.
7. Ensure that the subscribers' emergency operations centers (EOCs) are maintained and ready.
8. Provide training on the use of EOC equipment and readiness including regional disaster exercises to measure the subscriber's preparedness to
respond to emergencies and to develop action plans to address any deficiencies identified during such exercises.
9. Oversee the maintenance and evaluation of the emergency warning systems including the outdoor warning sirens or additional warning systems in
place in each subscriber community.
10. Assist in the preparation and distribution of incident action plans for planned special events. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-5: FUNCTIONS:
SEMA shall perform such EMA functions within the Village as shall be prescribed in and by the State of Illinois EMA plan and program prepared by the
Governor, and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits of the Village as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement
with any other political subdivision, municipality, or quasi-municipality entered into as provided in "The Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act", as
amended. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-6: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any member of the SEMA organization may be designated as a member of a mobile support team created by the Director of the State of Illinois
Emergency Management Agency, as provided by law. The leader of the mobile support team shall be designated by the Director of SEMA. Any member of
a mobile support team, who is a Village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor, or the State Director, shall receive the
compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or
employee of the Village, while so serving, shall receive from the State of Illinois, reasonable compensation as provided by law. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-7: AGREEMENT WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The Director of SEMA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other cities, villages or political subdivisions of the State of Illinois, but no such
agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Streamwood. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-8: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the Governor proclaims that a disaster or state of emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within
the State of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from man-made or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of
SEMA to cooperate fully with the State of Illinois EMA and with the Governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-
19-2018)
2-9-9: EMERGENCY POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Village President Emergency Power: The Village President may exercise the emergency power and authority necessary to fulfill the general powers and
duties as defined by this chapter. The judgment of the Village President shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke emergency powers provided by
this chapter and other appropriate authorities. The Village Board of Trustees may convene to perform its legislative and administrative powers as the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 46/498
situation demands and shall receive reports relative to emergency management activities. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as abridging or
curtailing the powers or restrictions of the Village Board of Trustees.
B. Regulations As Deemed Necessary: During any period when disaster threatens or when the Village has been struck by disaster, within the definition of
this chapter, the Village President or the Director of SEMA at the direction of the Village President, may promulgate such regulations as deemed
necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources. Such regulations may include, but shall not be limited to, the following:
1. Regulations prohibiting or restricting the movement of vehicles in order to facilitate the work of emergency management personnel or to facilitate the
mass movement of persons from critical areas within or without the Village.
2. Regulations pertaining to the movement of persons from areas deemed to be hazardous or vulnerable to disaster.
3. Such other regulations necessary to preserve public peace, health and safety.
4. Regulations promulgated in accordance with the authority above will be given widespread circulation by proclamations published and expressed by
newspaper, radio, televised media and social media.
C. Emergency Locations; Governmental Powers: Whenever, due to an emergency resulting from the effects of natural or manmade disaster or hostile act
or the anticipated effects thereof, it becomes imprudent, inexpedient or impossible to conduct the affairs of local government at the regular or usual
place or places, the Village Board may meet at any place within or without the Village limits in accordance with the Open Meetings Act1 and shall
proceed to establish and designate by ordinance, resolution, or other manner alternate or substitute sites or places as the emergency temporary
location or locations of government where all, or any part of, the public business may be transacted and conducted during the emergency situation.
D. Conducting Public Business At Temporary Location: During the period when the public business is being conducted at the emergency temporary
location or locations, the Governing Body and other officers of the Village shall have and possess and shall exercise, at such location or locations, all of
the executive, legislative, and judicial powers and functions conferred upon such body and officers by or under the laws of this State. Such powers and
functions may be exercised in the light of the exigencies of the emergency situation, and all acts of such body and officers shall be valid and binding.
E. Continuity In Office: In the event that the Village President is unavailable, the powers of the office shall be exercised and duties shall be discharged by
the designated emergency interim successors, as provided for in this Code and laws of this State, in the order specified. The emergency interim
successor shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which designated until such time as a vacancy which may exist shall be
filled in accordance with the Constitution or statutes; or until the officer, or their deputy or a preceding emergency interim successor, again becomes
available to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. Based on the authority of the Emergency Interim Executive Succession Act2,
the line of succession for the executive branch of government shall be: Village President, Chairperson of the Finance Committee and senior or second
most senior Trustee.
In the event that, at the time or as a consequence of any disaster or occurrence described in this chapter, the Village President and the three (3)
successors on file with the Village shall be absent, killed, or rendered incapable of performing the duties of such office, such office shall be filled until
such time as a successor can be selected in the manner prescribed by law, in the following line of succession: the remaining members of the Village
Board based on tenure, the Village Manager, the Chief of Police, the Fire Chief, the Finance Director and the Director of Public Works. In the event
that, at the time or as a consequence of any disaster or occurrence described in this chapter, the incumbent of any Municipal office or position shall be
absent, killed, or rendered incapable of performing the duties of such office or position, such office or position shall be filled, until such time as a
successor can be selected in the manner prescribed by law, by appointment by the Village President with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees. The Village President shall give due consideration to the list of three (3) successors on file with the Village but is not required to select from
said list. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-10: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY AND EMERGENCY PLANS:
A. A comprehensive emergency operations plan shall be adopted and maintained by resolution of the Corporate Authorities upon the recommendations of
the Village President. In the preparation of the plan as it pertains to Village organization, it is the intent that the services, equipment, facilities and
personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be utilized to the fullest extent. When approved, it shall be the duty of the Director of SEMA, all
departments, and all employees to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at
all times. The emergency operations plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter and have the effect of law whenever a disaster has been
proclaimed.
B. Each department head assigned responsibility in the emergency operations plan shall be responsible for carrying out all duties and functions assigned
therein. Duties will include the organization and training of assigned Village employees and volunteers.
C. The Village President shall prescribe in a continuity of operations and continuity of government plan those positions within the disaster organization, in
addition to their own, for which lines of succession are necessary. In each instance, the responsible person will designate and keep on file with the
Village a current list of three (3) persons as successors to the position. The list will be in order of succession and will as nearly as possible designate
persons best capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions.
D. When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the Village government, the Village President or Acting Village
President is authorized to seek assistance from persons outside of government. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall also
grant authority for the persons so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during, and after a disaster. The Village may accept such services from
persons outside of government on a volunteer basis. Such persons shall be enrolled as emergency management volunteers in cooperation with the
heads of departments affected.
E. Some of the duties ascribed to the Village President in this section will ordinarily be handled as a matter of routine by SEMA's Director or Coordinator,
but the responsibility and authority stem from and remain with the Village President. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 47/498
2-9-11: COMPENSATION:
Members of SEMA who are paid employees or officers of the Village, if called for training by the State of Illinois Director of EMA, shall receive for the time
spent in such training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such Village employees or officers shall receive for
such training time, such compensation as may be established by the President and Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-12: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The Finance Director of the Village may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement by the State of Illinois to the Village for expenses
incident to training members of SEMA as prescribed by the State Director of EMA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile
support team while serving outside the Village in response to a call by the Governor or State Director of EMA, as provided by law, and any other
reimbursement made by the State incident to SEMA activities as provided by law. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-13: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
The Village Board of Trustees may, on recommendation of the Director of SEMA, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the Village in a
position to combat effectively any enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the State of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from
enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from man-made or natural disasters and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide
emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster.
In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the Director of SEMA is authorized, on behalf of the Village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment
or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the emergency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed
by law pertaining to Village contracts or obligations, as authorized by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act3, as amended; provided, that if the
Village President is available at such time, the SEMA Director shall act subject to the direction and restrictions imposed by the Village President. (Ord.
2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-14: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the EMA organization shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the following oath:
I (state your name) of the Emergency Management Agency of the Village of Streamwood do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend
and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the state of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and
facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or
purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter, and I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not
advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or
of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of Streamwood EMA organization, I will not advocate nor
become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or
violence.
(Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-15: OFFICE:
The Village Manager is authorized to designate space in any Village building or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the Village President for the SEMA
organization as its office. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
2-9-16: LOCAL DISASTER EMERGENCIES:
A local disaster emergency may be proclaimed only by the Village President as provided by the Illinois Emergency Management Agency Act, as amended.
A local disaster emergency shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the Village Board.
Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing or terminating a local disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with
the Village Clerk. It shall be the duty of SEMA to cooperate fully with the Village President in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law during
the time of a local disaster emergency. (Ord. 2018-11, 4-19-2018)
Chapter 10
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
2-10-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created and established for the Village a Civil Service Commission, which shall operate in all respects as provided in "An Act to Regulate
the Civil Service of Cities", sections 1 to 41, approved March 20, 1895, as amended. (1994 Code)
2-10-2: MEMBERSHIP, TERMS:
The Village President, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, shall appoint three (3) persons who shall constitute and be known as the Civil Service
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 48/498
Commission: one for three (3) years; one for two (2) years; and one for one year from the time of appointment and until their respective successors are
appointed and qualify. In every year thereafter the Village President, with the approval of the Board of Trustees, shall in like manner appoint one person as
the successor of the Commissioner whose term shall expire in that year to serve as such Commissioner for three (3) years and until his successor is
appointed and qualified. Two (2) Commissioners shall constitute a quorum. All appointments to the Commission, both original and to fill vacancies, shall be
made so that not more than two (2) members shall at the time of appointment be members of the same political party. The Commissioners shall hold no
other lucrative office of employment under the United States, the State or any Municipal corporation or political division thereof. Each Commissioner,
before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take the oath prescribed by the Constitution of the State. (1994 Code)
2-10-3: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE; VACANCIES:
The Village President may, in his discretion, remove any Commissioner for incompetence, neglect of duties or malfeasance in office. The Village President
shall, within ten (10) days, report in writing any such removal to the Board of Trustees with the reasons therefor. Any vacancy in the office of Commissioner
shall be filled by appointment by the Village President with the approval of the Board of Trustees. (1994Code)
2-10-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Civil Service Commission shall make rules to carry out the purpose of the Civil Service Act and for examinations, appointments and removals, in
accordance with its provisions, and the Commission may from time to time make changes in the original rules. All rules made as herein provided and all
changes therein shall forthwith be printed for distribution by the Commission. (1994 Code)
2-10-5: CHIEF EXAMINER:
The Civil Service Commission shall employ a chief examiner, whose duties it shall be, under the direction of the Commission, to superintend any
examinations held in the Village under the Civil Service Act and who shall perform such other duties as the Commission shall prescribe. The chief
examiner shall be ex officio secretary of the Commission under the direction of such Commission and as such secretary shall keep the minutes of its
proceedings, preserve all reports made to it, keep a record of all examinations held under its direction and perform such other duties as the Commission
shall prescribe. (1994 Code)
2-10-6: APPROPRIATION FOR EXPENSES, MEETING ROOM:
A sufficient sum of money shall be appropriated by the Board of Trustees each year to carry out the provisions of the Civil Service Act. The Village
President shall cause suitable rooms to be provided for the Civil Service Commission at the expense of the Village. (1994 Code)
Chapter 11
NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVANCY COMMISSION
2-11-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created a commission which shall be known as the village of Streamwood "natural resource conservancy commission", hereinafter
referred to as "commission". (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
It shall be the intent and purpose of the natural resource conservancy commission to be a recommending commission only to make recommendations to
the village board of trustees on programs and plans to conserve and protect natural resources, educate residents on ways to protect the environment and
conserve energy. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-3: COMMISSIONERS, APPOINTMENT, TERMS, VACANCY, QUORUM:
A. The natural resource conservancy commission shall consist of five (5) voting members, appointed by the village president with the advice and consent
of the board of trustees. The five (5) members of the commission shall be appointed to overlapping terms. Three (3) members shall be appointed for
three (3) years, two (2) members shall be appointed for two (2) years. Thereafter, their successors shall be appointed for two (2) year terms. (Ord.
2009-15, 6-18-2009)
B. The natural resource conservancy commission shall also include one ex officio nonvoting member who shall be the assistant village engineer. (Ord.
2009-15, 6-18-2009; amd. Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
C. Persons selected to serve on the natural resource conservancy commission shall possess training, interest or experience in such areas as ecology,
biology, environmental law, education, pollution control, engineering, science and public health.
D. If for any reason a commissioner is unable to serve, the president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a replacement to
fill the unexpired term.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 49/498
E. Any three (3) commissioners shall constitute a quorum. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-4: ALTERNATE MEMBERS:
A. The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint two (2) alternate members of the commission. The president shall
designate a first alternate and second alternate. Alternate members shall serve in the order of their designation. All appointments for alternate
members shall be for a period of two (2) years.
B. When a regular appointed member is absent for any reason from a meeting of the commission, any alternate shall have such powers and may exercise
such duties as a regularly appointed member.
C. When there is a vacancy of a regular member and a new appointment is to be made, the alternate member who has been designated first alternate
shall then be appointed as a regular member. When the first alternate member is appointed as a regular member, the second alternate member shall
become the first alternate member and the new appointment shall be the second alternate member. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-5: ADVISORY MEMBERS:
The president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint nonvoting advisory members to the commission. Advisory members shall
possess training, interest or experience in such areas as ecology, biology, environmental law, education, pollution control, engineering, science and public
health. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-6: MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the commission shall be held at the call of the chairman, but not less frequently than once per quarter. (Ord.
2009-15, 6-18-2009)
B. Special Meetings: The chairman or any three (3) commissioners may call special meetings of the commission by the filing of a written notice with the
secretary of the commission. This notice shall contain the time and place of the special meeting and a brief statement of the business to be submitted
for the consideration of the commission at such special meeting, and no other business shall be considered at such special meeting. Notice of special
meetings to commissioners shall be given orally or in writing at least forty eight (48) hours in advance of the meeting. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009; amd.
Ord. 2015-7, 5-7-2015)
2-11-7: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of the commission to make recommendations to the village board of trustees on programs and plans to conserve and protect the
natural resources, educate residents on ways to protect the environment and conserve energy, including, but not limited to:
A. Conservation And Protection:
1. Conduct and maintain an inventory of the natural resources of the village.
2. Study, investigate, develop and update annually a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees
and shrubs in or upon all village owned public property.
3. Review and comment on long term management plans, as such plans are developed by village staff with respect to areas of specific interest,
including, but not limited to, Poplar Creek, village tree conservancy areas, and village wetland detention facilities.
B. Education And Outreach:
1. Develop educational materials to help foster a better understanding of the balance required to sustain the environment in a built community,
including materials regarding the sustenance of water quality and natural habitats.
2. Conduct annual workshops with area schools, in conjunction with Earth Day/Arbor Day celebrations to promote sustainability.
3. Provide information and ideas for articles for the village newsletter to promote sound resource use, environmental protection and energy
conservation.
4. Facilitate an annual exposition or workshop for residents and businesses to improve energy use, consumption and preservation of natural resources.
5. Serve as a liaison between the village and other governmental, public and private agencies such as the Streamwood park district, school district U-
46, Chicago Metropolitan agency for planning, Poplar Creek watershed planning group, Chicago Wilderness, North Cook County soils, and others to
encourage development of programs and management of land that supports recognition and conservation of native species and natural ecological
communities, and the improvement and enhancement of the environment.
C. Energy Conservation Strategies:
1. Assess and recommend strategies to address deficiencies obtained from an annual energy audit of village owned property.
2. Devise methods of promoting energy efficiency and energy conservation for village government, residents and businesses.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 50/498
3. Investigate and recommend the best methods of maintaining an environment beneficial to the village and as free from pollution as is practical and is
reasonable.
4. Promote the use of alternatives to traditional energy consumption and resource management.
5. Devise methods to promote recycling and reduce waste in the village.
6. Advise village board regarding solid waste management related matters generally in the village. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
2-11-8: ADOPTION OF PROCEDURAL RULES:
The commission may adopt bylaws containing procedural rules and such substantive regulations as it deems necessary to accomplish the purposes of this
chapter. (Ord. 2009-15, 6-18-2009)
