collect the tax pursuant to subsection D of this section on or before the payment due date of the public utility's bill first reflecting the tax, or directly to
the village treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is delivered to the retail purchaser if no
public utility has been designated to collect the tax pursuant to subsection D of this section or if the gas is delivered by a person other than a public
utility so designated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 68/498
4. Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose a tax upon any person, business or activity which, under the constitutions of the United States or
state of Illinois, may not be made the subject of taxation by the village.
5. A person who purchases gas for resale and therefore does not pay the tax imposed by this section with respect to the use or consumption of the
gas, but who later uses or consumes part or all of the gas, shall pay the tax directly to the village treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the
second month following the month in which the gas is used or consumed.
6. The tax shall apply to gas for which the delivery to the retail purchaser is billed by a public utility on or after January 1, 2012.
7. If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this section, whether as a result of mistake of fact or
an error of law, then such amount shall be: a) credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this section from the taxpayer who made the
erroneous payment or b) subject to a refund if no such tax is due or to become due; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3)
years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be so credited or refunded.
8. No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this section shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of
such amount.
9. To prevent multiple taxation, the use of gas in the village by a retail purchaser shall be exempt from the tax imposed by this section if the gross
receipts from the sale at retail of such gas to the retail purchaser are properly subject to a tax imposed upon the seller of such gas pursuant to the
village's municipal utility tax, imposed pursuant to subsection 3-3-4A3 of this chapter, as amended from time to time, as authorized pursuant to
section 8-11-2 of the Illinois municipal code5.
D. Collection Of Tax By Public Utility: The president, village treasurer, village manager, and village finance director are each authorized to enter into a
contract for collection of the tax imposed by this section with any public utility providing gas service in the village. The contract shall include and
substantially conform with the following provisions:
1. The public utility will collect the tax from retail purchasers as an independent contractor;
2. The public utility will remit collected taxes to the village treasurer no more often than once each month;
3. The public utility will be entitled to withhold from tax collections a service fee equal to three percent (3%) of the amounts collected and timely
remitted to the village treasurer;
4. The public utility shall not be responsible to the village for any tax not actually collected from a retail purchaser; and
5. Such additional terms as the parties may agree upon.
E. Books And Records: Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records, including original source documents and books of entry, denoting the
activities or transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise to any tax liability or exemption under this section. All such books and records shall, at
all times during business hours, be subject to and available for inspection by the village. (Ord. 2011-34, 11-17-2011)
3-3-5: FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES TAX6:
A. Compliance With Provisions: It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association, not incorporated under the laws of the state, to engage in the village
in effecting fire insurance, or to transact any business of fire insurance in the village, while in default by not fully complying with any of the requirements
of this section, and until such requirements shall have been fully complied with; but this provision shall not relieve any company, corporation or
association from the payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this section.
B. Tax Imposed: Any such corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the state, which is engaged in the village in effecting fire
insurance, shall pay the village treasurer, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department of the village a sum of money equal in amount to
two percent (2%) per annum of the gross receipts received as premiums upon fire insurance policies by any and all agents of such corporation,
company or association, during the year ending on July 1 in each year, for any insurance effected, or agreed to be effected, on property located in the
village, by or with such corporation, company or association during such year.
C. Report And Payment Of Tax: Every person acting in the village as agent for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or association shall, on or
before July 15 of each and every year, render the village clerk a full, true and just account verified by his oath, of all premiums upon fire insurance
policies which, during the year ending July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him, or by some other person for him, in his behalf of
any such corporation, company or association on property located in the village. Such agent shall also at the time of rendering the aforesaid report, pay
to the village treasurer the sum of money for which the company, corporation or association represented by him is chargeable, by virtue of the
provisions of this section.
No insurance agent in the village shall have any insurance business or dealings with any company, association or corporation not incorporated under
the laws of this state, which shall be in default for not reporting or making payments as hereinbefore provided, until it shall have complied with all the
requirements of this section.
D. Action To Recover Tax: The sum of money for which such company, corporation or association is so chargeable may be recovered of it, or its agents or
agent, by an action in the name of and for the use of the village as for money had and received. Nothing in this section shall be held to exempt any
person, corporation, company or association from indictment and conviction under the provisions of an act entitled "an act to enable cities, towns and
villages, organized under any general or special law, to levy and collect a tax or license fee from foreign insurance companies for the benefit of
organized fire departments", in force July 1, 1895. (1994 Code)
E. Penalty: Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 1998-4,
1-8-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 69/498
F. Collection And Distribution Of Fire Department Tax:
1. The Illinois municipal league is hereby authorized by the corporate authorities of the village to receive and examine the reports and payments of the
two percent (2%) fire department taxes tendered the village by foreign fire insurance companies writing such business on property located within the
corporate limits of the village.
2. The league shall establish a permanent fire insurance tax bureau in which there shall be kept a permanent, accurate and complete record of all such
tax payments received from foreign fire insurance companies and the distribution of such payments to the municipalities. All such records shall be
open to the inspection of any village official during reasonable office hours.
3. The village hereby agrees to pay to the Illinois municipal league for the cost of maintaining the services of the aforementioned fire insurance bureau
a fee of seven percent (7%), based upon the amount of the two percent (2%) fire department taxes actually collected by the league, not later than
thirty (30) days after the receipt of tax payments by the village. The Illinois municipal league is hereby further authorized to carry on necessary
correspondence with the foreign fire insurance companies owing taxes to the village, in behalf of the village, for the purpose of increasing the tax
payments of the insurance company to the village. (1994 Code)
3-3-6: HOME RULE MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION AND SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A. A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property
titled or registered with an agency of this state's government, at retail within the corporate boundaries of the village at the rate of one percent (1%) of
the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this section is in effect; and a tax is hereby imposed upon all persons
engaged within the corporate boundaries of the village in the business of making sales of service, at a rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of all
tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman as an incident to a sale of service. Such "home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax" and
"home rule municipal service occupation tax" shall not be applicable on the sale of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the
premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription
and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics. (1994 Code;
amd. Ord. 2003-44, 9-4-2003, eff. 1-1-2004)
B. The taxes hereby imposed, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto, shall be collected and enforced by the department of
revenue of the state of Illinois. The department of revenue shall have full power to administer and enforce the provisions of this section. (1994 Code)
3-3-7: FOOD AND BEVERAGE TAX:
3-3-7.1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this section 3-3-7, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Any alcohol, spirits, wine, beer, ale or other liquid containing more than one-half of one percent of alcohol by volume, which is
intended for internal consumption by humans.
PREPARED FOOD: Includes any solid, liquid including both alcoholic liquor and nonalcoholic liquids, except "soft drinks" as hereinafter defined, powder or
item used or intended to be used for human internal consumption, whether simple, compound, or mixed, and which has been prepared for immediate
consumption. Prepared food may be purchased for consumption within or upon the premises where it is sold, or it may be purchased for consumption off
the premises. However, with respect to food purchased for consumption off the premises where it is sold, the term "prepared food" does not include any
food which is taxed pursuant to 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/2-10 or is sold in a closed or sealed bottle, can, carton or container of the manufacturer
or wholesaler or which has not been prepared for immediate consumption. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section 3-3-7, "prepared food"
does not include any food or drink sold through a vending machine regardless of the location of the vending machine.
PREPARED FOOD FACILITY: Any person, business, or establishment which sells at retail prepared food that has been prepared for immediate
consumption with seating provided for consumption of the prepared food, whether or not such prepared food facility use is conducted along with any other
use in a common establishment commonly described as an inn, restaurant, eating place, drive-in restaurant, buffet, bakery, cafeteria, cafe, lunch counter,
grocery store, convenience store, fast food outlet, catering service, coffee shop, diner, sandwich shop, soda fountain, bar, cocktail lounge, soft drink parlor,
ice cream parlor, tearoom, delicatessen, hotel, motel, or club, or any other establishment which sells at retail food which has been prepared for immediate
consumption. The term "prepared food facility" does not include churches, public or private schools, boarding houses, daycare centers, nursing homes,
retirement centers or similar residential care facilities, or programs for the central preparation of meals to be delivered and consumed at private residences
of the elderly or disabled, or other facilities of not for profit associations or corporations.
PURCHASE AT RETAIL: To obtain for use or consumption and not for resale, in exchange for consideration, whether in the form of money, credits, barter
or any other nature.
RETAIL LIQUOR FACILITY: Any premises required to obtain a retail liquor license pursuant to chapter 4 of this title.
RETAILER: A person or entity who/which sells or offers for sale for use or consumption and not for resale.
SOFT DRINKS: Any complete, finished, ready to use, nonalcoholic drink, whether carbonated or not, including, but not limited to, soda water, cola, fruit
juice, vegetable juice, carbonated water, and all other preparations commonly known as soft drinks of whatever kind or description that are contained in
any closed or sealed bottle, can, carton, or container, regardless of size. "Soft drink" does not include coffee, tea, noncarbonated water, infant formula,
milk or milk products as defined in the grade A pasteurized milk and milk products act, or drinks containing fifty percent (50%) or more natural fruit or
vegetable juice.
VILLAGE: Streamwood, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.2: IMPOSITION OF TAX:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 70/498
Effective January 1, 2012, a tax, in addition to any and all other taxes imposed, is hereby levied and imposed upon the retail purchase of alcoholic liquor
and prepared foods at any prepared food facility or retail liquor facility, within the village, at the rate of two percent (2.0%) of the purchase price of such
alcoholic liquor and prepared foods, excluding other taxes imposed thereon, the ultimate incidence of and the liability for payment of which shall be borne
by the purchaser. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.3: COLLECTION OF TAX:
The retailer of each prepared food facility and each retail liquor facility shall have the duty to collect and account for the tax imposed on each purchaser at
the time the consideration is paid by the purchaser. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.4: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
The retailer of each prepared food facility and each retail liquor facility shall have the duty to maintain complete and accurate books, records and accounts,
showing the gross receipts for sale of prepared foods and alcoholic liquor and the tax collected each business day, which shall be made available to the
village for examination and for audit by the village upon reasonable notice and during customary business hours. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-
2011)
3-3-7.5: TRANSMISSION OF TAX COLLECTION:
The retailer of each prepared food facility and each retail liquor facility shall have the duty to cause to be filed, a sworn prepared food and beverage tax
return with the director of finance of the village for each prepared food facility and retail liquor facility located within the village. The return shall be prepared
and submitted on forms prescribed by the village and filed with the village by the filing date and at the same time intervals or frequencies as the sale and
use tax return, form ST-1, is due to be filed with the Illinois department of revenue. The return shall also be accompanied by payment to the village of all
taxes imposed by this section 3-3-7 which are due and owing for the time period covered by the return. The return shall also be accompanied by a copy of
the sale and use tax return, form ST-1, filed with the Illinois department of revenue for sales within the village during the same time period. All taxes
collected by the village pursuant to this section 3-3-7 are general revenues of the village and may be used by the village for any lawful corporate purpose.
(Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.6: LATE PAYMENT PENALTY:
If any tax imposed by this section 3-3-7 is not paid when due, a late payment penalty equal to five percent (5.0%) of the unpaid tax shall be added for each
month, or any portion thereof, that the tax remains unpaid and the late payment penalty shall be paid along with the tax imposed. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-
2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.7: TRANSMITTAL OF EXCESS TAX COLLECTIONS:
If any retailer collects an amount upon a sale not subject to the tax imposed hereby, but which amount is purported to be the collection of the tax, or if a
retailer collects an amount upon a sale greater than the amount of the tax imposed herein and does not for any reason return it to the purchaser who paid
it before filing the return for the period in which it occurred, that person shall account for and pay over those amounts to the village along with the tax
properly collected. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.8: ENFORCEMENT, LICENSE SUSPENSION, REVOCATION:
Payment and collection of the tax and any late payment penalty may be enforced by action in any administrative hearing or any court of competent
jurisdiction and failure to collect, account for and pay over the tax and any late payment penalty shall be cause for suspension or revocation of any village
license issued for the prepared food facility or retail liquor facility, if any, and all in addition to any other penalties provided for by this code. (Ord. 2011-32,
11-17-2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
3-3-7.9: PENALTY:
Any retailer operating a prepared food facility or retail liquor facility within the village who fails or omits to collect, account for, pay over to the village the tax
and any late payment penalty, if any, imposed by this section 3-3-7, or fails to maintain or allow examination of the books and records required in section
3-3-7.4 of this chapter shall be guilty of a business offense and shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. Each day a violation of this section 3-3-7 continues shall be considered a separate violation. (Ord. 2011-32, 11-17-
2011, eff. 12-31-2011)
Chapter 4
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR DEALERS
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms as used in this chapter shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 71/498
capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being.
BANQUET HALL: Every building or public place kept, used, maintained and held out to the public to be a place where banquets, weddings and other
single day events and parties are catered to and where no other portion of the premises is used for any other purpose defined herein.
BOTTLE SERVICE: The sale or delivery of spirits by the bottle for consumption on the licensed premises.
CLUB: A corporation under the laws of this state, and not for pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or
consumption of alcoholic liquor, which conforms to the definition of a club in 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-3.24.
HOTEL: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where meals are actually and
regularly served and consumed and where sleeping accommodations are offered for pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or
residential, in which twenty five (25) or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations for such guests and having one or more public dining
rooms where meals are served to such guests, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings, in
connection therewith, and such building or buildings or structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary dining room and kitchen
equipment and capacity.
LICENSEE: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership, club or park district holding a license under the provisions of this chapter.
ORIGINAL PACKAGE: Any bottle, flask, jug, can, cask, barrel, keg, hogshead or other receptacle or container whatsoever used, corked or capped, sealed
and labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor to contain and to convey any alcoholic liquor.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where meals are served, and where meals are
actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room
equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests.
Provided further, that no restaurant licensed to do business as such shall sell alcoholic liquor except with meals unless such restaurant seats one hundred
fifty (150) persons at any one time.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption and not for resale. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 1996-17, 4-18-1996; Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
3-4-2: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
The village president is hereby authorized to be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the dram shop act,
235 Illinois Compiled Statutes and of such village ordinances and resolutions relating to alcoholic liquor as may be needed. The village president may
appoint a person or persons to assist him in the exercise of the powers and performance of the duties provided for such liquor control commissioner. Such
person or persons to assist said local liquor control commissioner, as provided for herein, shall not exceed five (5) in number, which number shall not
include any more than two (2) village trustees, and it shall not be necessary that any village trustee be such assistants. Such assistants shall possess the
same qualifications as an individual must have to be elected a village trustee, and the term of office of each such assistant shall be one year. The
appointment of such assistant by the village president shall have the concurrence of the board of trustees and any such assistant appointed may be
removed for cause by said liquor control commissioner only, however, with the consent of the board of trustees. No such assistant appointed shall be
interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquors. (1994 Code)
3-4-3: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale in the village any alcoholic liquor without having a license, or in violation of the terms of such license. (1994
Code)
3-4-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the local liquor control commissioner. Such applications shall be made in writing, and shall be signed by
the applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a club or corporation, verified by oath or affidavit.
All said applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to cover the costs of necessary
investigations. Said fee shall apply only to first time applications and not to renewals. Fees for investigation as a result of a change of manager, etc., shall
be administratively set by the village clerk.
An application for license by a park district shall be executed by a duly authorized agent thereof and shall contain such of the following information as is
pertinent. The three hundred dollar ($300.00) nonrefundable fee for investigation shall not apply to a park district license application.
Such applications shall contain the following information and statements:
A. The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits
thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses
of the officers and directors, and if five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, in interest, is owned by one person or his nominee, the name and
address of such person or persons.
B. The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
C. The character of business of the applicant; and in the case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
D. The length of time that said applicant has been in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was issued.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 72/498
E. The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time application is made.
F. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license.
G. A statement as to whether applicant has made similar application for a similar license or premises other than described in this application, and the
disposition of such application.
H. A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter, laws of the state, or ordinances of the village.
I. Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the federal government has been revoked and the reasons therefor.
J. A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state or the United States in the conduct of his place of business. (1994 Code)
K. A statement that the applicant will apply for and obtain approval for a special use permit from the village board for the sale of alcoholic liquor. (Ord.
1999-55, 11-4-1999)
3-4-5: RESTRICTIONS ON GRANTING LICENSES:
No such licenses shall be issued to:
A. A person who is not a resident of the village.
B. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides.
C. A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
D. A person who has been convicted of a felony under any federal or state law.
E. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of or is the keeper of a house of ill fame. (1994 Code)
F. A person who has been convicted of pandering or any other crime or misdemeanor in violation of decency and morality. (Ord. 1998-24, 4-2-1998)
G. A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for cause.
H. A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license under a first application.
I. A copartnership, unless all the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to receive a license.
J. A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the
stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the village.
K. A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
L. A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is to be
issued, provided that the said premises are properly zoned permitting the sale of alcoholic liquor.
M. Any law enforcing public official, president, any member of the board of trustees, and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or
indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic liquor.
N. Any person, association or corporation not eligible for a state retail liquor dealer's license. (1994 Code)
O. Any applicant without dramshop insurance. Applicants shall furnish evidence satisfactory to the local liquor control commissioner that such applicant is
covered by a policy of dramshop insurance issued by a responsible insurance company authorized and licensed to do business in the state insuring
such applicant against liability which applicant may incur under the provisions of section 5/6-21 of the Liquor Control Act1.
The provisions of this subsection shall be liberally construed and each applicant and license holder shall have the burden of providing the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner with satisfactory evidence that said insurance is in full force and effect at any particular time during the term of any such license.
Failure to do so after the issuance of any local liquor license shall render said license void ab initio. (Ord. 1998-24, 4-2-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 73/498
P. A person who has not applied for and obtained a special use permit for the sale of alcoholic liquor from the Village Board. (Ord. 1999-55, 11-4-1999)
Q. Any person, association, corporation or applicant that has failed to pay, after notice, any judgment or fine due and owing the Village or is in arrears in
the payment of any penalty, tax or other indebtedness or charge due and owing to the Village. (Ord. 2018-3, 1-18-2018)
3-4-6: EXAMINATION OF APPLICANT FOR LOCAL LICENSE:
The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the right to examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any application for a local license or for a
renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served as provided by statute, and to examine or cause to be
examined the books and records of any such applicant or licensee, to hear testimony and take proofs for his information in the performance of his duties,
and for such purpose to issue subpoenas which shall be effective in any part of this State. For the purpose of obtaining any of the information desired by
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner under this section, he may authorize his agent to act on his behalf, as provided by statute. (1994 Code)
3-4-7: DANCING AND LIVE ENTERTAINMENT:
(Rep. by Ord. 1999-47, 10-7-1999)
3-4-8: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS, FEES, NUMBER ISSUED:
There shall be fifteen (15) retail liquor license classifications. At no time shall the maximum number of licenses in each class exceed the actual number of
licenses issued except as amended from time to time by action of the Village Board. The Village Board shall be required to take action to expand the
number of licenses. (Ord. 1998-24, 4-2-1998; amd. Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
The classes are designated and defined as follows:
A. Class A license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the licensed premises only.
2. License fee: One thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Eight (8). (Ord. 2018-2, 1-4-2018)
B. Class A-1 license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on, or off of, the licensed premises.
2. License fee: One thousand seven hundred dollars ($1,700.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Zero (0). (Ord. 2019-3, 1-3-2019)
C. Class B license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquors but not for consumption on the licensed premises.
2. License fee: One thousand three hundred dollars ($1,300.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Twelve (12). (Ord. 2019-6, 2-7-2019)
D. Class C license:
1. Description: Authorizes the sale of alcoholic liquors for a period not to exceed twelve (12) hours, and only on the premises described in said license.
2. License fee: Twenty four dollars ($24.00) per twelve (12) hour period.
3. Maximum number allowed: No limit. (1994 Code)
E. Class D license:
1. Description: Authorizes the sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the licensed premises only, this class of license being granted only to clubs
or fraternal organizations incorporated under a General Not For Profit Corporation Act, organized for at least three (3) years prior to the making of the
license application and having at least twenty five (25) regular dues paying members who are residents of the Village.
2. License fee: Eight hundred dollars ($800.00) annually.
3. Maximum number allowed: One. (Ord. 2009-23, 9-3-2009)
F. Class F license:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 74/498
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic beverages defined as beer and wine, only with alcoholic content not to exceed thirty percent (30%)
for consumption on the licensed premises.
2. License fee: Eight hundred dollars ($800.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Seventeen (17). (Ord. 2018-26, 10-18-2018)
G. Class G license:
1. Description: Authorizes the free tasting of liquors on the premises. This class of license may only be issued to holders of Class B licenses. Tasting
under this license shall be limited to not more than two (2) days in any month.
2. License fee: Ten dollars ($10.00) per day.
H. Class H license:
1. Description: Authorizes the sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only in hotels.
2. License fee: Two thousand four hundred dollars ($2,400.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Zero (0). (Ord. 2019-3, 1-3-2019)
I. Class I license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only in restaurants, expressly providing, however, that
such licenses shall be issued only to establishments having a regular capacity, in accordance with existing Village and State public health and fire
prevention ordinances and statutes, to serve meals to at least one hundred fifty (150) persons at any one time. (Ord. 2000-6, 2-3-2000)
2. License fee: One thousand six hundred dollars ($1,600.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: Two (2). (Ord. 2019-3, 1-3-2019)
J. Class J license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquors for consumption on the premises only in banquet halls.
2. License fee: Two thousand four hundred dollars ($2,400.00) annually. (Ord. 2018-25, 10-4-2018)
3. Maximum number allowed: One. (Ord. 2019-3, 1-3-2019)
K. Class K license:
1. Description: Authorizes the sale or delivery of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises only in Park District buildings where authorized by the
Streamwood Park District Board. In such cases where the sale of alcoholic liquors in Park District buildings is conducted for a single event by a
person, club or corporation other than the Streamwood Park District, such person, club or corporation shall secure a Class C license for such event.
2. License fee: None.
3. Maximum number allowed: Only one such license allowed which may only be issued to the Park District.
L. Class L license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic beverages defined as beer and wine, only with alcoholic content not to exceed thirty percent (30%)
but not for consumption on the licensed premises.
2. License fee: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) annually. (1994 Code)
3. Maximum number allowed: One. (Ord. 2018-25, 10-4-2018)
M. Class M license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic beverages defined as beer and wine, only with an alcoholic content not to exceed thirty percent
(30%) of content not for the consumption or use on the licensed premises where delivery is by mail or common carrier.
2. License fee: Eight hundred dollars ($800.00) annually. (Ord. 1994-18, 4-21-1994)
3. Maximum number allowed: None. (Ord. 1998-34, 5-21-1998)
N. Class N license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in its original package but not for consumption on the licensed premises of a convenience or
similar store where the display of alcoholic liquor shall not occupy an area greater than ten percent (10%) of the total sales floor area of the
premises. Alcoholic liquor with an alcohol content exceeding thirty percent (30%) must be displayed behind the sales counter and not accessible by
customers. Alcoholic liquor with an alcohol content exceeding thirty percent (30%) shall not be sold in containers of less than eight (8) ounces
(236.5 mL).
2. License fee: One thousand three hundred dollars ($1,300.00) annually. (Ord. 2014-35, 12-4-2014, eff. 1-1-2015)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 75/498
3. Maximum number allowed: One. (Ord. 2019-6, 2-7-2019)
O. Class O license:
1. Description: Authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic beverages defined as beer for consumption on or off the premises of a grocery store/restaurant.
2. License fee: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) annually. (Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
3. Maximum number allowed: Zero (0). (Ord. 2016-7, 4-7-2016)
3-4-9: LICENSE TERM:
Licenses shall be issued for the period beginning January 1 and shall be valid to and including December 31, both in the same year, to be known as the
license period. (1994 Code)
3-4-10: DISPOSITION OF FEES:
All such license fees shall be paid to the Village at the time application for license is made. In the event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be
returned to the applicant. If the license is granted, then the fee shall be deposited in the General Corporate Fund or in such fund as shall have been
designated by the Village President and the Board of Trustees by proper action. (1994 Code)
3-4-11: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license shall be a purely personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year after issuance unless sooner revoked as is in this chapter provided, and
shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such licenses shall not descend by the laws of testate or
intestate devolution, but shall cease upon the death of the licensee; provided, that executor or administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and
the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee when such estate consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or
manufacture of alcoholic liquor under the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee
after the death of such decedent or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license, but no longer than six (6) months, after the death,
bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee. A refund shall be made of that portion of the license fee paid for any period in which the licensee shall be
prevented from operating under such license in accordance with the provisions of this section. (1994 Code)
3-4-12: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A liquor dealer's license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in the premises described in the application and license. Such location may be
changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the Village President. No change of location shall be permitted unless the proposed
new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor under the Statutes of the State and the provisions of this Code. (1994 Code)
3-4-13: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof; provided, that he is then qualified to receive a license and the premises for which such
renewal license is sought are suitable for the purpose; provided further, that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested
right which shall in any case prevent the Board of Trustees from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within the Village. No license shall be
renewed if the licensee has failed to pay, after notice, any judgment or fine due and owing to the Village or if the licensee is in arrears in the payment of
any penalty, tax or other indebtedness or charge due and owing to the Village. (Ord. 2018-3, 1-18-2018)
3-4-14: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. Proximity To Church, School Or Hospital: No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquors within one hundred feet (100') of any
church, school, hospital or home for the aged or indigent persons. However, in the event a church, school, hospital or home for the aged or indigent
persons obtains a temporary license to sell alcoholic liquors for charitable purposes, this restriction shall not apply.
B. Restrictions In Residential Areas: It is hereby determined that the following described portions of the Village are predominantly residential in character:
All that territory restricted to single residence use and multi-family building use under the zoning ordinance of the Village. No license shall be issued for
a location falling within the above listed areas; provided however, the aggregate number of hours of all such licenses issued for the same location shall
not exceed thirty (30) hours in any period of one hundred sixty eight (168) hours. Such number of hours shall be counted from the first hour for which
any such license is granted.
C. Park District Excepted: The above restrictions shall not apply to premises owned by a Park District. (1994 Code)
D. Village Hall: The delivery of alcoholic beverages is approved for the premises commonly known as the Streamwood Village Hall, 301 East Irving Park
Road, only for civic and charitable events. (Ord. 1993-78, 12-16-1993)
3-4-15: CLOSING HOURS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 76/498
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, serve or retail any alcoholic liquor in the Village:
A. Before the hour of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. on any day except Sunday and before nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on Sunday; (1994 Code)
B. After the hour of twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight for Class B, Class L and Class N liquor license holders and for that portion of a Class A-1 liquor license
holder which provides for the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption off of the licensed premises. (Ord. 2016-7, 4-7-2016)
C. After the hour of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday; after two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Saturday, Sunday and
New Year's Day for all license holders other than those provided for in subsection B of this section. (1994 Code)
3-4-16: PREMISES AND BUILDING REGULATIONS:
A. Sanitary Conditions: All premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the Village ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for
human consumption.
B. View From Street: In premises in which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises is licensed, other than in restaurants, hotels or
clubs, no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside such
premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or sidewalk at all times, and no booth,
screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangement of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises which shall
prevent a full view of the entire interior of such premises, and the entire space used by the public must be so located that there shall be a full view of
the same from the street, road or sidewalk. All rooms where alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the premises shall be continually lighted at all
hours by natural or artificial white lights so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. In case the view into any such licensed
premises required by the foregoing provisions shall be wilfully obscured by the licensee or by another person authorized by him, such license may be
revoked in the manner herein provided. In order to enforce the provisions of this subsection, the Local Liquor Commissioner shall have the right to
require the filing with him of plans, drawings and photographs showing the clearance of the view as above required. (1994 Code)
3-4-17: EMPLOYEE REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with, or who is a carrier of, any
contagious, infectious or venereal disease, and it shall be unlawful for any person afflicted with or who is a carrier of any such disease to work in or about
any such premises or to engage in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. (1994 Code)
3-4-18: STORES SELLING SCHOOL SUPPLIES, LUNCHES:
No license shall be issued to any person for the sale at retail of any alcoholic liquor at any store or other place of business where the majority of the
customers are minors or school age or where the principal business transacted consists of schoolbooks, school supplies, food, lunches or drinks for such
minors. (1994 Code)
3-4-19: RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MINORS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to purchase or obtain any alcoholic liquor in any tavern or other place in the
Village where alcoholic liquor is sold.
B. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining
alcoholic liquor in any tavern or other place in the Village where alcoholic liquor is sold. (1994 Code)
C. In every tavern or other place in the Village where alcoholic liquor is sold there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place:
WARNING TO MINORS
You are subject to a fine up to $750.00 under the provisions of the Streamwood Village Code if you purchase alcoholic liquor or misrepresent your
age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor.
(1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2010-9, 5-6-2010)
D. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a retail liquor dealer's license or his agent or employee to suffer or permit any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years to remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises are located;
provided, that this subsection shall not apply to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who is accompanied by his parent or guardian, or to
any licensed premises which derives its principal business from the sale or services of other commodities than alcoholic liquor.
The president may revoke or suspend the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this section.
E. It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any minor child of which he may be the parent or guardian to violate any of the provisions of this
section.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 77/498
F. No person under the age of twenty one (21) years may draw, pour, sell, mix or tend bar of any alcoholic liquors as an employee of any retail licensee.
(1994 Code)
3-4-20: GAMBLING AND/OR GAMES OF CHANCE:
A. Games Of Chance: It shall be unlawful for any games of chance to be located in or on the licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is to be sold.
B. Slot And Pinball Machines: It shall also be unlawful for any slot machine or for any pinball machine which returns to the player money or other valuable
property to be located in or on the licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is to be sold.
C. Coin In The Slot Mechanical Devices: Coin in the slot operated mechanical devices played for amusement which can reward the player with free
games, which devices are so constructed or devised as to make such result of the operation thereof depend in part upon the skill of the player and
which return to the player thereof no money, property or right to receive money or property are permitted in or on the licensed premises where alcoholic
liquor is to be sold. (1994 Code)
D. Simulated Video Or Mechanical Gaming Devices: It shall be unlawful for any simulated video or mechanical gaming devices to be located in or on the
licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is to be sold. (Ord. 2004-8, 3-4-2004, eff. 1-1-2005)
E. Video Gaming Devices/Terminals: The provisions of this section notwithstanding, video gaming devices/terminals shall be permitted on those premises
holding a valid on premises consumption liquor license as may be authorized by section 3-4-21 of this chapter and as licensed pursuant to the
provisions of the Illinois video gaming act2. (Ord. 2013-20, 6-20-2013)
3-4-21: VIDEO GAMING:
A. Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
APPLICANT: Any person or entity applying for a video gaming license under this section.
CODE: The village code of ordinances of the village of Streamwood, Cook County, Illinois.
FRATERNAL ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not for profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone
as a result of the operation and that is exempt from federal income taxation under section 501(c)(8) or (c)(10) of the internal revenue code.
GAMING LICENSEE: The person, firm or entity to whom a license has been granted by the village and state permitting it to engage in the defined
activities of video gaming.
ILLINOIS GAMING BOARD: The board created by the Illinois legislature to regulate video gaming by the state of Illinois.
LICENSED FRATERNAL ESTABLISHMENT: The location where a qualified fraternal organization that derives its charter from a national fraternal
organization regularly meets.
LICENSED VETERANS' ESTABLISHMENT: The location where a qualified veterans' organization that derives its charter from a national veterans'
organization regularly meets.
LICENSED VIDEO GAMING LOCATION: A "liquor licensed establishment", "licensed fraternal establishment" or a "licensed veterans' establishment",
all as defined in section 5 of the video gaming act and this section that holds a valid video gaming license granted by the village and state permitting
the licensee to locate one or more, but not more than five (5) video gaming terminals at the establishment.
LIQUOR COMMISSION: The liquor commission of the village.
LIQUOR LICENSE: A retail local license issued by the village authorizing the holder to sell and offer for sale at retail alcoholic liquor for use or
consumption on the premises.
LIQUOR LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any retail liquor licensed establishment in the village where alcoholic liquor is drawn, poured, mixed, or
otherwise served for consumption on the premises.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STATE LICENSE: Authorization granted by the Illinois gaming board permitting a licensee to engage in the defined activities of video gaming.
VETERANS' ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not for profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone
as a result of the operation and that is exempt from federal income taxation under section 501(c)(19) of the internal revenue code (26 USC 501(c)(19)).
VIDEO GAMING ACT: The Illinois video gaming act3.
VIDEO GAMING LICENSE: Authorization granted by the village permitting a gaming licensee to locate a video gaming terminal at a permitted location
in the village.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion of cash, is available to play or simulate the play of a video game,
including, but not limited to, video poker, line up, and blackjack, as authorized by the Illinois gaming board utilizing a video display and microprocessors
in which the player may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that directly dispenses
coins, cash, or tokens or is for amusement purposes only.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 78/498
VILLAGE: The village of Streamwood, Cook County, Illinois.
B. Premises Authorized: Premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor for consumption on the licensed premises only, licensed fraternal organizations and
licensed veterans' organizations, shall be authorized to operate and maintain up to five (5) video gaming terminals when so licensed by the Illinois
gaming board and the village of Streamwood.
C. License Fee: Every licensed establishment that is licensed to operate a video gaming terminal(s) by the Illinois gaming board pursuant to the provisions
of the Illinois video gaming act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., shall pay an annual license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) to the
village for each video gaming terminal located at the licensed establishment. Such license fee shall be in addition to any license fee imposed by the
Illinois gaming board.
1. The annual license fee shall be for a period ending on December 31 of each year.
2. Upon payment of the video gaming terminal license fee, the village clerk shall issue a video gaming license sticker which shall be affixed to each
video gaming terminal in a conspicuous place, readily identifiable upon public inspection. Video gaming terminal licenses shall not be transferable.
D. License Required: It shall be unlawful to operate a video gaming terminal in the village without having first paid the annual video gaming terminal
license fee.
E. Location: Video gaming terminals shall be located in an area that is restricted to persons over twenty one (21) years of age.
F. Hours: Video gaming terminals may not be operated or played during the hours alcoholic liquor sales are prohibited.
G. Compliance With State And Local Law: Every licensed video gaming location shall comply with all provisions of the Illinois video gaming act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed by the Illinois gaming board and all ordinances of the village. (Ord.
2013-20, 6-20-2013)
3-4-22: PEDDLING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. (1994 Code)
3-4-23: OFFENSES BY LICENSEE:
No licensee under the provisions of this chapter shall, either individually or through his agents or employees, do any of the following:
A. Canceled Revenue Stamps: Sell or possess for sale any package containing alcoholic liquor unless the same shall have affixed thereto all canceled
revenue stamps which may be required by law.
B. Serving Alcohol To Be Consumed Off Premises: Knowingly serve any alcoholic beverage to any person for consumption other than on the licensed
premises unless in its original package for consumption off the premises.
C. Permitting Alcohol Consumption On Premises: Permit any person to consume any alcoholic liquor on the premises described in the license unless such
alcoholic liquor has been purchased on the premises.
D. Exhibiting Intimate Apparel: Sell, offer for sale or exhibit any items of intimate apparel, including lingerie, undergarments, sleepwear or swimsuits on the
premises. (1994 Code)
E. Supplying Alcohol To Minors: Sell, give or deliver any alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated
person, or to any person known to him to be a habitual drunkard, insane, mentally ill, mentally deficient or in need of mental treatment. (Ord. 1999-47,
10-7-1999)
F. Bottle Service: Sell or offer for sale bottle service on the licensed premises.
G. Responsibility Of Licensee For Employee Actions: Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter by an officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, if such act is committed or omission is made within the scope of
such agency or employment or with the authorization, knowledge or approval of the licensee, shall be deemed and held to be the act of such employer
or licensee and such employer and licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the
licensee personally. (Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
3-4-24: RESPONSIBLE ALCOHOL SERVICE SERVER TRAINING:
A. All alcohol servers shall obtain and complete training in basic responsible alcohol service as provided in 77 Illinois administrative code 3500, by July 1,
2015, or within one hundred twenty (120) days after the alcohol server begins his or her employment, whichever is later.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 79/498
B. The renewal application for a class A, A-1, B, D, F, H, I, J, L, M, N and O license shall be accompanied with proof of completion of a state certified
alcohol education and training program.
C. A photocopy of the certificate of completion of a state certified alcohol education and training program for each server must be filed with the village clerk
and maintained in the manager's office of the licensed premises. (Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
3-4-25: ENTRY POWERS:
The local liquor commissioner is hereby given the power to enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon the premises licensed
hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of the dramshop act, 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes, or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by
the state liquor commission have been or are being violated and at such time to examine the premises of said licensee in connection therewith. (1994
Code)
3-4-26: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FINES:
A. Fines; Notice: The local liquor control commission may, in accordance with the Illinois liquor control act4, revoke or suspend any license issued under
the provisions of this chapter, if it determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of the Illinois liquor control act, this chapter or any
other ordinance or resolution enacted by the corporate authorities of the village, or any applicable rules or regulations established by the local liquor
commission or the Illinois liquor control commission, or any state and/or federal statute which is not inconsistent with the law. In addition to a
suspension or revocation, the local liquor control commission may levy a fine on the licensee for such violations. The fine imposed shall not exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a first violation within a twelve (12) month period, one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation
within a twelve (12) month period, and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month
period. Each day in which a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. Not more than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines under
this section may be imposed against any licensee during the one year license period. However, no such license shall be revoked or suspended nor
shall any licensee be fined except after a public hearing by the local liquor control commission after a three (3) day written notice to the licensee
affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend the charges contained in such notice. The three (3) day notice provision shall begin the day
following delivery of a notice of hearing to the licensee, by certified or registered mail or by personal service. Any fine imposed against a licensee
pursuant to this chapter shall constitute a debt due and owing the village of Streamwood and shall be paid to the village within thirty (30) days after
issuance of a written order levying a fine. Failure on the part of a licensee to pay any fine within thirty (30) days may subject the licensee to further
sanctions as herein provided.
B. Premises Threatens Welfare Of Community: If the local liquor control commission has reason to believe that any continued operation of a particular
licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community it may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason(s) for such
conclusion and without notice or hearing order the licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) days giving the licensee an opportunity to be
heard during that period except that if the licensee is also engaged in another business on the licensed premises such order shall not be applicable to
such other business. Notice of said hearing shall be in the manner herein provided.
C. Written Order: The local liquor control commission shall within five (5) days after such hearing, if it determines after such hearing that the license should
be revoked or suspended, and/or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order of revocation, suspension
and/or imposition of fine(s) and serve a copy of such order within five (5) days upon the licensee.
D. Review Of Decisions: Review of decisions of the local liquor control commission shall be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings of
the local liquor control commission, as provided for in paragraph 7-9 of the Illinois liquor control act.
E. Use Of Premises After Revocation: When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person or entity for the
period of one year thereafter for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the premises described in the revoked license unless the revocation order has been
vacated or unless the revocation order was entered as to the revoked licensee only. (Ord. 2015-26, 10-15-2015)
3-4-27: DISPLAYING LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his/her licenses to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place of the licensed premises. (1994 Code)
Chapter 5
AMUSEMENTS
ARTICLE 1. GENERAL PROVISIONS
3-5.1-1: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this Article, except as to licensing and fees, shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the Village,
whether specifically licensed in another article in this Chapter or not. (1994 Code)
3-5.1-2: LICENSES REQUIRED, APPLICATION AND FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 80/498
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the public and for admittance to which a fee is charged, without having first
obtained a license therefor; provided, that the provisions of this Section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by
any other ordinance of the Village, and where applicable all applications for licenses relating to amusements shall be accompanied by a certificate of
insurance showing the amount of liability insurance coverage by the applicant. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the Village Clerk, and shall
comply with all of the general provisions of this Code relating to such applications. See Section 3-2-2 of this Title for fees. (1994 Code)
3-5.1-3: ORDER, CROWDING:
The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such
amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risks.
(1994 Code)
3-5.1-4: STREET SHOWS:
No permit shall be granted or given for any carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such place that
the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public place, except on order of the President and Board of Trustees. (1994 Code)
3-5.1-5: ATHLETIC EXHIBITIONS:
It shall be unlawful to conduct, operate or exhibit any race between persons, animals or vehicles, or any baseball game, boxing or wrestling matches or
any other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged without having first procured a license therefor.
The proprietor of such exhibition shall submit to the Village Clerk a statement verified under oath of the gross receipts of such game, contest or race,
within one week after such exhibition. At the same time, the proprietor or person exhibiting or operating such exhibition shall pay to the Clerk a sum equal
to three percent (3%) of the gross receipts, after deducting the license fee paid. (1994 Code)
3-5.1-6: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to:
A. Indecent Shows: Present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of public
amusement or show.
B. Riots: Present any public amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance. (1994 Code)
3-5.1-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continue. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 2. COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT AND MUSIC DEVICES
3-5.2-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the indicated meanings unless from the context a different meaning clearly appears:
ADULT ATTENDANT: Adult attendant shall mean that a person not less than twenty one (21) years of age and an employee of the licensee shall be
present on the licensed premises at all times that the licensed premises are open for business.
AMUSEMENT ARCADE: An establishment open to the public which is used for the operation and maintenance of automatic amusement devices, as
hereinafter defined, and utilizing not less than eleven (11) nor more than fifty (50) automatic amusement devices.
AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT MACHINE: Any mechanical or video machine, fortune telling machine, palm reading machine, and machines and devices for
games of skill and science which returns to the player thereof no money or property or no right to receive money or property or other thing of value and
which is governed or controlled by the insertion of a coin, token, slug, currency or similar object.
GAME AREA: An establishment open to the public which is used for a purpose other than the operation and maintenance of automatic amusement
devices, but which operates and maintains more than five (5) but less than eleven (11) such automatic devices.
GAME AREA, LIQUOR ESTABLISHMENT: A game area conducted in a place of business licensed to sell liquor under a class A or class A-1 license of the
village. Such game areas shall be permitted to have five (5) or less automatic amusement devices.
GROSS PUBLIC FLOOR AREA: That portion of the licensed premises accessible to the public, excluding bathroom facilities.
SIMULATED VIDEO OR MECHANICAL GAMING DEVICES: Any video poker machine, video or mechanical slot machine (excluding inoperable antique
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 81/498
slot machines, as defined by section 28-1(b)(7) of the Illinois criminal code1), video or mechanical bingo machine or other device which involves any game
of chance or amusement based upon poker, blackjack, dog racing or horseracing, craps, and any card or dice game, or any similar device operated by
means of the insertion of a coin, token, slug, currency or similar object. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2004-8, 3-4-2004, eff. 1-1-2005)
3-5.2-2: RESTRICTIONS ON OPERATIONS:
A. No person shall keep, conduct or operate for profit any amusement arcade, game area or amusement device without first being licensed to do so as
hereinafter provided.
B. No amusement arcade or game area shall be kept, conducted or operated so as to constitute a public nuisance.
C. It shall be the responsibility of the licensee to maintain order on the licensed premises at all times.
D. Amusement arcade licenses shall provide not less than one parking space for each one hundred (100) square feet of gross public floor area and not
less than one slot in a bicycle rack for each two (2) automatic amusement devices being utilized. The maximum number of amusement arcade licenses
is five (5).
E. Game areas are prohibited from utilizing more than ten percent (10%) of their gross public floor area for automatic amusement devices. The maximum
number of game area licenses is six (6).
F. Game area, liquor establishments are prohibited from utilizing more than ten percent (10%) of their gross public floor area for automatic amusement
devices. The maximum number of game area, liquor establishment licenses is unlimited by this subsection but is limited by the number of authorized
retail liquor dealer licenses within the village, from time to time, authorizing sale of liquor by the drink only.
G. The licensee shall provide a full time, responsible adult attendant from the licensed premises during business hours.
H. All amusement arcades shall be special zoning uses.
I. All licenses required and described herein shall be purely grants of personal privileges and shall not constitute property; they shall not be transferable in
any manner. (1994 Code)
3-5.2-3: LICENSES:
Any person desiring to operate, keep, conduct or maintain an amusement arcade or game area or other amusement establishment wherein automatic
amusement machines or devices are operated or maintained for amusement of members of the public, shall adhere to the following procedures before any
license may be granted by the village:
A. Make written application to the village clerk, setting forth therein the information generally required by this code for business licenses and, in addition,
specifying the following:
1. Name: The applicant's full name (if a corporation, firm, partnership or association, all principals thereof must be listed with their addresses);
2. Residence Address: The applicant's residence address;
3. Business Address: The applicant's business address;
4. Proposed Address Of Arcade Or Game Area: The address of the proposed amusement arcade or game area;
5. Addresses Of Interested Persons: The name and address of every person who has any interest in the amusement arcade or game area and the
nature of that interest;
6. Felony Conviction: Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, or of pandering, gambling, operation of a gambling device,
operation of a gaming house or being a keeper of a house of ill fame, any offense associated with cannabis, alcohol or controlled substances or any
other misdemeanor;
7. Employee Interest: Whether or not the applicant, or his or her spouse, or any relative of the applicant is an employee or representative of the village,
and whether or not any employee or representative of the village is interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the license applied for, the
devices or the operation of the same; (1994 Code)
8. Description: A full description of the automatic amusement machine or machines, which description shall contain the manufacturer's name, the make
and the factory and serial numbers thereof for each machine license applied for. No license shall be issued for any simulated video or mechanical
gaming device. (Ord. 2004-8, 3-4-2004, eff. 1-1-2005)
9. Application Fee: All applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray the costs of investigation
and licensing. This application fee is not applicable for credit to the licensing fees hereunder.
B. The chief of police shall conduct an investigation of each person named in the application and submit a written report of his findings to the clerk and the
president and board of trustees of the village. (1994 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 82/498
C. Make written application to the planning and zoning board for a special use permit when applying for a game arcade in accordance with customary,
standard procedure. The planning and zoning board shall, in connection with its hearing on the application for a special use permit, consider the
following in addition to those matters customarily considered: (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
1. Information contained in the license application.
2. Proposed plans of the applicant to assure the health and safety of children.
3. The space to be allotted by the applicant for installation of the amusement devices. The recommendation standard shall be twenty five (25) square
feet per amusement device and no amusement device shall occupy a space less than four feet (4') wide. The recommended standard shall also
apply to game areas within the corporate limits of the village. (1994 Code)
D. The planning and zoning board shall, after proper hearing of the game arcade application, submit its recommendations concerning the grant of a
special use permit, and any reasonable conditions which should be attached thereto, to the village board. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
E. In the event the village board grants a special use permit for a game arcade, the applicant shall within ten (10) days thereafter remit necessary license
fees to the license clerk and thereupon the applicant shall be issued the appropriate business license and unit licenses. Any conditions of special use
as may be specified by the village board shall be listed on the business license, including the maximum number of machines which are authorized
under the license.
F. Every business license shall at all times during the life thereof be posted in a conspicuous place in the licensed establishment so that the same may be
easily read and seen.
G. Every unit (or device) license issued thereunder shall be issued for the number of machines requested under the business license for the establishment
and such license shall be conspicuously displayed in the licensed establishment. Individual units are not required to bear license stickers and the
licensee may interchange the machines on the licensed premises, provided that the number of units (or devices) shall not exceed at any time the total
number of machines authorized under the business license for the establishment. (1994 Code)
3-5.2-4: AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT AND GAMING DEVICES PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person or firm or corporation to keep, locate, maintain or operate any simulated video or mechanical gaming device in any area
open to the public within the village. (Ord. 2004-8, 3-4-2004, eff. 1-1-2005)
3-5.2-5: AUTOMATIC MUSIC DEVICES:
A. Definition: The term "automatic music device" means any phonograph, player piano, music box, jukebox or other instrument or device capable of
producing or reproducing vocal or instrumental sounds, other than a motion picture sound machine, which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a
coin or token.
B. License Required: No person shall keep or permit to be kept for gain or profit from operation within the village, any automatic musical instrument without
first having obtained a license as herein provided.
C. Application For License: An application for said license shall be made to the village clerk, in conformity with chapter 1 of this title, except as otherwise
herein provided. In addition, the applicant shall set forth the description of the automatic musical instrument or instruments intended to be kept or used
on his premises.
D. Transfer Of License: No license issued to any person shall be transferable.
E. Regulations: No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any automatic instrument at any place or in any manner which will disturb the
peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. No immoral or indecent selections shall be played on any such instrument. (1994 Code)
3-5.2-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 3. BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS
3-5.3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard, pool, bagatelle or pigeonhole table open to the public without having first obtained a license
therefor as is herein required. All applications for such a license shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number of tables
to be used therein. (1994 Code)
3-5.3-2: HOURS OF OPERATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 83/498
No hall licensed hereunder shall be used between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on a weekday or between the hours of
one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on a Sunday, except however, a billiard or pool hall which has been granted a liquor license shall
be allowed to stay open during the liquor hours allowed under said license. (1994 Code)
3-5.3-3: MINORS RESTRICTED:
Minors under the age of eighteen (18) years shall not, under any circumstances, frequent, loiter, stay or remain in any hall licensed hereunder at any time
unless it be upon some lawful errand and under the direction and the consent of and knowledge of the parent, guardian or other persons having the lawful
custody of such minor; and it shall be unlawful for the proprietor of any hall so licensed to allow or permit any such minor to frequent, loiter or remain within
the hall in violation of this Section. (1994 Code)
3-5.3-4: SALE OF ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR:
It shall be unlawful for any person owning, operating or conducting a billiard or pool table which is accessible to the general public to sell or permit the sale
of alcoholic liquor therein, except whenever said billiard or pool table is operated as part and parcel of a bowling alley and saidbowling alley has a permit
for the sale of alcoholic liquor therein. (Ord. 1995-5, 1-19-1995)
3-5.3-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 4. BOWLING ALLEYS
3-5.4-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open to the public without having first obtained a license therefor; application for such license shall be
made in writing and shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the number of alleys to be used. (1994 Code)
3-5.4-2: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No person shall keep open, operate or use any such alley between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., except, if said
bowling alley has a valid liquor license, the hours of said bowling alley shall be allowed to correspond to the hours of the liquor license. (1994 Code)
3-5.4-3: GAMBLING PROHIBITED:
