It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, bet or permit any form of gambling or betting in any premises used for a bowling alley, pin or ball alley. (1994
Code)
3-5.4-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 5. MOTION PICTURES, THEATRICALS
3-5.5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or theatrical for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given
solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license therefor as is
herein provided. (1994 Code)
3-5.5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the general provisions relating to such applications, and shall state in addition to the
other information required the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. (1994 Code)
3-5.5-3: OUTDOOR THEATERS:
Outdoor theaters where the audience is not housed in a building shall be conducted in full compliance with all applicable provisions of this Article. (1994
Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 84/498
3-5.5-4: CROWDING, ORDER:
It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is
presented during the time of such performance; and it shall be unlawful to admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating
arrangements for the premises. (1994 Code)
3-5.5-5: PROHIBITED PICTURES:
It shall be unlawful to permit any person to offer or presentany motion picture which has a tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace, or
any immoral, indecent or blasphemous picture or performance. (1994 Code)
3-5.5-6: OBSTRUCTING EXITS:
It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisles, corridors or exits leading from the room or enclosures in which a motion picture
performance or theatrical is being given or in which an audience for such a performance is gathered. (1994 Code)
3-5.5-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 6. PUBLIC DANCES
3-5.6-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the Village without having first obtained a license therefor as is herein required. (1994 Code)
3-5.6-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title relating to licenses, and shall specify the location
of the proposed dances and the person or organization sponsoring the dance.
No such license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented by a
person of good moral character. (1994 Code)
3-5.6-3: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT:
It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant and report the results of such
investigation to the Board of Trustees. (1994 Code)
3-5.6-4: CONDUCT AT DANCES:
It shall be unlawful to indulge in or to permit any improper or any immoral conduct at any public dance. (1994 Code)
3-5.6-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 7. SKATING RINKS
3-5.7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain a public skating rink in the Village without first having obtained a license therefor as is herein provided. (1994
Code)
3-5.7-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
Application for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title relating to licenses and shall specify the location of
the proposed skating rink and the person or organization sponsoring the same.

No such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the Village

3-5.7-3: OPERATION RESTRICTIONS:
A. It shall be unlawful to indulge in any improper conduct or to permit any improper conduct at any public skating rink.

ARTICLE 8. TEENAGE NIGHTCLUBS
3-5.8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE:
It shall be unlawful to operate a teenage nightclub in the village without first having obtained a license as herein provided and paying a fee as set forth in
section 3-2-2 of this title per year for said license. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2003-52, 11-20-2003)
3-5.8-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION; USE PERMIT:
Any person desiring to operate, keep, conduct or maintain a teenage nightclub shall adhere to the following procedures before any license may be granted
by the village:
A. Application For License; Fee: Make written application to the village clerk, setting forth therein the information generally required by this code for
business licenses and, in addition, specifying the following:
1. The applicant's full name (if a corporation, firm, partnership or association, all principals thereof must be listed with their addresses);
2. The applicant's residence address;
3. The applicant's business address;
4. The address of the proposed teenage nightclub;
5. The name and address of every person who has any interest in the teenage nightclub and the nature of that interest;
6. Whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, or of pandering, gambling, operation of a gambling device, operation of a gaming
house or being a keeper of a house of ill fame, any offense associated with cannabis, alcohol or controlled substances or any other misdemeanor;
7. All applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray the costs of investigation. This application
fee is not applicable for credit to the licensing fees hereunder.
B. Investigation: The chief of police shall conduct an investigation of each person named in the application and submit a written report of his findings to the
clerk and the president and board of trustees of the village. (1994 Code)
C. Special Use Permit: Make written application to the planning and zoning board for a special use permit when applying for a teenage nightclub in
accordance with customary, standard procedure. The planning and zoning board shall, in connection with its hearing on the application for a special
use permit, consider the following in addition to those matters customarily considered: (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
1. Information contained in the license application;
2. Proposed plans of the applicant to assure the health and safety of children. (1994 Code)
D. Hearing: The planning and zoning board shall, after proper hearing of the teenage nightclub application, submit its recommendations concerning the
grant of a special use permit, and any reasonable conditions which should be attached thereto, to the village board. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-
7-2015)
E. Issuance Of License; Conditions: In the event the village board grants a special use permit for a teenage nightclub, the applicant shall within ten (10)
days thereafter remit the necessary license fees to the license clerk and thereupon the applicant shall be issued the appropriate business license. Any
conditions of special use as may be specified by the village board shall be listed on the business license. Application for such license shall be made in
conformance with the provisions of chapter 1 of this title relating to licenses and shall specify location of the proposed teenage nightclub and the
person or organization sponsoring same. No such license shall be issued to a person who is not of good moral character, nor to a corporation or
organization which is not represented in the village by a person of good moral character. (1994 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 86/498
3-5.8-3: ADULT SUPERVISION:
It shall be unlawful to conduct a teenage nightclub on any premises at any time without adult supervision. An adult must be present at all times during
business hours. An adult attendant shall mean a person, not less than twenty one (21) years of age and an employee of the licensee. (1994 Code)
3-5.8-4: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No teenage nightclub shall operate prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. nor stay open after legal curfew. (1994 Code)
3-5.8-5: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES:
No alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on the premises or sold on the premises. (1994 Code)
3-5.8-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. In addition thereto, the president and board of trustees shall have the
right to rescind the business license of any teenage nightclub found to be causing a public nuisance or causing chronic complaints. (Ord. 1998-4, 1-8-
1998)
Chapter 6
FOOD DEALERS
ARTICLE 1. GENERAL PROVISIONS
3-6.1-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "food dealer" as used in this chapter shall be construed to mean and include every person, firm or corporation engaged in the sale of food or
beverage (other than intoxicating liquor) intended for human consumption.
The sale of any food or beverage by means of a coin operated vending machine shall be construed as conducting the business of a food dealer.
The term "food" as used in this chapter shall be construed to include beverages. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful for any food dealer to engage in or do business in the village without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such
licenses shall be made in compliance with the general provisions of this title relating thereto, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold or
handled. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-3: RULES AND REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
A. The 1998 edition of the state of Illinois department of public health food service sanitation rules and regulations, three (3) copies of which are on file in
the office of the village clerk, and any amendments thereto, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this code, subject to the additions,
amendments and deletions hereinafter set forth: (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001)
Amend section 750.1200 to read: take out "sealed concrete."
Add section:
750.101 - No food business will be allowed to operate any food or beverage storage or preparation out of a residential home or attached garage or
detached garage.
Sec. 750.1110 of said rules and regulations is hereby amended by adding thereto paragraphs e) and f) which paragraphs shall read as follows:
e) Every food service establishment which provides for the consumption of food or beverages on the premises including drive-in establishments, shall
provide adequate, conveniently located, public toilet facilities which comply with the Illinois State Plumbing Code. Toilet rooms shall not open directly
into any room which food, drink or utensils are handled or stored.
f) Hand washing signs shall be posted in all toilet facilities utilized by employees.
The words "Local Enforcement Authority" in said rules and regulations shall be understood to refer to the village of Streamwood. (1994 Code)
B. The 1992 edition of the Illinois department of public health retail food store sanitation rules and regulations, three (3) copies of which are on file in the
office of the village clerk, and any amendments or changes thereto, are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference into this code as the regulations
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 87/498
of the village for retail food stores. (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001)
C. The 1978 edition of the U.S. department of health, education and welfare "The Vending of Food and Beverages", three (3) copies of which are on file in
the office of the village clerk, and any amendments or changes thereto, are adopted and incorporated by reference into this code, subject to the
additions, amendments and/or deletions hereinafter set forth:
Sections 6-601 and 6-602 of said regulations are herewith deleted.
(1994 Code)
3-6.1-4: ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS:
A. Temporary Suspension Of Licenses: Licenses may be suspended temporarily by the health authority for failure of the holder to comply with the
requirements of this article.
Whenever a license holder or operator has failed to comply with any notice issued under the provisions of this article, the license holder or operator
shall be notified in writing that the license is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that a request for a hearing must be filed with the
health authority by the license holder. The suspension order shall be stayed pending any such hearing.
Notwithstanding the other provisions of this article, whenever the health authority finds unsanitary or other conditions in the operation of a food service
establishment or retail food store establishment which, in his judgment, constitute a substantial hazard to the public health, he may, without warning or
notice of hearing, issue a written notice to the license holder or operator citing such condition, specifying the corrective action to be taken, and
specifying the time period within which such action shall be taken; and, if deemed necessary, such order shall state that the license is immediately
suspended, and all food service operations are to be immediately discontinued. Any person to whom such an order is issued shall comply immediately
therewith, but upon written petition to the health authority, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible.
B. Reinstatement Of Suspended Licenses: Any person whose license has been suspended may, at any time, make application for a reinspection for the
purpose of reinstatement of the license. Within two (2) days following receipt of a written request, including a statement signed by the applicant that in
his opinion the conditions causing suspension of the license have been corrected, the health authority shall make a reinspection. If the applicant is
complying with the requirements of this article, the permit shall be reinstated.
C. Revocation Of Licenses: For serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this article, or for interference with the health authority in the
performance of his duties, the license may be permanently revoked after an opportunity for a hearing has been provided by the health authority. Prior to
such action, the health authority shall notify the license holder in writing, stating the reasons for which the license is subject to revocation and advising
that the license shall be permanently revoked at the end of five (5) days following service of such notice, unless a request for a hearing is filed with the
health authority, by the license holder, within such five (5) day period. A license may be suspended for cause pending its revocation or a hearing
thereto.
D. Hearings: The hearings provided for in this section shall be conducted by the village manager at a time and place designated by him or her. Based upon
the record of such hearing, the village manager shall make a finding to sustain, modify or rescind any official notice or order considered in the hearing.
All hearings for a license revocation or permanent closure of a food establishment or retail food store establishment shall likewise be before the village
manager. Based upon the record of such hearing, the village manager shall make a recommendation to the president and board of trustees whether to
permanently revoke such establishment. A written report of the hearing decision by the president and board of trustees shall be furnished to the license
holder by the health authority within five (5) days from the date said matter is decided by the president and board of trustees. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-5: INSPECTIONS:
A. Inspection Frequency: An inspection of a food service establishment or retail food store establishment shall be performed at least once every six (6)
months. All schools shall be inspected at least once a year. Additional inspections shall be performed as often as are deemed necessary for the
enforcement of this article. (Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001)
B. Access: Representatives of the regulatory authority, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any food service establishment or retail food
store establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this article. The representative shall be
permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received or used.
C. Report Of Inspections: Whenever an inspection of a food service establishment or retail food store establishment is made, the finding shall be
recollected on an inspection report form. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this article and shall set forth a weighted point
value for each requirement. Inspectional remarks shall be written to reference, by section number, the section violated and shall state the correction to
be made. The rating score of the establishment shall be the total of weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from one hundred (100). A copy
of the completed inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The
completed inspection report form is a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law.
D. Correction Of Violations:
1. The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violation found; and correction of the
violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions:
a. If any imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall
immediately cease food service operations. Operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the regulatory authority.
b. All violations of 4 - or 5 - point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within ten (10) days following inspection.
Within fifteen (15) days after the inspection, the holder of the permit, license or certificate shall submit a written report to the regulatory authority,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 88/498
stating that the 4 - or 5 - point weighted violations have been corrected. A follow up inspection shall be conducted to confirm correction at the
discretion of the Cook County health department.
c. All 1 - or 2 - point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection. (1994 Code)
d. When the rating score of the establishment is less than eighty (80), the establishment shall receive an additional inspection for compliance within
ninety (90) days of the previous inspection to assure compliance.
e. When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations within
forty eight (48) hours. A minimum of one or more reinspections will be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
f. In the case of temporary food service establishments, or retail food store establishments, all violations shall be corrected within twenty four (24)
hours. If violations are not corrected within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food service operations until
authorized to resume by the regulatory authority. (Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001)
2. The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food service operations. An
opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations or both will be provided if a written request is filed with the regulatory
authority within ten (10) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearings is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of
receipt of the request.
3. Whenever a food service establishment or retail food store establishment is required under the provisions of this subsection D to cease operations, it
shall not resume operations until it is shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. Opportunity
for reinspection shall be offered within a reasonable time. (1994 Code)
E. Posting Of Health Scores: All food service and retail food store establishments are required to post notice of a passing or failing health score at the front
entrance to the establishment. The form and placement of the notice shall be at the discretion of the community development director, or his designee.
For the purpose of this section, a passing score shall be considered to be a score of eighty (80) or above. (Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001)
3-6.1-6: PREMISES AND EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS:
From and after the effective date of this article, no existing food service establishment or retail food store establishment shall continue to operate within the
village unless it conforms with the requirements of this article; provided, however that equipment and facilities, installed in a food service establishment or
retail food store establishment prior to the effective date of this article, which do not fully meet all of the design and construction requirements of this
article, shall be deemed acceptable in that establishment if they are in good repair, capable of being maintained in a sanitary condition, and the food
contact surfaces are nontoxic.
A. New Food Service Establishments Or Retail Food Establishments: All food service establishments or retail food store establishments which are
hereafter constructed, reconstructed or extensively altered shall conform in such construction to the requirements of this article. New and replacement
equipment shall meet the requirements of this article as to construction and installation.
B. Plan Review, New Construction: Properly prepared plans, including equipment specifications and installation layouts, shall be submitted to the health
authority for review and approval before work is begun on the construction of new food service establishments or retail food store establishments or the
reconstruction or extensive alteration of existing ones. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-7: SALE OF FOOD FROM OUTSIDE VILLAGE JURISDICTION:
Food from food store establishments or retail food store establishments outside the jurisdiction of the village may be sold within the village if such food
service establishments or retail food store establishments conform to the provisions of this article or to substantially equivalent provisions. To determine
the extent of compliance with such provisions, the health authority may accept reports from the responsible authority or other jurisdictions where such food
service establishments or retail food store establishments are located. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-8: PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION SUSPECTED:
When the health authority has reasonable cause to suspect possibility of disease transmission from any food service establishment or retail food store
establishment or employee, he shall make such investigation as may be indicated, including the morbidity history of suspected employees and take
appropriate action. The health authority may require any or all of the following measures:
A. The immediate closure of the food service establishment or retail food store establishment concerned until, in the opinion of the health authority, no
further danger of disease outbreak exists. Upon such closure the establishment may open only upon written notice from the health authority.
B. The immediate exclusion of the employee from food service establishments or retail food store establishment.
C. Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of transmitting disease.
D. Adequate medical and laboratory examinations of the employee and, if deemed necessary, other employees. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-9: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION:
Samples of food and other substances may be determined or sampled by the health authority as often as may be necessary to determine freedom from
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 89/498
adulteration and misbranding and determine bacteriological contact. The health authority may request the condemnation of or request the removal,
destruction or denaturing of any food which is unwholesome, adulterated or misbranded. The health authority may, upon written notice to the owner or
person in charge, place a tag or hold order on any food which he determines, or has probable cause to believe to be unwholesome. Under a hold order,
food shall be permitted to be suitably stored. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or alter a hold order, notice or tag placed on food by the health
authority, and neither such food nor the containers thereof shall be relabeled, repacked, reprocessed, altered, disposed of, or destroyed without
permission of the health authority, except on order by a court of competent jurisdiction. The health authority may vacate the hold order, or may by written
order direct the owner or person in charge of the food, which was placed under the hold order, to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into
compliance with provisions of this article; provided, that such order shall be stayed if the order is appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction within three
(3) days. (1994 Code)
3-6.1-10: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each occasion. A separate
occasion shall be deemed existing on each day on which a violation continues or occurs. In addition thereto, such persons may be enjoined from
continuing such violations. (Ord. 1998-4, 1-8-1998)
3-6.1-11: FEES:
The cost of any and all inspections required under this article shall be borne by the licensee. The fee for each inspection is set at one hundred ten dollars
($110.00). (1994 Code; amd. Ord. 2001-53, 12-6-2001; Ord. 2014-30, 11-6-2014, eff. 12-1-2014)
ARTICLE 2. FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLES
3-6.2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to use any vehicle for the delivery or sale of food intended for human consumption in the Village at retail without having first secured a
license therefor. The term "food" as used in this Article shall include nonalcoholic beverages and milk. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for such license shall comply with the general provisions of Chapter 1 of this Title relating to applications for licenses. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-3: EXEMPTION:
No license fee shall be required for any vehicle used to deliver foodstuffs from any establishment which is licensed and inspected as a food dealing
establishment in the Village; but all provisions of this Article, other than that providing for the payment of a fee, shall be complied with in connection with
such vehicles. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-4: VEHICLE REGULATIONS:
All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. It shall be unlawful to permit
stale food, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used.
If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such goods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened and
protected against dust and insects. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-5: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the President and Board of Trustees to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance with
the provisions of this Article. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued under the provisions of this Article may be revoked by the President and Board of Trustees for any violation of any provision or
regulation hereof, and such revocation shall be in addition to any fine imposed by virtue of this Article. (1994 Code)
3-6.2-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 3. ICE CREAM VENDING VEHICLES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 90/498
3-6.3-1: DEFINITIONS:
ICE CREAM VENDING VEHICLE: A vehicle from which the retail sale by ice cream or similar confections of beverages for human consumption is
conducted from a roadway.
OWNER: The title holder of an ice cream or similar confections or beverage vending vehicle.
RETAIL SALE: The sale of ice cream or similar confections or beverage to the consumer thereof.
ROADWAY: Any public or private street, highway or road used by vehicles.
VEHICLE: Every motor vehicle which is mechanically propelled and designed to transport one or more persons.
VENDING: The act of selling, or offering to sell, any ice cream or similar confections or beverage for human consumption from an ice cream vending
vehicle on a roadway.
VENDOR: Any person who physically operates an ice cream vending vehicle or any person who physically conducts vending from such a vehicle. (1994
Code)
3-6.3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, offer for sale or expose for sale any ice cream or similar confection or beverage of any kind from a
truck or other self-propelled motor vehicle, whether or not the same remains in one place in the Village, without first having obtained a license for such
purpose according to Chapter 1 of this Title. (1994 Code)
3-6.3-3: LICENSE LIMITATIONS:
One license shall be required for each such truck or self-propelled motor vehicle being used and not more than four (4) licenses shall be issued or be in
effect at the same time. (1994 Code)
3-6.3-4: INSPECTION OF VEHICLE:
Prior to the issuance of said license, and after the issuance of said license, the licensee shall present to the Public Health Director each truck or other selfpropelled
motor vehicle for inspection as to the cleanliness and sanitation, no less often than every thirty (30) days. (1994 Code)
3-6.3-5: REQUIRED VEHICLE EQUIPMENT:
In addition to having a current State registration, complying with the provisions of this Article and other applicable provisions of this Code, vehicles used for
the vending of ice cream or similar confections or beverages shall be equipped with the following, which shall be in good working order:
A. A sign on the front and back of the vehicle which shall consist of reflective letters no less than three inches (3") in height and shall state "Caution -
Children Crossing".
B. A foldout, diamond-shaped sign on the left side of the vehicle which shall consist of black on yellow reflective letters no less than five inches (5") in
height and shall state "Slow". This sign shall be located at a height of between five feet (5') and eight feet (8') above ground level and shall be
displayed at a ninety degree (90°) angle to the left side of the vehicle whenever it is stopped for the purpose of vending.
C. Two (2) amber lights, each five inches (5") in diameter, mounted on the left and right front, and two (2) amber lights each five inches (5") in diameter,
mounted on the left and right rear of the vehicle, all at the top of the vehicle.
Each left light shall flash alternately from the opposing right light, and have sufficient lumens so that the flashing will be visible at a distance of five
hundred feet (500') whenever the vehicle is stopped for the purpose of vending.
D. A litter or trash container, visible and available to customers of the vending vehicle.
E. Equipment which will keep all perishable ice cream or similar confections at a temperature of zero degrees (0°) to minus ten degrees Fahrenheit
(-10°F). Beverages or other type confections on the vehicle shall be maintained at a temperature of below fifty degrees Fahrenheit (50°F). (1994 Code)
3-6.3-6: PROHIBITIONS ON CONDUCTING BUSINESS:
The following shall not be performed from a vending vehicle:
A. Vending from the left, or driver's side, of the vehicle. (1994 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 91/498
B. The emission of any amplified or electronic noise intended to advertise the presence of the vehicle. Manually operated bells may be utilized while the
vehicle is in motion. The emission of any noise to advertise the presence of the vehicle while the vehicle is stopped is prohibited. (Ord. 2002-20, 5-16-
2002)
C. Vending if the vehicle is not parked with the right side thereof to the curb or right side of the roadway.
D. Vending within a distance of one hundred feet (100') from the nearest intersecting roadway.
E. Vending before ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. any day, or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. any day.
F. Vending on any of the following roadways:
Barrington Road.
Irving Park Road (Route 19).
Lake Street (Route 20).
G. Conducting a sale to any customer who is standing on a roadway. (1994 Code)
3-6.3-7: OPERATORS' RESTRICTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or is the carrier of any infectious or contagious disease to conduct vending. (1994 Code)
3-6.3-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and each violation shall be
deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 1998-4, 1-8-1998)
Chapter 7
MERCHANTS
ARTICLE 1. BARBER AND BEAUTY COSMETOLOGY SHOPS
3-7.1-1: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW; RULES AND REGULATIONS:
3-7.1-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
BARBER SHOPS AND THE PRACTICE OF BARBERING: As defined in 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 410/2 et seq., inclusive.
BEAUTY SHOPS AND THE PRACTICE OF BEAUTY COSMETOLOGY: As defined in 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 410/3 et seq., inclusive. (1994 Code)
3-7.1-1-2: COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW:
No person shall operate a barber shop or beauty cosmetology shop except in full compliance with the State statute provisions as set forth in 225 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 410 et seq. (1994 Code)
3-7.1-1-3: INSPECTIONS:
The Superintendent of the Health Department, Health Officer or any other duly appointed assistant shall inspect barber and beauty cosmetology shops as
often as is necessary to ensure compliance with this Section 3-7.1-1. They shall be permitted entry to the premises for the purpose of making inspections.
(1994 Code)
3-7.1-1-4: PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Section 3-7.1-1 shall be fined, upon conviction, as set forthin Section 1-4-1 of this Code. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that a violation exists. (Ord. 1998-17, 3-19-1998)
3-7.1-2: VILLAGE LICENSING REGULATIONS, BARBERS, COSMETOLOGY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 92/498
3-7.1-2-1: DEFINITION:
The word "barber" shall mean every person who shaves or trims the beard; cuts the hair; gives facial or scalp treatments with oils or creams or other
preparations made for that purpose, either by hand or by mechanical appliances; singes or shampoos the hair; applies hair tonic to, or dyes the hair of any
person; or who supervises or manages any persons who do the foregoing.
The word "cosmetologist" shall mean a person who performs any one or any combination of the following practices when done for cosmetic or beautifying
purposes and not for the treatment of disease or of muscular or nervous disorder: arranging, dressing, cutting, trimming, curling, waving, chemical
restructuring, shaping, singeing, bleaching, coloring or similar work, upon the hair of any person; any practice of manicuring, pedicuring, decorating nails,
applying sculptured nails or otherwise artificial nails by hand or with mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliances, or in any way caring for the nails of
another person for other than therapeutic purposes; any practice of epilation or depilation of any person; any practice for the purpose of cleansing,
massaging or toning the skin of the scalp; beautifying, massaging, cleansing or stimulating the skin of the human body by the use of cosmetic
preparations, antiseptics, tonics, lotions or creams or any device, electrical or otherwise, for the care of the skin; applying make-up or eyelashes to any
person, tinting eyelashes and eyebrows and lightening hair on the body and removing superfluous hair from the body of any person by the use of
depilatories, waxing or tweezers. Nothing in this Section 3-7.1-2 shall be construed to prohibit the shampooing of hair by persons employed for that
purpose and who perform that task under the direct supervision of a licensed cosmetologist. (1994 Code)
3-7.1-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a barber without first having obtained a Village license therefor, as hereinafter provided.
(1994 Code)
3-7.1-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The Village Clerk shall issue such license where such barber has furnished the Clerk with the following information:
A. His/her name and residence address;
B. The name and address of his/her employer, if any as such barber in the Village;
C. The address of the location of his/her barbering/cosmetology activities in the Village; and
D. Adequate evidence of his/her having been licensed as such barber or cosmetology under the laws of this State, including his State license number or
photocopy of same. (1994 Code)
3-7.1-2-4: TRANSFERABILITY OF LICENSE, POSTING:
No license issued hereunder shall be transferable to any other person, but can be used at another location in the Village by the same person, after such
licensee has given notice of his change of location to the Village Clerk. Every license issued hereunder shall be prominently displayed in the place of
business of each barber. (1994 Code)
3-7.1-2-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this Section 3-7.1-2 shall be fined as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code; and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 2. CIGARETTE, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE AND TOBACCO DEALERS
3-7.2-1: DEFINITIONS:
A. As used in this article, the following words shall have the following meanings:
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE OR E-CIGARETTE: An electronic device usually composed of a mouthpiece, a heating element or atomizer, a battery,
and electronic circuits that provide a gas derived from liquid nicotine and/or other substances which is inhaled by a user simulating smoking. The
term includes such devices, regardless of the details of the product appearance or marketed name, generally manufactured to resemble cigarettes,
cigars, pipes, or other smoking devices.
LIQUID NICOTINE: Any liquid product composed either in whole or part of nicotine, propylene glycol and/or other similar substances and
manufactured for use with an electronic cigarette to be converted into gas for inhaling.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing
tobacco or dipping tobacco. (Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014)
3-7.2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 93/498
It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale of electronic cigarettes, cigarettes, cigars, tobacco products or liquid nicotine in any form at retail without having
first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the village clerk and no such license shall be issued to any person who is
not a person of good character or to any corporation, partnership or other entity that is not represented in the village by a person of good character. (Ord.
2014-22, 9-4-2014)
3-7.2-3: CIGARETTE VENDING MACHINES:
A. Compliance With Article Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or maintain any cigarette or tobacco product vending machine without complying with
the provisions of this article.
B. Locking Device Required On Vending Machine: It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away, deliver, or to keep with the
intention of selling, giving away or delivering, tobacco products by the use of a vending machine unless such vending machine is equipped with a
manual, electric or electronic locking device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of eighteen (18).
C. Exemption: Any premises where access by persons under the age of eighteen (18) years is prohibited by law or premises where the public is generally
not permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of the employees of a business located at such premises shall be exempt from the
requirements of subsection A of this section. (Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014)
3-7.2-4: PROHIBITED SALES, DELIVERY, SIGNS:
A. Minors: It shall be unlawful to sell, give or deliver cigarettes, cigars, tobacco products, electronic cigarettes or liquid nicotine in any form to a person
under the age of eighteen (18) years. In every location where electronic cigarettes, liquid nicotine, tobacco products, cigars or cigarettes are sold, there
shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place, at or near the point of sale, the following warning:
WARNING TO MINORS
YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE OF UP TO $750.00 UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE STREAMWOOD VILLAGE CODE IF YOU PURCHASE
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES, LIQUID NICOTINE, CIGARETTES, CIGARS OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS IN ANY FORM OR MISREPRESENT
YOUR AGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PURCHASING OR OBTAINING ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES, LIQUID NICOTINE, CIGARETTES, CIGARS
OR TOBACCO PRODUCTS IN ANY FORM.
B. Display Of Products: It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, or display electronic cigarettes, liquid nicotine, cigarettes, cigars or tobacco
products, in any form, for sale at any location where the consumer can acquire those products through self-service. All electronic cigarettes, liquid
nicotine, cigarettes, cigars and tobacco products shall be displayed from behind a sales/service counter so that no consumer can access such items
without assistance by an employee of the licensee. This restriction shall not apply to consumer self-service from vending machines as described in
subsection 3-7.2-3B of this article. (Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014)
3-7.2-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed
on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. A second or subsequent offense of this article within a twelve (12) month period shall
subject a license holder to a suspension or revocation of the retail license issued pursuant to this article. (Ord. 2014-22, 9-4-2014)
ARTICLE 3. PEDDLERS
3-7.3-1: DEFINITION:
The word "peddler" is hereby defined to mean any individual who, going from place to place, shall sell, offer for sale, sell and deliver, barter or exchange
any goods, wares, merchandise or country produce from a vehicle or otherwise. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of peddler without a license so to do. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Every individual who desires a license as a peddler shall make application therefor to the village clerk in writing upon the form prescribed by the chief of
police and approved by the village board. The nature of the acts or things permitted by the license shall be in accord with the application. Any applicant for
a license hereunder shall submit to being fingerprinted and photographed by the village police department, which department shall, prior to the issuance of
any license, complete its verifying of such information as such applicant may furnish in connection with such application for license. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-4: LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 94/498
Such peddler's license shall not be transferable and shall be a license only for the individual named therein. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-5: LICENSE TERM:
The term and fee for such license shall be as set forth in section 3-2-2 of this title, under peddlers and solicitors. (Ord. 2004-10, 3-4-2004)
3-7.3-6: TIME LIMIT ON PEDDLING:
No peddler shall act as a peddler within the village on Sunday or national holidays or between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M., inclusive. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-7: FRAUD, IMPOSITION AND MISREPRESENTATION:
Any peddler who shall be guilty of fraud, misrepresentation or imposition on any citizen within the village shall be in violation of this article and shall be
fined in accordance with the penalties hereof. (1994 Code)
3-7.3-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 4. SOLICITORS
3-7.4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Article, the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the meanings herein ascribed thereto:
HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular travel.
PERSON: Every natural person, firm, copartnership, association or corporation.
REGISTERED SOLICITOR: Any person who has obtained a valid badge of registration as hereinafter provided and which badge of registration is
prominently displayed on his or her person while engaged in soliciting.
RESIDENCE: Every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure.
SOLICITING: Any one or more of the following activities seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of
any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; or
seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication; or
seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable ornonprofit association,
organization, corporation or project. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-2: BADGE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED, EXCEPTION:
No person shall engage in soliciting as herein defined from persons in residences within the Village without being registered under the provisions
contained in this Article and being issued a badge of registration containing the solicitor's picture. The badge of registration is to be conspicuously
displayed on the person of each solicitor. The issuance of a solicitor's badge shall be a critical step in the registration procedure, and the revocation or
denial of such solicitor's badge shall constitute a failure to register under the provisions contained in this Article.
Badges of registration shall not be necessary for distributors of local and area newspapers. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-3: APPLICATION FOR BADGE OF REGISTRATION:
A. Application for a badge of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the Village Clerk and filed with such Chief. The applicant shall truthfully
state in full the following information requested on the application:
1. Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at such address; also business address if other than residence address;
also social security number;
2. Address of place of residence;
3. Age of applicant;
4. Physical description of the applicant;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 95/498
5. Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association whom the applicant is employed by or represents;
6. Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the soliciting which the applicant will engage in;
7. Period of time for which the badge is applied for;
8. Has a badge of registration issued to the applicant under this article ever been revoked;
9. Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the
United States.
B. All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath.
C. The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other
information and data pertaining thereto and all badges of registration issued under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of applications.
Applications for badges shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every badge issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the
duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-4: LICENSE FEES AND DURATION:
The term and fee for such license shall be as set forth in section 3-2-2 of this title under peddlers and solicitors. There shall be no fees charged for not for
profit organizations or groups other than the actual cost of the badge. However, not for profit organizations or groups shall make application for badges of
registration by the use of only one application which contains, in addition to the information required in section 3-7.4-3 of this article, for the person making
the application, the names and addresses of all of the solicitors for that organization. The fee shall not apply to those services exempted by Illinois law.
Badges of registration shall be returned to the village clerk within five (5) days of its expiration. (Ord. 2004-10, 3-4-2004)
3-7.4-5: ISSUANCE AND REVOCATION OF BADGES:
No badge of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state
or federal law of the United States, within five (5) years of the date of the application; not to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this article, nor to any person whose badge of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided, nor to any
person who has made a false material statement on the application provided for herein.
Any badge of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the badge is convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a badge of
registration under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the
badge in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his residence address set forth in the application. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-6: TIME LIMIT OF SOLICITATION:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute anuisance for any reason, whether registered under this article or not, to go upon any premises
and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door; or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof to engage in
"soliciting" as herein defined, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any weekday, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. on Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or a state or national holiday. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-7: FAILURE TO LEAVE PREMISES UPON REQUEST:
It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in solicitation on the premises of any residence or dwelling unit to remain thereon after having been asked by
the owner or occupant thereof to leave such premises. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-8: SOLICITATION AT PRINCIPAL ENTRANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in solicitation to seek entry at any entrance to a residence or dwelling unit other than the principal entrance.
(1994 Code)
3-7.4-9: "NO SOLICITING" DECAL:
The Chief of Police shall cause to be printed a decal which shall read "No Soliciting by Order of Police Department" and shall make said decals available
to citizens of the Village who shall reimburse the Village for the cost of printing the decal. It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a
nuisance for any person, whether registered under this Article or not, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence
located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such
residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engaging in soliciting as herein defined, where such residence has the
above mentioned decal posted in a conspicuous place at its principal entrance. (1994 Code)
3-7.4-10: SOLICITATION ON HIGHWAYS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 96/498
No person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except as expressly provided for herein.
Solicitation on highways within the Village shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full stop. In addition to otherwise
complying with all other provisions of this Article, the soliciting agency shall:
A. Be registered with the Illinois Attorney General as a charitable organization as provided by "An Act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for
charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefor," approved July 26, 1963, as amended;
B. Be engaged in a Statewide fund raising activity; and
C. Be liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is casually related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
Any person engaged in the act of solicitation on a highway shall be sixteen (16) years of age or more and shall be wearing a high visibility vest. (1994
Code)
3-7.4-11: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine as set forth in Section 1-4-1 of this Code for
each offense. (Ord. 1998-4, 1-8-1998)
ARTICLE 5. TAXICABS/LIMOUSINES
3-7.5-1: DEFINITION:
A "taxicab" is herein defined to be any motor vehicle carrying not more than eight (8) fare paying passengers for hire and for which public patronage is
solicited and not being operated over fixed routes or of fixed time schedules including limousine service. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any taxicab or engage in the business of operating taxicabs in the village, including the operation of
one or more such vehicles, without obtaining a taxicab vehicle license for each such taxicab operated, as provided in this article and otherwise conforming
to the requirements of this code and applicable provisions of other ordinances of the village. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-3: NUMBER OF PASSENGERS:
No driver or operator of a taxicab shall carry more than eight (8) persons at any one time, nor shall he carry any other person than the person first
employing the taxicab, without the consent of the first passenger. Neither shall any person, other than the driver and the passenger being conveyed,
occupy any taxicab while the taxicab is carrying passengers. It shall be the duty and responsibility of the driver to notify the initial passenger of the rate of
fare and/or any changes thereof. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-4: INSPECTION:
No vehicle shall be licensed as a taxicab under the provisions of this article, until it has been inspected by the Illinois department of transportation (safety
lane) as designated by the village manager or his designee. Said inspections shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions set forth in this article
and said approval shall be made by the village manager or his designee. The cost of said inspection is to be borne by the owners of the respective cab
companies. Such inspection shall be made prior to the issuance of a license or renewal of said license, according to the provisions of this article. The
village manager or his designee may cause a subsequent inspection of said vehicle to be made periodically, by any individual the village manager or his
designee shall designate and such inspection shall include the following: condition of tires, including spare tire, cleanliness, general appearance, facilities
for transportation of passengers in rear compartment, and condition and accuracy of taximeter, except there shall be no requirement to test a taximeter in
a limousine. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-5: APPLICATION RENEWAL:
Each license issued thereunder shall be valid for the calendar year in which it is issued and shall be renewed only upon application by the holder thereof.
(1994 Code)
3-7.5-6: APPLICATION AND FEE:
Application for taxicab licenses shall be made in writing to the village clerk and signed and sworn to by the applicant or if the applicant is a corporation, by
its duly authorized agent upon forms provided by the clerk. The application shall contain the full name, business address and residence address of the
applicant, the business telephone number of the applicant, the manufacturer's name, model, year of car, horsepower, and seating capacity of the vehicle
which applicant seeks to use. A separate application and separate license is required for each vehicle to be operated as a taxicab or public passenger
vehicle. The term and fee for engaging in the business of owning and operating taxicabs or causing them to be operated shall be as set forth in section 3-
1-7 of this title and the term and fee for each additional taxicab covered by the application for permit shall be as set forth in section 3-2-2 of this title. (Ord.
2004-10, 3-4-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 97/498
3-7.5-7: BOND AND INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No such license shall be issued to any person unless the applicant has secured the bond provided by statute and unless he has submitted to the village
clerk, a copy or copies of his or their insurance policies, or certificate or certificates ofinsurance, demonstrating public liability insurance coverage payable
for personal injuries in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for each person and three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000.00) for each accident, and payable for property damage in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each accident. If at
any time in the judgment of the village manager or his designee, a policy of insurance given pursuant to this section is not sufficient for any good cause,
the village manager or his designee may require the owner of the taxicab who filed the same, to replace that policy of insurance with another good and
sufficient bond or insurance policy which complies with the provisions of this section. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-8: DRIVER'S REQUIREMENTS:
A. No license shall be issued to any person, to operate a taxicab within the village, including owners thereof, until he or she shall first have met the
application requirements herein. Each driver who shall drive any licensed taxicab in the village shall:
1. Be licensed by the state of Illinois;
2. Be eighteen (18) years of age or older;
3. Be first submitted to fingerprinting by the chief of police of this village or by a person whom he shall designate;
4. Have first submitted to photographing by the chief of police of this village or by a person whom he shall designate;
5. Have first paid an application fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) which shall be used to defray the cost of processing the application.
B. Any person desiring to secure a license with the village shall make an application in writing with the village clerk, together with the above said license
fee. The village clerk shall supply said applicant with a license application form which shall set forth the name of applicant, his driver's license number,
and other pertinent information. It shall further require that the applicant attest to whether or not he has been convicted of a felony or driving under the
influence of intoxicating beverages;
C. No license shall be issued to any applicant if the results of the foregoing examination are unsatisfactory in any respect, nor to an applicant who made
false statements on his application. After the foregoing examination has been completed and the inspections required by this article have been made,
the police chief and any person so designated by him, shall endorse on the application his recommendation as to whether the license shall be issued
and thereupon forward said application to the village clerk, who shall issue saidlicense;
D. The annual fee to operate a taxicab shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per operator. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-9: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
The village manager or his designee is empowered and directed to revoke or suspend the license of any person owning and operating any taxicab found
not to be in safe condition, and in good condition with respect to appearance, cleanliness and mechanical operation, or is found not to be in accord with
the provisions of this article. Licenses when so suspended or revoked shall not be reissued until such vehicle and its appurtenances are put in fit condition
for use by the public in a manner that is satisfactory to the chief of police. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-10: NAME OF VEHICLE:
Every vehicle licensed as aforesaid shall bear on both sides of the vehicle thereof, in a conspicuous place, the name of the owner thereof, in letters not
less than two inches (2") high, which letters shall be of a color in contrast to the color of the vehicle, and shall be properly proportioned and legible.
If any licensee operates more than one taxicab, each vehicle should be numbered with figures not less than two inches (2") high and no two (2) vehicles
shall bear the same number. This section shall not apply to limousines; except that the operator of a limousine shall immediately identify the company
name upon request. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-11: CONDITION OF VEHICLES:
All vehicles licensed under this article must be kept in a safe, clean, and sanitary condition, and must be equipped with properly working brakes, lights and
warning signals, in accordance with the motor vehicle laws of the state, this article and the ordinances of the village, and no license shall be issued for the
operation of any public passenger vehicle under this Article until it is shown to be in good mechanical condition. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-12: VEHICLE LICENSE AND DRIVER'S LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE:
Neither the public passenger vehicle license nor the taxicab and livery cab driver's licenses provided for in this article shall be transferable. (1994 Code)
3-7.5-13: NUMBER OF TAXICABS OPERATING IN VILLAGE:
The village shall have the right to limit the number of taxicab companies and licensees operating in the village. (1994 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 98/498
3-7.5-14: PENALTIES:
A. No person shall engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the village without first obtaining the permit required by section 3-7.5-6 of this article.
Every person who is found guilty of violating this section shall be punished by a fine as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day a violation exists.
B. No person shall operate a taxicab in the village without first obtaining the permit required by section 3-7.5-8 of this article. Every person who is found
guilty of violating this section shall be punished by a fine as set forth in section 1-4-1 of this code for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed for each day a violation exits. (Ord. 1998-4, 1-8-1998)
ARTICLE 6. GASOLINE SERVICE STATIONS
3-7.6-1: DEFINITION:
A "service station" is any place of business where gasoline, or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines, are sold or
offered for sale at retail, and dispensed into fuel tanks of such motor vehicles. (1994 Code)
3-7.6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
It shall be unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the Village without having first obtained a license therefor.
No such license shall be issued unless the location and equipment to be used fully comply with the provisions of this Code.
The annual fee for such license shall be as set forth in Section 3-2-2 of this Title. (1994 Code)
ARTICLE 7. MASSAGE
3-7.7-1: DEFINITIONS:
MASSAGE OR MASSAGE THERAPY: Any method of pressure on or friction, including, but not limited to, rubbing or kneading, against the external parts
of the human body with the hands or a device, with or without supplementary aids, in exchange for money or any other consideration. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-
1999)
3-7.7-2: REGISTRATION REQUIRED:
A. Requirements: No person shall engage in the practice of massage or massage therapy in the Village unless:
1. He or she is a professional licensed by the State of Illinois, including, but not limited to, physicians, nurses, physical or occupational therapists,
athletic trainers, chiropractors, podiatrists, naprapaths, barbers, cosmetologists, estheticians or nail technologists, limited to performing massage or
massage therapy in a manner consistent with and permitted by his or her State license, or
2. He or she is a massage therapist who:
a. Has graduated from a five hundred (500) hour massage therapy school approved by the American Massage Therapy Association Commission on
Accreditation and Training and/or approved by the Illinois State Board of Education, or is currently enrolled in such a school and is working under
the direct supervision of a licensed massage therapist, and
b. Is an active professional member in good standing of the American Massage Therapy Association, and
c. Is practicing massage therapy in a location where he or she is associated with the practice of a professional licensed by the State, including the
practice of a physician, nurse, physical or occupational therapist, athletic trainer, chiropractor, podiatrist, naprapath, barber, cosmetologist,
esthetician or nail technologist, and
d. Has registered his or her practice with the Village as required in subsection C of this Section.
B. Massage In Salons And Spas: In the case of a barbershop, or cosmetology, esthetics or nail technology salon where a massage therapist will operate:
1. The shop or salon must also be licensed by the State under 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 410/3D-5, and
2. Massage facilities may make up only twenty five percent (25%) or less of the floor space of such shop or salon.
C. Registration:
1. All persons who practice massage therapy in the Village of Streamwood must register with the Village. Such registration shall be made with the
Village Clerk, and shall include:
a. Written evidence that such person has met the requirements to practice massage therapy in the Village as outlined in subsection A2 of this
Section, and
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 99/498
b. Submission of personal/biographical information on a form prepared by the Village Clerk, and
c. A complete listing of all locations where he or she will practice massage therapy, as well as the name and state license number of the licensed
professional with whom the massage therapist's practice will be associated with, and (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999)
d. The payment of an annual registration fee as set forth in section 3-2-2 of this title. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999; amd. Ord. 2003-52, 11-20-2003)
2. A person applying for registration as a massage therapist in the village must also submit to and pass a criminal background check in order to qualify
for registration. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999)
3. A massage therapist who is properly registered with the village will receive a "certificate of registration" which will be good for one year. The
certificate must be renewed annually, at a cost as set forth in section 3-2-2 of this title. Registered therapists shall provide the village with any
changes to his or her registration within thirty (30) days of their occurrence, including changes of address or a change in the place or places of
practice. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999; amd. Ord. 2003-52, 11-20-2003)
4. Registration under this section shall not be required for professionals licensed by the state, including, but not limited to, physicians, nurses, physical
or occupational therapists, athletic trainers, chiropractors, podiatrists, naprapaths, barbers, cosmetologists or estheticians, who are performing
massage or massage therapy in a manner consistent with and permitted by his or her state license. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999)
3-7.7-3: RESTRICTIONS:
A. Outcall massage, or any massage therapy conducted off the premises of the place of registration shall be prohibited, unless performed on an invalid or
other person under the care of a licensed physician.
B. No person shall, while practicing massage therapy under this article, touch the sexual or genital parts of another person in any way. Sexual or genital
parts include all genitals, pubic regions, the buttocks and female breasts.
C. All persons who practice massage therapy shall be clothed in clean, nontransparent outer garments that provide complete coverage of the massage
therapist's person from the neck to the knee. (Ord. 1999-68, 12-2-1999)
3-7.7-4: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
A. It is unlawful to practice massage therapy in violation of this article. A person found in violation of this article or a person who practices massage therapy
without a valid registration as hereby required may have his or her registration revoked or application for registration denied. Additionally, such a
person may be banned from practicing massage therapy within the village for up to five (5) years and may be subject to a fine of up to five hundred
dollars ($500.00) per violation.
B. Any person registered to practice massage therapy in the village may have his or her registration revoked if he or she is found to have violated any
provision of this code, state or federal law.
C. The village clerk is charged with the administration of this article and may make all necessary and appropriate rules to provide for its enforcement. (Ord.
1999-68, 12-2-1999)
ARTICLE 8. ANIMAL CARE AND SALE
3-7.8-1: LICENSE REQUIRED, APPLICATION:
It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale or care of animals without having first obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made to
the village clerk and no such license shall be issued to any person who is not a person of good character or to any corporation that is not represented in
the village by a person of good character. (Ord. 2003-52, 11-20-2003)
3-7.8-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article, the following terms mean:
ANIMAL: Any live, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild.
COMMERCIAL ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENT: Any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, riding school or stable, zoological park, circus, performing animal
exhibition, or kennel.
KENNEL: Any premises wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs or
cats.
PET SHOP: Any establishment for the buying, selling or boarding of any species of animal, whether operated separately or in connection with another
business enterprise, except for a licensed kennel.
SHELTER: Any facility used to house animals for sale or care. (Ord. 2003-52, 11-20-2003)
3-7.8-3: STANDARDS FOR BUILDINGS AND PREMISES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 100/498
In order for any business to be licensed hereunder, the following minimum standards for the buildings and premises shall be followed:
A. Buildings: All housing facilities for animals must be:
1. Designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound;
2. Kept in good repair, protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering; and
3. Floors of buildings, that house or display animals, must be of permanent construction to enable thorough cleaning and sanitizing. Dirt and unfinished
wood floors are not permitted. Cleaning must be performed daily, or more often, to prevent accumulation of debris, dirt or waste.
B. Surfaces: All interior surfaces shall comply with the following:
1. Interior surfaces or any surfaces that come into contact with any animal must:
a. Be free of excessive rust that prevents the required cleaning and sanitation, or that affects the structural strength of the surface; and
b. Be free of jagged edges or sharp points that might injure the animals.
2. Hard surfaces that animals come into contact with must be spot cleaned daily and sanitized to prevent accumulation of excreta and reduce disease
hazards.
3. Floors made of absorbent bedding, sand, gravel, grass, or other similar material must be raked or spot cleaned with sufficient frequency to ensure all
animals freedom to avoid contact with excreta.
4. All other surfaces of housing facilities must be cleaned and sanitized daily.
5. The floors and walls of housing facilities, and any other surfaces that come into contact with the animals, must be impervious to moisture.
6. The ceilings of housing facilities must be impervious to moisture or be replaceable (e.g., a suspended ceiling with replaceable ceiling panels).
C. Shelter:
1. Dogs and cats must be provided with adequate shelter from the elements at all times to protect their health and well being.
2. The shelter structures must be large enough to allow each animal to sit, stand, and lie in a normal manner and to turn around freely.
3. All housing facilities and must provide adequate facilities for the separation of diseased animals to avoid exposure tohealthy animals.
D. Primary Enclosures:
1. General Requirements: Primary enclosures must:
a. Be constructed of a material that is impervious to urine and water and able to withstand damage from gnawing and chewing.
b. Be designed and constructed of suitable material so that they are structurally sound.
c. Be kept in good repair.
d. Be constructed and maintained so that they:
(1) Have no sharp points or edges that could injure the animals.
(2) Protect the animals from injury.
(3) Keep other animals from entering the enclosure.
(4) Contain the animals securely.
(5) Enable the animals to keep dry and clean.
(6) Provide shelter and protection from extreme temperature and weather conditions.
(7) Provide sufficient shade to shelter all the animals housed in the primary enclosure at one time.
(8) Provide all animals with easy and convenient access to clean food and water.
(9) Have surfaces that can be readily cleaned and sanitized.
(10) Have floors that are constructed in a manner that protects the animals' feet and legs from injury, and that, if a mesh or slatted construction, do
not allow the animals' feet to pass through any part of the floor.
e. Be cleaned and sanitized at least once a day, or more often if necessary, and all empty cages must be kept clean at all times.
f. Be of sufficient size to allow the animal to comfortably stand, sit, and lie, and offer freedom of movement (permanent tethering is prohibited).
2. Minimum Space Requirements: Primary enclosures for animals shall be as follows:
a. Primary Enclosures For Cats: Each cat, including weaned kittens, that is housed in any primary enclosure shall be provided minimum vertical
height and space as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 101/498
(1) Must be at least twenty one inches (21") high.
(2) Cats up to and including nine (9) pounds must be provided at least three (3) square feet of open floor space.
(3) Cats over nine (9) pounds must be provided at least four (4) square feet of open floor space.
(4) If more than one cat occupies these primary enclosures, space will be figured for the first cat, with each additional cat needing one-half (1/2) of
the minimum space required.
b. Primary Enclosures For Dogs: Each primary enclosure, in which a dog spends the majority of its day, shall have the following minimum
requirements:
(1) Small dogs up to ten inches (10") high: 4.5 square feet.
(2) Small dogs up to sixteen inches (16") high: 6.0 square feet.
(3) Medium dogs up to twenty two inches (22") high: 9.0 square feet.
(4) Large dogs up to twenty six inches (26") high: 12 square feet.
(5) Extra large dogs up to thirty inches (30") high: 16 square feet.
(6) Giant breeds over thirty inches (30") high: 18 square feet.
(7) The height shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the height of the dog at the shoulder.
(8) If more than one dog occupies these primary enclosures, space will be figured for the first dog, with each additional dog needing one-half (1/2)
of the minimum space required.
E. Runs And Exercise Areas:
1. The length of the runs and the exercise areas should be at a minimum three (3) times the length of the dog, from the tip of the nose to the base of
the tail. The width should allow the dog to turn around easily, and the height shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the height of the dog.
2. Runs shall be constructed of material of sufficient strength and design to confine the animal(s).
3. They shall be kept in good repair and condition.
4. Surface of the run shall be designed to permit the surface to be cleaned and kept free from excessive accumulation of animal waste.
F. Water And Electrical Power:
1. The housing facilities must have reliable electrical power for heating, cooling, ventilation, and lighting.
