(Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-4-3: EASEMENTS:
A. Easement Design And Location: Utility distribution or transmission installations serving the subdivision, and when required, stormwater drainageways
shall be located in easements as designated on the subdivision plat of record. Such easements shall be located along the rear lot lines or side lot lines
at locations and extensions of utility installation between blocks, or continuity of drainageway. Easement width shall be a minimum of five feet (5') or as
required by the village engineer, local utility providers including, but not limited to, electric, gas, telephone, cable TV and/or internet services. Additional
easements at other locations may be recommended for specific condition by the village engineer and required by the board of trustees.
B. Continuity Of Easements: Easements shall be designed to provide continuity from block to block.
C. Drainage Easements: Where a subdivision is traversed by a natural drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a drainage easement,
conforming substantially with the areas bordering such watercourse that are subject to flooding, and in accordance with the Streamwood master
drainage plan. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-4-4: BLOCKS:
A. Configuration Of Blocks: The shape of blocks shall be determined by topographical features, the basic street system and traffic pattern, lot depths, and
areas designated for public and other nonresidential land uses. In addition to these, the lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with
due regard to:
1. Site Adequacy: Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 347/498
2. Zoning: Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions within the corporate limits of the village.
3. Convenience: Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
B. Length Of Blocks:
1. Residential: In residential subdivisions, the maximum length of blocks containing lots less than one hundred fifty feet (150') in width shall be one
thousand eight hundred (1,800) linear feet, and the maximum length of blocks containing lots one hundred fifty feet (150') and over in width shall be
two thousand (2,000) linear feet. No blocks shall be less than one thousand (1,000) linear feet in length unless recommended by the planning and
zoning board and approved by the board of trustees.
2. Nonresidential: In manufacturing and business subdivisions, maximum length of blocks shall be as recommended by the planning and zoning board
and approved by the board of trustees. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
C. Nonresidential Blocks: Blocks or portions thereof intended for commercial or industrial use shall be designated as such, and the plan shall show
adequate off street areas to provide for parking, loading docks, and other such facilities. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-4-5: LOTS:
A. Configuration Of Lots: The lot size, width, depth, shape and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of
development and use contemplated and, in general, lots should be as nearly rectangular in shape as practicable. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
1. Conformance With Zoning Regulations: Width and areas of lots shall conform with lot width and area requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance
of the village (title 11 of this code) or that of Cook County in the unincorporated areas beyond the village limits. Corner lots shall be increased in
width by twenty percent (20%) over the width of typical interior lots, except that corner lots need not exceed ninety feet (90') in width if the ninety feet
(90') in width is greater than the width of the typical lot; except the board of trustees may require, when recommended by the planning and zoning
board, a greater lot width to provide for the proper development of intersection design and traffic safety.
2. Nonresidential Lots: Width, area and depth of lots in a commercial or industrial subdivision shall be as recommended by the planning and zoning
board and approved by the board of trustees. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
3. Side Lot Lines: Side lot lines of lots shall be at right angles or radial to the street line, or substantially so.
B. Access To Lots: Each lot within the subdivision must have access to a public or private street unless otherwise provided by local ordinance.
C. Separation From Major Streets: Through lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of residential development from major
streets or highways or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. A planting screen easement, a minimum of twenty feet (20')
in depth and across which there shall be no right of vehicular access, shall be provided along the rear lot lines of lots abutting such highways and major
thoroughfares. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
D. Through Lots: Through lots are not permitted, except where lots back upon a major street, upon a body of water in separate or undivided ownership, or
in manufacturing and business subdivisions when specifically recommended by the planning and zoning board and approved by the board of trustees.
E. Lots Abutting A Watercourse: Lots abutting upon a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall have an additional depth or width as
recommended by the planning and zoning board and approved by the board of trustees in order to provide acceptable building sites.
F. Preservation Of Natural Features: In the subdividing of any land, due regard shall be given to the preservation of natural features, such as trees,
watercourses, historical landmarks, and similar community assets which, if preserved, would add to the attractiveness and value of the subdivision,
neighborhood or the community as a whole. The planning and zoning board shall include in its report its conclusions as to compliance herewith. (Ord.
2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
10-4-6: BUILDING SETBACK LINES:
Building setback lines in all new subdivisions shall conform to the provisions of the Streamwood zoning ordinance (title 11 of this code). (Ord. 2010-27, 12-
2-2010)
10-4-7: PARKS, SCHOOL SITES AND PUBLIC AREAS:
Whenever required by this title or any other ordinance of the village, parks, school sites and/or other public areas shall be shown on all plans and plats and
shall be of such configuration as to be acceptable to the planning and zoning board, village board, and concerned public agency. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-
2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)

Chapter 5
REQUIRED UNDERGROUND IMPROVEMENTS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 351/498
10-5-1: SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
A. Sewer Service Required: Public or community sanitary sewer systems, including sewer stub terminals at the outside of curb line or edge of pavement
for each lot, shall be installed to serve all lots in a subdivision or lot divisions. Subdivisions or lot divisions containing no lots less than one acre or more
in area and located in the unincorporated areas within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the village or subdivisions or lot divisions
containing no lots less than one acre in areas which are annexed to the village after the effective date hereof, may be served with individual sewage
disposal systems; provided, in either case, there is conformance with standards approved by the Cook County health department and other applicable
governmental authorities, except that individual sewerage disposal systems shall be permitted in such subdivisions annexed to the village after the
effective date hereof only after the board of trustees shall find that connection with a public or community system is not practicable, or there is an
agreement between the subdivider and the village and to guarantee by the subdivider that all lots in the subdivision will be served with a public or
community sewerage system within a specified period of time.
B. Approval For Construction: All sanitary sewer systems shall be constructed in accordance with standards approved by the environmental protection
agency of the state of Illinois, the metropolitan water reclamation district of Chicago, and the village, or such other utility corporation, public or private,
whose service may be required. All sewer design plans, and specifications shall be submitted to the above agencies for approval and file.
C. Larger Capacity Sometimes Required: Where sanitary sewer mains of larger capacity than necessary are required, as directed by the board of trustees
to serve the subdivision as delineated in the preliminary plan, the subdivider shall be required to pay for the proportionate benefit of the installation to
his subdivision, as established by the board of trustees.
D. Sewer Pipe Specifications: Public sanitary sewers shall have a minimum internal diameter of eight inches (8"). Sanitary sewers with internal diameters
between eight inches (8") and fifteen inches (15") shall be constructed of PVC SDR 26 in accordance with ASTM D3033, D3034 and D3212. Sanitary
sewers with internal diameters over fifteen inches (15") shall be constructed of reinforced concrete pipe or ductile iron pipe. All sanitary sewers more
than seventeen feet (17') deep shall be class 52 ductile iron pipe with restrained joints and an interior sanitary lining as designed specifically for the
protection of sanitary sewer as approved by the village engineer in polyethylene encasement. The sewer service from a ductile iron main shall be
ductile iron.
E. Sewer Joint Specifications: Joints for sanitary sewer pipe shall be in conformance with the specifications for the appropriate type of pipe used, or
approved by the village engineer.
F. Miscellaneous Specifications:
1. Wye Connections: All connections to sewer mains shall be with a wye. A wye shall be installed in the sewer main at each lot. Vertical risers are
prohibited. No riser shall be at an angle greater than forty five degrees (45°) to horizontal.
2. Self-Cleansing: Sanitary sewers shall be self-cleansing with a minimum flow of two and one-half feet (21/2') per second. Minimum slopes for sanitary
sewers shall be:
8 inches 0.40 percent
10 inches 0.28 percent
12 inches 0.22 percent
15 inches 0.15 percent
3. Depth Of Sewer: The depth from the finished grade to the top of a sanitary sewer shall not be less than five feet (5').
4. Overexcavated Trenches: All sewer trenches shall be overexcavated by four inches (4") and backfilled with CA-11 or CA-13 bedding material. Pipe
shall have four inch (4") bedding or one-fourth (1/4) of the pipe diameter bedding and granular backfill to the centerline of the pipe. Material shall be
CA-11 or CA-13. The pipe shall be backfilled from the centerline to six inches (6") above the top of the pipe with CA-11 or CA-13 or compacted select
material passing a one inch (1") sieve. From six inches (6") above the pipe to the subgrade the pipe shall be backfilled in accordance with IDOT
section 550.07.
5. Granular Trench Backfill: Granular trench backfill is required anytime any portion of the trench falls within two feet (2') or is under the curb,
driveways, sidewalk or pavement. All trenches, regardless of location, must be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of modified proctor and all
granular trench backfill must be compacted according to SSRB 550.07. All compacted trenches must have compaction tests taken on every lift. All
granular trench backfill shall be CA-6 grade 8 or grade 9. No recycled trench backfill is allowed.
6. Location Of Sewer: All underground improvements shall be installed outside the pavement wherever possible.
7. Sanitary Sewers Under Creeks: When a sanitary sewer shall cross a creek, it shall be a minimum of two feet (2') below the creek bed. Pipe shall be
class 54 ductile iron and shall be installed with a steel casing pipe.
8. Installation: All noncurvilinear sanitary sewers shall be installed using a laser.
G. Standards For Construction: All sanitary sewers shall be constructed in accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer
Construction" in Illinois and the requirements of the MWRDGC.
H. House Connections: All house sewer connections to the main sewer shall be inspected and approved by the village engineer. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-
2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 352/498
10-5-2: STORMWATER DRAINAGE SYSTEM:
A. Stormwater Drainage System Required: An adequate system of stormwater drainage shall be constructed and installed, consisting of natural
watercourses, storm sewers and other necessary facilities which will drain the subdivision and protect roadway pavements. Open ditches shall be
prohibited.
B. Design Requirements:
1. Storm Drainage Computations: The design engineer shall submit to the village one copy of the storm drainage computations. The storm sewer
system shall be designed based on a ten (10) year storm with an intensity based on the time of concentration. The coefficient of runoff shall be an
approved composite established for each project. Rainfall shall be as determined in subsection 10-6-12C of this title.
2. Downstream Capacity Of Existing System: The design engineer shall indicate in his drainage computations any cases where the downstream
capacity of the sewer system is inadequate and the proposed sewers will not handle the runoff, or where the topography of the ground is such that
flooding can be expected more often than the period for which the system is designed.
3. Construction Of Detention Ponds: See section 10-6-12 of this title.
C. Sewer Pipe And Joint Specifications: Storm sewers shall be constructed of reinforced concrete pipe conforming to the American Society For Testing
And Materials designation, C-76, wall thickness B.
Other materials of storm sewer construction may be used in special cases upon the approval of the director of public works. Existing drain tiles shall be
connected to storm sewers or shall be restored to operating condition. Joints shall meet the requirements of the Illinois "Standard Specifications For
Road And Bridge Construction". Storm sewers shall be a minimum of twelve inches (12") in diameter.
Under design flow, the minimum velocity shall not be less than three feet (3') per second.
D. Miscellaneous Specifications:
1. Minimum Cover: Minimum cover on storm sewers shall be a minimum of one and one-half feet (11/2') measured from top of pipe to the pavement
subgrade or finished grade in grassed areas.
2. Inlets: Storm draining inlets shall be placed in rear yards and street gutters at intersections and elsewhere as required by the terrain, but shall not be
spaced more than five hundred feet (500') apart or from the high point. At all low points and on all slopes exceeding two percent (2%), double inlets
shall be installed. All inlets shall have directional lids.
Continuous six inch (6") drain tile shall be installed in all rear yards and connected to rear yard inlets. Drain tiles must be installed in all cases
including horseshoe type lot drainage. Drain tiles shall be installed in pea gravel or washed river gravel. The entire trench must be lined with an
approved geotextile fabric. No direct connections to concrete storm sewer pipe are allowed.
All sump pump discharge lines shall be connected with an air gap to the rear yard drain tile.
3. Outfalls: Any outfall storm sewer that drains into an existing open ditch or natural watercourse shall have a reinforced concrete headwall or a
reinforced concrete flared end section with trash rack in accordance with IDOT standards. All such outfalls shall be provided with energy dissipation
devices with fabric, in accordance with the "Standards For Soil Erosion Control" (the Green Book). All outfalls shall be supported by the placement of
concrete or creosoted timber piles approximately ten feet (10') long.
4. Granular Trench Backfill: Granular trench backfill is required anytime any portion of the trench falls within two feet (2') or is under the curb,
driveways, sidewalk or pavement. All trenches, regardless of location, must be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of modified proctor and all
granular trench backfill must be jetted. All compacted trenches must have compaction tests taken on every lift. All granular trench backfill shall be
CA-11 or CA-13. Storm sewer pipe shall have four inches (4") of granular bedding and granular backfill to the centerline of the pipe. From the
centerline to the subgrade the pipe shall be backfilled in accordance with IDOT standard specifications.
E. Separation Required: Stormwater shall not be directed into the sanitary sewer system and no connections between the storm and sanitary sewer
systems will be permitted at any time before, during or after construction.
F. Larger Capacity Sometimes Required: Where storm sewer mains of larger capacity than necessary are required, as directed by the board of trustees to
serve the subdivision as delineated in the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall be required to pay for the proportionate benefit of the installation to his
subdivision, as established by the board of trustees.
G. Surface Water Runoff:
1. Review Of Engineering Plans: Plans and specifications for all channels shall be included in the documentation required in section 10-3-4 of this title.
2. Effect On Downstream Land: Due cognizance shall be taken to the effect of development of any land tract downstream and surrounding land
affected by rainfall and surface water runoff.
H. Standards For Construction: Installation of stormwater drainage facilities shall meet the requirements of the state of Illinois "Standard Specifications For
Road And Bridge Construction". In cases where this title conflicts with the requirements of these specifications, the provisions of this title shall govern.
I. Report And Video Required: Immediately prior to final acceptance, the developer, in the presence of the village representative, shall color televise and
record the storm sewer system and provide the village with a written report and a copy of the recording in a digital format acceptable to the village
engineer. All defects shall be repaired prior to final acceptance. The sump pump connections and yard drain tiles are considered part of the storm
sewer system and must be televised.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 353/498
J. Testing And Approval: All testing shall be made or caused to be made by the contractor or owner at no cost to the village and in the presence of the
village representative. Testing shall be of the low pressure air testing method for sanitary sewers as approved by the metropolitan water reclamation
district of Greater Chicago and the village. Immediately prior to final acceptance, the developer in the presence of the village representative, shall color
televise and record the sanitary sewer system in a digital format acceptable to the village engineer. All defects shall be repaired prior to final
acceptance. Sanitary sewer house services shall be televised.
K. Waterway Opening: All streets which cross Poplar Creek, or any open tributary, or creek shall have a waterway opening sized in accordance with the
requirement of and approved by IDOT DWR, the crossing shall be reinforced concrete box culvert with a minimum opening of one hundred twenty
(120) square feet. All box culverts whether cast in place or precast shall: have epoxy coated reinforcing bars; have cast in place head walls and wing
walls; have a cast in place antiseep collar. This structure shall be designed by an Illinois registered structural engineer. The crossing shall be protected
by a steel plate guardrail. A streetlight shall be installed at the crossing. The slope from the street ROW line to the top of the head wall shall be flatter
than four to one (4:1). (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-3: MANHOLES AND DRAINAGE APPURTENANCES:
Manholes and drainage appurtenances, as outlined below, shall be constructed in accordance with the requirements of the village standard detail sheets.
A. Manholes:
1. Manhole Size And Construction: Manholes for sewers thirty six inches (36") and smaller shall have an inside diameter of forty eight inches (48") and
a six inch (6") thick precast concrete base, in one piece, bedded in at least four inches (4") of CA-11 or CA-13. The sidewalls shall be of precast
concrete ring construction which shall have a five inch (5") minimum thickness. Manhole bases for sewers with an internal diameter forty two inches
(42") and larger shall be constructed of reinforced concrete.
2. Manhole Spacing: Manhole spacing shall be three hundred fifty feet (350') maximum. Manholes shall be required whenever the sewer changes
direction.
3. Drop Type Manholes Required: Wherever two (2) sanitary sewer lines connect and there is a difference of vertical elevation of more than two feet
(2'), there shall be constructed a precast, drop type manhole. All drop assemblies shall be ductile iron and the first pipe out of the drop shall be
ductile iron. All backfill around drop manholes shall be trench backfill up to the bottom of the inlet pipe.
4. Rubber Boots: Pipe connections to sanitary sewer manholes shall include rubber boot. Connections to existing sanitary sewer manholes must be
cored and have a boot installed.
5. Gasket Sealed Covers: Sanitary sewer manholes shall have Neenah self-seal gasketed covers or approved equal.
6. Seal Required: The adjusting rings and manhole sections of sanitary sewer manholes must be sealed with an approved mastic material and chimney
seals.
B. Catch Basins:
1. Catch Basin Size And Construction: Catch basins shall be IDOT type A or type C.
2. Curb Inlets: Curb inlets shall have an internal diameter of two feet (2') and a minimum depth of two feet (2'). Sidewalls shall be precast concrete
having a thickness of four inches (4"), bedded in a minimum of two inches (2") of CA-11 or CA-13. Inlets shall be IDOT type A.
3. Catch Basin Location: Catch basins shall be placed in street gutters at intersections and elsewhere as required by tile terrain. Manholes, inlets and
catch basins shall be located so that the length of over the surface drainage, either along a street or through the rear lot areas, will not exceed five
hundred feet (500').
4. Bedding Catch Basins: All catch basins or inlets shall be bedded in a minimum of four inches (4") crushed stone.
C. Frames And Grates: Frames and grates for manholes, catch basins, inlets and valve vaults shall be in accordance with the IDOT standard type I or type
II depending upon the type of curb used.
D. Standards For Construction: Installation of all manholes, catch basins or other drainage appurtenances shall meet the requirements of the state of
Illinois "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". In cases where this title conflicts with these standards, the provisions of this title
shall govern. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-4: WATER SUPPLY AND DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM:
The water supply and distribution system shall be constructed in accordance with the village standard detail sheets.
A. Water Supply And Distribution System Required: Public or community water supply and distribution systems, including water stub terminals to each lot
shall be installed to serve each lot in a subdivision or lot divisions. Subdivisions containing no lots less than one acre or more in area and located in the
unincorporated areas within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits of the village; or subdivisions containing no lots less than one acre in
area and which are annexed to the village after the effective date hereof, may be served with water supply from individual wells conforming with
standards approved by Cook County health department and other applicable governmental authorities, except individual wells shall be permitted in
such subdivisions located within the village only after being specifically approved by the board of trustees when it is determined that connection with a
public or community water supply system is not practicable; or there is an agreement between the subdivider and the village and a guarantee by the
subdivider that all lots in the subdivision will be served with a public or community water supply system within a specified period of time. Evidence shall
be presented by the subdivider that an adequate water supply is available or will be in advance of occupancy for development of individual lots and that
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 354/498
the local utilities can satisfactorily serve the area by the utility easements shown. No physical connection shall be permitted between the village water
system and/or supply and any other system and/or supply not of equal or better bacteriological and chemical quality as determined by inspections and
analysis by the village. Said connection must be approved by the village board.
B. Approval For Construction: All water distribution systems constructed to or within a subdivision shall be constructed in accordance with standards
approved by the state of Illinois environmental protection agency, and the village public works department. All distribution system plans and
specifications shall be submitted to the above agencies for approval and file.
C. Larger Capacity Sometimes Required: The subdivider shall install the water main in the size required by the village to provide for future growth. No
recapture agreements for water main construction will be allowed.
D. Water Main And Joint Specifications: Water mains shall be a minimum of eight inches (8") internal diameter. However, water main loops in cul-de-sacs
may be six inches (6") internal diameter provided there is not more than one fire hydrant on the line. Water mains shall be constructed of either ductile
iron mechanical joint or double sealing single gasket joint pipe, class 52, conforming to American Standards Association specifications A21.6, or A21.8,
with A21.10 mechanical joint fittings or push on type joints. All fire hydrants, valves and bends or other fittings must be secured with the use of a
restrained joint, "mega lug" or approved equal. In some cases the village engineer may require stainless threaded rods and concrete thrust blocks.
E. Valve Specifications: Valves shall be nonrising stem gate valves with operating nut, designed to take full pressure on either face, furnished in full
compliance with American Water Works Association standards C-500. All valves shall open by turning to the left. Valves shall operate at a working
pressure of one hundred fifty (150) pounds per square inch and a test pressure of three hundred (300) pounds per square inch. Valves eight inches (8")
and smaller shall be housed in valve vaults with an internal diameter of forty eight inches (48"); valves over eight inches (8") shall be housed in vaults
with an internal diameter of sixty inches (60"). Valve vault, sidewall and base construction shall conform to that required for catch basins. Precast
concrete vaults shall be constructed around all line valves. Valve vaults are not needed for hydrant valves.
F. Hydrant Requirements And Specifications:
1. Hydrant Requirements: Fire hydrants shall be installed at all street intersections and, at the termination points of all cul-de-sacs, and at the end of all
mains before the water line is put into service. Intermediate hydrants shall be installed so that the spacing between hydrants shall not exceed four
hundred feet (400') in single-family residential areas, or three hundred feet (300') in multiple-family, commercial or industrial areas. The village board
may require spacing of intermediate hydrants at closer intervals in special situations where recommended by the fire chief of the village. No more
than one fire hydrant shall be allowed on a six inch (6") water main.
When a water main shall cross the creek, a valve and vault shall be placed on the line on each side of the creek not more than two hundred feet
(200') from the center of the creek. The pipe shall be ductile iron class 54 and have a minimum of three feet (3') bury under the creek bed. All water
mains under a creek crossing shall be in a steel casing.
2. Hydrant Specifications:
a. Hydrant Standards: Hydrants shall be of the compression or gate type conforming to American Water Works Association standard C-502 and shall
be of a make that has been adopted by the village as standard. Hydrants shall be designed for a three hundred (300) pound test pressure and a
one hundred fifty (150) pound working pressure. Threads on nozzles and caps, and operating nuts, shall be national standard threads. Hydrants
shall open by turning to the left and shall be so marked. Hydrants shall be the "breakaway" base model. Fire hydrants shall be manufactured by
the East Jordon Iron Works, the Traverse City Iron Works or the Muller Company.
b. Nozzle Requirements: Hydrants shall be furnished with two (2) 21/2-inch hose nozzles and one 41/2-inch steamer nozzle.
c. Thrust Block Required: In accordance with the village standard detail sheets.
d. Painting: Hydrants shall be painted to conform to village standards.
e. Elevation: The center of the hydrant steamer nozzle shall be not less than eighteen inches (18") nor more than twenty eight inches (28") above
finished grade. There shall not be any plantings and/or other obstructions within this area, or the area between the steamer nozzle and the curb
line.
G. Miscellaneous Specifications:
1. Depth Of Main: Water main shall be installed at a depth of not less than five feet (5') nor more than nine feet (9') below finished grade.
2. Special Valves Required: Antisiphoning and/or check valves shall be installed between commercial, industrial and residential land uses for the
purposes of conservation and relief of demands on existing residential supply.
3. Water Reclamation: Consideration shall be given to water reclamation and reuse in commercial and industrial tracts for the purpose of conservation
and relief of demands on existing residential supply.
4. Connections: Connections to the existing water system shall be made by pressure tap where required by the village board.
5. Corrosion Protection: Prior to the installation of any water main, a corrosion protection investigation shall be conducted by the Ductile Iron Pipe
Research Association. The application for the investigation shall be made by the developer. The developer shall install all corrosion protection
devices called for by the investigation. If no report is provided the water main shall be protected by polyethylene encasement.
6. Bedding And Backfill: Water main pipe shall have four inches (4") of granular bedding and granular backfill to the centerline of the pipe. Bedding
material shall be CA-11 or CA-13. From the centerline of the pipe to the subgrade, backfilling shall be in accordance with the "Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Construction" in Illinois. Granular trench backfill is required anytime any portion of the trench falls within two feet
(2') of, or is under the curb, driveway, sidewalk or pavement. All trenches, regardless of location, must be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of
modified proctor and all granular trench backfill must be jetted. All compacted trenches must have compaction tests taken on every lift. All granular
trench backfill shall be CA-11 or CA-13.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 355/498
H. Disinfection: Disinfecting of all newly constructed water supply, treatment and distribution facilities shall be performed in accordance with the
requirements of the American Water Works Association standard C-601 with the following modifications:
Revise section 12 of the standard to read "...at least 25 ppm after 24 hours standing..." in lieu of 10 ppm. This may be expected with an application of
40-50 ppm in lieu of 25 ppm as stated.
Revise section 14 to read "...and should produce no less than 25 ppm..." in lieu of 10 ppm.
I. Standards For Construction: Installation of all water mains, valves and hydrants shall be in accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And
Sewer Construction" in Illinois. In cases where this title conflicts with these requirements the provisions of this title shall govern.
J. Leakage Testing: All water mains and building services four inches (4") in diameter and larger shall be tested for leakage at a minimum of one hundred
fifty (150) psi for a minimum of one hour. The allowable leakage shall be as shown in the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Construction"
in Illinois, latest edition.
K. Fire Sprinkler Services: Automatic sprinkler service lines from the water main to any building shall meet the following specifications:
1. The system shall have an independent water supply (not for domestic use).
2. A valve vault shall be installed at the source of the tap.
3. Underground supply mains shall be ductile iron pipe class 52 or type K copper, when approved by the village engineer.
4. The service shall be constructed in accordance with the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Construction" in the state of Illinois.
5. Testing shall be the same as for water mains.
6. Disinfections and sampling shall be the same as for water mains.
7. All testing, disinfection and sampling shall be done in the presence of an inspector and/or certified water plant operator of the public works
department. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-5: BUILDING SERVICES FOR UNDERGROUND UTILITIES:
A. Building Services Required: Individual building services for sewer and water shall be constructed to connect each lot, dwelling unit or building site with
the utility service mains for each utility required in the provisions of this title as follows:
1. Length Of Building Service: Building services shall extend from the main to the property line.
2. Boxes: All service boxes and buffalo boxes shall be located in the parkway or easements. B-boxes shall be cast iron extension type with one and
one-half inch (11/2") Minneapolis pattern base, or two and one-half inch (21/2") Tyler cast iron #95E curb box.
3. Marking: At the end of all building services, a two by four (2 x 4) plank, six feet (6') in length, shall be driven into the ground to a depth of four feet (4')
to be used as a temporary marker.
4. Construction: Building services shall be one continuous piece of copper from the water main to the B-box, and one continuous piece of copper from
the B-box to the meter whenever possible. Any building services that are not capable of being laid in one piece shall have a mechanical coupling of a
type that shall be approved by the community development department. All services which require a coupling shall be tested for leakage. Testing
shall be at a minimum of one hundred (100) psi. All service testing shall be approved by the community development department.
5. Water Service Testing: All building services four inches (4") and larger shall meet the same requirements as set forth under water main leakage
testing and disinfection.
6. Water Service Testing: All building services smaller than four inches (4") may be required to be tested for leakage and disinfection at the discretion of
the official custodian of the community water supply.
B. Specifications For Building Water Services: Building water service for each single-family residence shall be minimum one inch (1") type K copper or
approved equal and shall be terminated at a shutoff valve and box of a type approved by the village engineer and located within the parkway. In no
case shall the buffalo box be located in the sidewalk or driveway or buried underground.
C. Specifications For Building Sanitary Services: The connection from the sewer to the sanitary building drain shall be six inch (6") PVC or ductile iron, set
at a minimum grade of one-fourth inch (1/4") per foot installed in accordance with the ASTM and the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer
Construction" in Illinois. Such service shall connect to the sewer with a wye. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-6: DRAINAGE PIPE INSTALLATIONS:
The village board may require a subdivider to install drainage pipe around any buildings constructed. Such pipe shall be perforated pipe encased in filter
fabric. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-7: DRY UTILITY DISTRIBUTION LINES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 356/498
A. All Dry Utilities To Be Underground: All dry utility distribution lines for telephone, cable TV, street lighting, electric and gas service in the subdivision shall
be placed underground entirely throughout a subdivided area. Installation of such facilities shall be made in compliance with the applicable orders,
rules and regulations of the Illinois commerce commission now or hereafter effective and the subdivider shall be responsible for compliance with rules
and regulations, now or hereafter effective and filed with said commission pursuant to the Illinois public utilities act, or any public utility whose service
will be required for the subdivision with respect to the provisions of such facilities.
B. Location And Specifications Of Dry Utilities: Underground telephone, electric and gas service shall be placed within easements or dedicated public
ways in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located so as not to be unsightly or
hazardous to the public. The utility lines shall be parallel to and not less than twelve inches (12") from the property lines. corner markers as required in
this title shall not be disturbed by the installation of utility lines. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-5-8: INSPECTION OF UNDERGROUND IMPROVEMENTS:
A. Inspection Required: All water, sewer, stormwater, streetlights, or other underground improvements as required by this title, shall be inspected during
the course of construction and upon completion by the village engineer.
B. Notification Required: During the course of construction of the improvements, the subdivider shall notify the village forty eight (48) hours before any
required inspection.
C. Approval Before Backfilling: No backfilling of utility trenches shall be made until all required inspections are completed. Any backfilling done in conflict
with this title shall be removed at the subdivider's expense.
D. Inspection Fees: All developments shall pay to the village the sum of two and one-half percent (21/2%) of the estimated cost of the improvement for the
purpose of providing engineering inspections. This fee is to be based on the total required guarantee amount as calculated by subsection 10-3-6A of
this title.
E. As Built Plan Required: No final inspection shall commence until the developer furnishes the village with an as built plan of the underground
improvement. Said as built plan shall show the exact location of all storm sewer, sanitary sewer, and water mains together with all manholes and
valves, and their rim and invert elevations.
All building services shall be shown with their location being shown by distances in feet from numbered manhole locations.
Said as built plans shall also contain all storm and sanitary sewer rim and invert elevations, the grades of the stormwater overland flood route and shall
be signed and sealed by a registered Illinois professional engineer.
After inspection of the improvements, but before final inspection and final approval, the developer shall supply the village with four (4) copies, plus one
reproducible copy on mylar, of the as built plan of the underground improvements, and a digital copy in a format approved by the village engineer.
All as built plans shall be approved by the village engineer. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
Chapter 6
REQUIRED SURFACE IMPROVEMENTS
10-6-1: EROSION, SEDIMENTATION AND DUST CONTROL; SITE DEVELOPMENT PERMIT:
10-6-1-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the following sections is to provide minimum standards to safeguard persons and to protect property and the environment by regulating the
design, construction and maintenance of any development or other activity which results in the movement of earth or land situated in the village. (Ord.
2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-1-2: GENERAL CRITERIA AND STANDARDS:
The following general principles shall apply to any movement of earth and any sedimentation and control plan:
A. The smallest practical area of land as determined by the village engineer shall be exposed at any given time during development.
B. Such minimum area exposure shall be kept to as short a duration of time as is practical as determined by the village engineer.
C. Sediment basins, debris basins, desilting basins or silt traps shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters from land
undergoing development.
D. Provision shall be made to effectively accommodate the increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 357/498
E. Permanent, final plant covering or structures shall be installed as soon as possible.
F. The plan shall relate to the topography and soils of the site so that the lowest potential for erosion is created.
G. Natural plant covering shall be retained and protected so far as is consistent with developing the site.
H. No site development permit shall be issued unless application is made for a development on the site.
I. All unsuitable, contaminated, or nonbuildable soils within building sites shall be removed and replaced under the supervision of a registered professional
engineer.
J. No work of any kind is permitted on any U.S. army corps of engineers designated wetland without a permit from the corps and from the village. (Ord.
2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-1-3: ENGINEERING REQUIREMENTS AND PERMITS:
A. Permit Required: Before land is cleared, graded, transported or otherwise disturbed by the movement of earth for construction projects within the
village, a site development permit embodying the proposed earth movement shall be obtained from the village engineer.
B. Application: No site development permit shall be issued until said developer submits a site development plan, together with any other submissions
required by this title, and certifies that any movement of earth shall be in accordance with such plan and submissions.
1. Each application shall contain an estimated time schedule and phasing of the land movement, which shall contain schedules for stripping and/or
clearing, rough grading and construction, final grading and vegetation establishment and maintenance.
The proposed phasing of development of the site, including stripping and clearing, rough grading and construction, and final grading and
landscaping. Phasing should identify the expected date on which clearing will begin, the estimated duration of exposure of cleared areas, and the
sequence of installation of temporary sediment control measures (including perimeter controls), clearing and grading, installation of temporary soil
stabilization measures, installation of storm drainage, paving streets and parking areas, final grading and the establishment of permanent vegetative
cover, and the removal of temporary measures. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to notify the village of any significant changes which
occur in the site development schedule after the initial erosion and sediment control plan has been approved.
These submissions shall be prepared in accordance with the requirements of this title and the standards and requirements contained in the latest
edition and updates of the "Illinois Urban Manual", which was originally prepared by the environmental protection agency, and the "Illinois Procedures
And Standards For Urban Soil Erosion And Sedimentation Control" (the Green Book), which was prepared by the Northeastern Illinois soil erosion
and sedimentation control steering committee and adopted by the North Cook County soil and water conservation district, which standards and
requirements are hereby incorporated into this title by reference.
The village may waive specific requirements for the content of submissions upon finding that the information submitted is sufficient to show that the
work will comply with the objectives and principles of this title.
A development plan of the site showing:
a. Existing topography of the site and adjacent land within approximately one hundred feet (100') of the boundaries, drawn at no greater than two
foot (2') contour intervals and clearly portraying the conformation and drainage pattern of the area.
b. The locations of existing buildings, structures, utilities, streams, lakes, floodplains, wetlands and depressions, drainage facilities, vegetation cover,
paved areas, and other significant natural or manmade features on the site and adjacent land within one hundred feet (100') of the boundary.
c. A general description of the predominant soil types on the site, their locations, and their limitations for the proposed use.
d. Proposed use of the site, including present development and planned utilization; areas of clearing, stripping, grading, excavation, and filling;
proposed contours, finished grades, and street profiles; provisions for storm drainage, including storm sewers, swales, detention basins and any
other measures to control the rate of runoff, with a drainage area map, indications of flow directions, and computations; kinds and locations of
utilities; and areas and acreages proposed to be paved, covered, sodded or seeded, vegetatively stabilized, or let undisturbed.
2. An erosion and sediment control plan showing all measures necessary to meet the objectives of this title throughout all phases of construction and
permanently after completion of development of the site including:
a. Locations and description, including standard details, of all sediment control measures and design specifics of sediment basins and traps,
including outlet details.
b. Location and description of all soil stabilization and erosion control measures, including seeding mixtures and rates, type of sod, method of
seedbed preparation, expected seeding dates, type and rate of lime and fertilizer application, kind and quantity of mulching for both temporary and
permanent vegetative control measures, and type of nonvegetative stabilization measures.
c. Location and description of all runoff control measures, including diversions, waterways, and outlets.
d. Location and description of methods to prevent tracking of sediment off site, including construction entrance details, as appropriate.
e. Description of dust and traffic control measures.
f. Locations of stockpiles and description of stabilization methods.
g. Description of off site fill or borrow volumes, locations, and methods of stabilization.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 358/498
h. Provisions for maintenance of control measures, including type and frequency of maintenance, easements, and estimates of the cost of
maintenance.
i. Identification (name, address, and telephone) of the person(s) or entity which will have legal responsibility for maintenance of erosion control
structures and measures during and after development is completed.
j. The starting date.
k. Duration of exposure of affected areas.
l. Installation of storm drainage by phase and date.
m. Plan for establishing permanent vegetative cover including the seeding mixes and rates, type of seed, seedbed preparation, seeding dates, time
and fertilizer application, temporary seeding and mulching or similar stabilization procedures to be applied immediately after final grading has been
completed.
3. No site development permit shall be issued for the sole purpose of removal of the existing trees, or other vegetation cover.
C. Dust Control: The developer shall have a water wagon or other acceptable device on, or available to, the project site in order to control dust.
D. Guarantee Amount: A guarantee in the amount of one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the total cost of the earth movement and one hundred
twenty five percent (125%) of the cost of the soil erosion control measures shall be filed with the village before a permit is issued.
E. Inspection: The village engineer or designee shall make inspections as herein required and shall either approve that portion of the work completed or
shall notify the permittee of the failure to comply with the plan. Where it is found by inspection that conditions are not substantially as stated or shown in
said plan, the village engineer may stop further work until approval is obtained for a revised grading plan conforming to the existing conditions. Plans
for the grading work, approved by the village engineer, shall be maintained at the site during progress of the work. In order to obtain inspections in
accordance with the following schedule, the permittee shall notify the village engineer at least two (2) working days before the said inspection is to be
made; first, when rough grading has been completed; and second, when all work, including installation of all drainage and other structures and required
planting, has been completed.
F. Responsibility: Failure of the village engineer to observe or recognize hazardous, or unsightly conditions, or to recommend denial of the site
development permit, or the village board to deny said permit shall not relieve the permittee from responsibility for the condition or damage resulting
therefrom and shall not result in the village, its officers or agents being responsible for any condition or damage resulting therefrom.
G. Appeal: Any applicant denied a permit under this section shall have the right to appeal such denial to the village manager and, if further denied, to the
village board. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-1-4: EXPIRATION OF PERMIT:
Every site development permit shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the work authorized by such permit has not been commenced within
one hundred eighty (180) days, or is not completed within one year from date of issue; except that the village may, if the permit holder presents
satisfactory evidence that unusual difficulties have prevented work being started or completed within the specified time limits, grant a reasonable extension
of time if written application is made before the expiration date of the permit. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-2: GRADING AND TRENCH BACKFILLING:
A. Grading And Grading Plans:
1. The grading plan shall indicate existing and proposed grades of the street, curb and gutter, lot and building finished swale. The minimum lot grades
for split drainage are one and one-half percent (11/2%) across rear yard and two percent (2%) in side yards. For horseshoe drainage, the minimum of
one and one-half percent (11/2%) to the high point then up to a minimum of six inches (6") to the finish grade at the building. Top of foundation shall
be six inches (6") above finish grade. Maximum allowable slope in rear yard is three to one (3:1), slope must be within the last five feet (5') of the rear
yard. If a three to one (3:1) slope cannot be maintained within the last five feet (5'), a retaining wall, designed by a registered structural engineer,
must be built within six inches (6") of the lot line. Retaining walls shall not be constructed of railroad ties. All walls with any part above eighteen
inches (18") in height shall be designed and certified by a registered architect or structural engineer. All walls in excess of eighteen inches (18") in
height must have a pressure treated forty two inch (42") high fence or other approved material installed along the top of the wall. Unless approved by
the village engineer all retaining walls shall be constructed of segmented concrete block. All walls shall have an approved drainage system installed
behind them. All retaining walls shall be inspected and approved by a licensed professional engineer provided for and paid for by the developer.
All grading plans shall have a minimum scale of one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50'). A one inch equals twenty feet (1" = 20') plan may be required if
additional detail is necessary.
Prior to issuance of a building permit, a detailed grading plan shall be submitted for each lot for which a permit is applied for. This detailed plan shall
show the proposed foundation, driveway, lot corner and swale grades. All building setback lines shall be shown. No work shall be done until this plat
is reviewed and approved by the village engineer. After completion of the foundation, an as built plat showing location and elevation of the foundation
shall be submitted. No building shall be erected until the as built plat is reviewed and approved by the village engineer.
All plats required by this section shall be signed and sealed by an Illinois registered land surveyor or Illinois registered professional engineer.
2. The roadway area shall be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of modified laboratory density to achieve a firm and unyielding subgrade as
tested with a heavily loaded truck, the subgrade shall be constructed in accordance with the Illinois department of transportation "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction" and for slab or grade the house pad area shall be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 359/498
modified laboratory density. If the subgrade is not firm and unyielding the material shall be removed and replaced with suitable material or the
subgrade stabilized as approved by the village engineer.
B. Granular Trench Backfill: Granular trench backfill is required anytime any portion of the trench falls within two feet (2'), or is under the curb, driveway,
sidewalk or pavement. All trenches, regardless of location, must be compacted to ninety five percent (95%) of modified proctor and all granular trench
backfill must be jetted. All compacted trenches must have compaction tests taken on every lift. All granular trench backfill shall be CA-11 or CA-13.
C. Completion Of Grading And Trench Backfilling: Before any base course of the roadway pavement or any sidewalk is laid, all grading of streets shall be
completed and approved, all of the underground work, such as water, sewer and gas mains, house service connections therewith, and all underground
conduits for electric and telephone lines, shall be completely installed in place and approved; and all backfilling of trenches dug across the roadway or
sidewalkway shall have completely settled to the satisfaction of the village director of public works. Any existing streets shall not be open cut without
written approval by the director of public works.
D. Removal Of Unsuitable Material: All unsuitable material shall be removed from under roads or utility lines. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-3: ROADWAY PAVEMENT:
Residential:
11/2" asphalt hot mix surface, Superpave, N50, mix D, PG 64-28, 4% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
11/2" asphalt hot mix binder, Superpave, N50, IL-25, PG 64-28, 4% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
7" bituminous base, Superpave, N50, IL-25, PG 64-28, 2% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
4" aggregate subbase type B
Commercial and industrial areas, arterial streets, major collector streets:
11/2" asphalt hot mix surface, superpave, N70, mix D, PG 64-28, 4% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
11/2" asphalt hot mix binder, Superpave, N70, IL-25, PG 64-28, 4% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
9" bituminous base, Superpave, N70, IL-25, PG 64-28, 2% voids @ 50 gyr, 0% RAP
4" aggregate subbase type B
Minimum crown on all streets shall be two percent (2%).
All mixes shall have a minimum of fifty percent (50%) manufactured sand, minimum lift thickness shall be three (3) times the largest aggregate size; mixes
containing pea gravel are not allowed, IL-9.5 surface and IL-19.0 are not allowed; no recycled material is allowed.
Thicker cross sections may be required if the traffic count or traffic type or soil conditions warrant additional thickness. The subbase shall comply with the
requirements of granular subbase type B, the material shall be CA-6 or CA-10, and must be a crushed stone or crushed gravel. Pit run gravel, gravel, or
crushed slag is not allowed.
Hot mix asphalt surface course shall not be installed until all other requirements of section 10-3-7 of this title are met.
After completion of the hot mix binder course, the contractor shall provide pavement cores at the frequency and location required by the director of public
works.
The village engineer shall review and approve the mix designs prior to installation. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-4: CURB AND GUTTER:
Concrete combination curbs and gutters shall be constructed on all streets in accordance with the requirements set forth on the village standard detail
sheets as follows:
A. Type Required: Curbs and gutters on all streets in all developments shall be type B6.12. In commercial and residential areas the depressed curb
openings shall be installed at the time the curb is placed. In industrial areas where the driveway locations are not known at the time of curb placement
the driveway openings will be established by a method approved by the director of public works. Saw cutting the back of the curb will not be allowed
unless approved by the director of public works.
B. Driveway Openings: Whenever a driveway or entranceway occurs at a barrier type curb and gutter, said curb shall be depressed to allow for adequate
entrances and exits with the tapering of the curb at a thirty degree (30°) angle.
C. Curb Returns: All curb returns at street intersections shall have a radius of not less than twenty feet (20').
D. Concrete: All concrete shall conform to the requirements of IDOT class SI 6.1 bag mix.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 360/498
E. Curb Thickness: In residential areas, the minimum curb thickness at the street shall be ten inches (10"). In industrial and commercial areas and on
arterial streets the minimum curb thickness at the street shall be twelve inches (12"). Two inches (2") of crushed unrecycled stone is required under all
curbs.
F. Expansion Joints: Expansion joints shall be every forty feet (40') with three inch (3") deep contraction joints every ten feet (10'). Contraction joints can be
either saw cut or tooled. Expansion joints shall be placed five feet (5') from all inlets, and at the PC of all curb returns at street intersections. (Ord.
2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-5: PARKWAYS:
Parkways shall be required on both sides of a street to the sidewalk line. They shall be graded by the subdivider with not less than four inches (4") of
topsoil. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-6: PUBLIC SIDEWALKS:
A. Construction Specifications: All sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with the village standards and approved by the village engineer.
B. Concrete: All concrete shall conform to the requirements of IDOT class SI 6.1 bag mix.
C. Width And Thickness: All sidewalks shall be four feet (4') wide and five inches (5") thick, with two inches (2") of compacted crushed stone under the
walk.
D. Sidewalks In Driveways: Sidewalk in driveways shall be four feet (4') wide and six inches (6") thick with #6 wire mesh and two inches (2") of compacted
crushed stone under the walk. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-7: STREET LIGHTING SYSTEM:
A. Description: Streetlights and appurtenances shall be installed according to the "American Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting", current edition and
the national electrical code, current edition.
The streetlight system consists of the poles, mast arms, luminaries, wire and all other materials and work necessary to complete the street lighting
installation.
Light standards shall be centrecon pole type MEO-/(Brown #513) installed in accordance with the manufacturer's requirements.
B. Design Requirements And Approval: The complete lighting system shall be designed by a registered professional engineer of the state of Illinois and
shall be submitted to the director of public works for approval. In special cases, the director of public works may designate larger lamps, higher poles,
two (2) masted poles, or vary the spacing as he deems necessary to meet special conditions.
C. Material And Workmanship: All materials comprising the lighting systems shall be the product of a firm or firms regularly engaged in the manufacture of
such materials and shall be covered by the manufacturer's or installing contractor's warranty or guaranty. The materials shall be new, of current
manufacture and of standard design free from defects.
Workmanship shall be of the highest grade in accordance with standard practice. All work shall be done in accordance with the national electric code
and local regulations and in case of differing standards, materials and construction shall be in accordance with those standards requiring the highest
grade. Soil shall be hydraulically tamped around the pole.
D. Material And Equipment Specifications:
1. Conduit: All driveways, street and sidewalk crossings shall have a two inch (2") galvanized rigid steel conduit or PVC conduit used as a raceway for
underground cable with two inch (2") insulating fiber bushings.
2. Wire And Cable: All wire installed under this section shall be copper with six hundred (600) volt insulation. Cable shall be of a type approved by the
director of public works for direct burial such as types "USE" and "UF" UL approved for two (2) conductors. All streetlight cables shall be installed in
one and one-fourth inch (11/4") diameter SDR 13.5 HDPE duct. One conductor shall be white to determine neutral. Wire installed in trench shall be
#6 stranded as shown on the plans. Vertical wire in poles shall be #10 stranded R.H. All wire will be subject to an insulation test to ground after
installation. The minimum acceptable resistance to ground will be two hundred fifty thousand (250,000) ohms. Any section of wiring failing to pass
the minimum insulation test will be replaced.
E. Location: A streetlight system shall be installed in all new developments and subdivisions. The locations of streetlights shall be as required by the
director of public works. Lights will be required at all intersections and at the point of curve (PC), point of tangent (PT), and point of intersection (PI) of
all curves. Lights will be required for special locations such as steep grades or creek crossings. A streetlight is required at the end of all cul-de-sac
streets. In no event shall streetlights in residential areas be located more than two hundred feet (200') apart. Lights will be placed in industrial and
commercial areas to provide a continuous level of illumination as recommended by the "American Standard Practice For Roadway Lighting".
F. Cable Location: Trench shall be eighteen inches (18") off the property line. All underground cable shall be continuous.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 361/498
1. Size Of Trench And Backfilling Procedures: This work shall consist of constructing a trench for the accommodation of cable or conduit and backfilling
it at the location shown on the plans, or as directed by the director of public works. The trench shall be excavated at least twenty four inches (24")
below the finished grade. Backfilling material shall be deposited in the trench in layers not to exceed six inches (6") in depth and shall be thoroughly
compacted by suitable tamping before the next layer is deposited in the trench. The trench shall be located two feet (2') back of the curb or as
directed by the director of public works.
G. Splices: Splices shall be made by using 3M scotch cast kits or equal, as approved by the director of public works.
H. Fuses And Fuseholders: Each pole shall be fused with a five (5) amp fuse using a tron in-line waterproof fuseholder (HEB-AA) and protective insulated
rubber boots or equal as approved by the director of public works.
I. Wire Nuts: All wire nuts will be taped.
J. Mast Arm Brackets: Crouse-Hinds (2 inch x 6 inch) rectangular arm OA1062 (10 inch arm).
K. Controls: Individual photoelectric control units shall be provided with each luminaire. Each luminaire shall use a tork photo control model #2007, 105-
277 multi-voltage or equal as approved by the director of public works. Said control shall fit all RCL series standard receptacles and be constructed so
as to prevent false turnoff by passing automobile headlights or lightning flashes.
L. Luminaries: The luminaries for light improvements to be accepted by the village for maintenance shall be manufactured by Crouse-Hinds Company in
the model and style listed below of luminaries equipped with photoelectric control units and one piece reflector housing of anodized aluminum. The
luminaire shall also be equipped with a hinged refractor holder that shall be securely held in place by a suitable latch. The luminaire head shall embody
a two inch (2") slip filter and shall be equipped with adjustable latch lugs to permit the proper orientation of the light pattern on the street; and an EELNEMA
standard, three (3) terminal polarized lock in type, photoelectric control receptacle. In addition, mercury units shall be equipped with built in
ballasts. The luminaries shall provide lighting distribution equivalent to IES type II except at intersections where IES type V or IES type II with four-way
distribution shall be provided.
Electrical luminaries shall be RCL15STN30-120/240 OA1063-4. Required wattage shall be as determined by the director of public works. Lamps shall
be color corrected high pressure sodium.

M. Ballasts: Ballasts shall be of high quality grain oriented strip steel, high power factor, constant wattage and shall have a primary voltage rating of
120/240 volts. They shall be suitable for outdoor service and capable of starting the lamp at minus twenty degrees Fahrenheit (-20°F).
N. Concrete Light Standards: Light standards to be accepted by the village for maintenance shall be centrecon MEO-8 or MEO-10, centrifugally cast,
prestressed and steel reinforced and of breakaway design. The standard shall have smooth ground and polished surfaces. The cross section of the
standard shall contain a raceway extending throughout the length of the standard. The raceway shall have a minimum opening of one and one-half
inches (11/2") and shall not exceed two inches (2") at the top of the standard. A hand hole shall be provided, and shall be covered with a heat treated
cast aluminum door, fastened to nonferrous inserts in the standard with stainless steel bolts. All ornamental poles and fixtures shall be lumec "Transit"
series in textured dark bronze.
O. Ground Rod: The ground rod is to be no more than twelve inches (12") from the pole; five-eighths (5/8) diameter; eight feet (8') long, solid copper rod.
Ground rod should be four inches (4") below grade. The specification should be a ground wire #10 (green) from luminaire to ground rod.
P. Tests: After the installation is complete and at a time convenient to the village, all equipment shall be demonstrated to operate in accordance with the
drawings and specifications.
Q. Warranty: The contractor and his surety shall guaranty and warrant the equipment, material and workmanship, for a period of one year from the date of
final acceptance by the village. Any defective material or workmanship shall be repaired or replaced by said contractor to the satisfaction of the village
without cost to the village. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-8: LANDSCAPING WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY:
A. Grass Seeding Or Sod Required: All unpaved areas within street rights of way shall be sodded with Kentucky bluegrass mixture or with such other
grass mixture as approved by the village board. Before the release of the twelve (12) month maintenance bond can be recommended by the village
engineer, all unpaved areas between the edge of the road pavement and the right of way line must support an adequate mat of grass. Provisions shall
be made to assure the growth of all landscaping. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-9: PRESERVATION PLANTING, MAINTENANCE, REPLACEMENT AND REMOVAL OF TREES:
A. Permit Required: No person shall plant, spray, fertilize, preserve, prune, remove, cut above the ground, or otherwise disturb any tree on private property
or any street on village owned property without a permit from the public works department. All such work shall be done in accordance with this section
and the standards set by the public works department.
Trees which are destroyed by vehicle accident or other means shall be replaced by the person responsible by a tree of like kind and total diameter. The
person causing the damage or destruction of the tree or his insurance so shall reimburse the village for the cost to install the tree or trees necessary to
replace the total diameter of the tree destroyed.
B. Existing Trees In Proposed Developments:
1. A tree location survey, conducted by a licensed Illinois arborist, is required for all areas to be developed. This plan shall be at the same scale as the
plans for the development, but not less than one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50') and is to be submitted as part of the preliminary plan.
The survey shall show all trees six inches (6") in diameter and larger. All trees over twelve inches (12") in diameter must be identified by size and
species. In addition, all key trees; i.e., a tree classified by the arborist as significant, or those trees which are exceptionally good examples of their
species, shall be identified on the tree survey. Each tree surveyed must be identified with a number on the drawing and in the field. These trees must
be preserved as part of the seventy percent (70%) preservation requirement as provided for in subsection F2 of this section.
All proposed rights of way, easements and lots must be shown on the survey.
2. Areas which contain significant trees will be designated as environmentally sensitive areas and will be subject to the requirements of that section.
The village may require modifications of the proposed project in order to preserve the trees. Wherever possible large groups of trees must be left
completely undisturbed.
3. In the event existing trees are destroyed prior to any development plans being approved, the village may require developer or property owner to
replace such trees of like kind and total diameter prior to or subsequent to development.
4. Persons removing vegetation and trees in an ESA will be subject to fines and prosecution.
C. Parkway Trees; Trees Required: Parkway trees shall be planted in the parkway in front of each proposed lot. Existing trees shall be preserved, if
possible, as determined by the village engineer. Trees newly planted shall not be further apart than forty feet (40') with a minimum of one tree per
inside lot and two (2) trees per corner lot. The type of tree shall be limited to those varieties approved by the director of public works.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 363/498
1. Tree Caliper: Newly planted street trees shall be at least two and one-half inches (21/2") in caliper, measured six inches (6") from the ground.
2. Prohibited Trees: The planting of the following varieties of trees within public rights of way shall be prohibited:
Ash (Fraxnius) All varieties
Box elder (Acer negundo) All varieties

Chinese elm (Ulmis parvifulia) All varieties
