Service berry (Amelanchie/grandflora) All varieties
Soft maple (Acer disycarpum) In variety
Tree of heaven (Ailanthus) All varieties
Willow (Salix) All varieties
3. Plant Materials:
a. Source Of Supply:
(1) All plant materials shall conform to the current edition (ANSIZ60.1) of the "American Standard For Nursery Stock" as approved by the American
National Standards Institute, Inc.
(2) Plant materials may be inspected and approved by the director of public works, or his duly authorized representative, at the source of supply
prior to digging. All materials are to be of highest quality. Certification by a landscape architect may be accepted by the director of public works.
(3) All plant materials shall have been grown under climatic conditions similar to those in Chicago, Illinois.
(4) All plants shall be freshly dug. No heeled in plants or plants from cold storage will be accepted. One-sided plants or plants taken from tightly
planted nursery rows will also be rejected. All plants shall be typical of their species or variety and shall be sound, healthy, and vigorous, well
branched and densely foliated when in leaf. They shall be free of disease, insect pests and larvae. They shall have healthy, well developed root
systems. Trees with distorted shapes, large curves in the trunk or other defects will not be allowed.
b. Measurements: Caliber of trees up to four inches (4") shall be taken six inches (6") above the ground level. Trees over four inches (4") shall be
measured one foot (1') above the ground level.
c. Inspection:
(1) Certificates of inspection of plant materials required by the federal, state or other governmental agencies are to accompany all shipments within
the state of Illinois and outside Illinois.
(2) Inspection and approval by the director of public works at the source of supply does not abdicate the right of the director of public works to
reject any material after it has been delivered to the site. Material from nurseries of greater distances than three hundred fifty (350) miles may
not be selected prior to digging and delivery. A final determination of acceptability of the material will be made at the time of delivery.
d. Digging And Handling:
(1) Plant material indicated "B&B" shall be balled and burlapped with firm, natural balls of earth. The balls shall be of sufficient depth and width to
include adequate fibrous and feeding roots to ensure full recovery and development of the plants. No plant dug with a ball shall be accepted if
the ball is broken before or during delivery operations.
(2) Machine dug materials.
(A) Wire baskets used instead of burlap shall be lined with burlap inside the basket. Wire used for baskets shall be of a type which is not
rustproof.
(B) The ball size shall be increased at least two (2) sizes in diameter from those specified in ANSIZ60.1 when using a machine for digging which
digs a tapered ball similar to the Vermeer tree spade.
(3) Trees with broken major branches, or badly bruised or damaged bark are not acceptable.
(4) Roots, balls and crowns, if in leaf, of all plants shall be protected at all times from sun, and/or drying winds prior to and during delivery, and
between the delivery site and planting site.
(5) The contractor is to supply topsoil for backfilling of trees. Topsoil shall be reasonably free of subsoil, quack grass roots, noxious weed seeds,
stones, lumps, plants or their roots, and other extraneous matter. Topsoil shall not be used for planting operations while in a frozen or muddy
condition. All topsoil material shall be approved by the director of public works.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 364/498
(6) All tree pits shall be excavated to the depth below the finished grade required to accommodate a bed of topsoil not less than six inches (6") in
depth beneath the roots. The ball shall rest on this bed when the tree is properly set to a finished grade. All excavated material shall be removed
and legally disposed of from the site. The pits shall be backfilled with topsoil as the trees are set.
(7) The pit shall be excavated a minimum of five feet (5') radius around the tree. The soil within the pit shall be amended with topsoil and peat
moss.
(8) All balled and burlapped plants which cannot be planted immediately upon delivery to the site shall be well protected with soil, wet straw, or
other acceptable materials. All balled and burlapped plants shall be planted at their locations no later than three (3) days after delivery.
(9) Spring planting shall be completed prior to June 1 and fall planting shall not begin before October 1.
(10) All trees shall be mulched, and wrapped with approved material within seven (7) days of planting. All trees shall be braced with steel posts or
approved guys.
(11) All trees shall be watered as necessary to assist in establishment.
D. Screen Planting Required: Protective screen planting may be required to secure a reasonably effective physical barrier between residential properties
and adjoining uses to minimize adverse conditions of sight and sound. The screen planting plan shall be prepared by a landscape architect and shall
meet the approval of the village board.
E. Replacement Of Sick Or Diseased Trees: Any plant which does not survive the guarantee period or is alive but does not represent normal growth
characteristics of health and vigor for the species or variety as determined by the director of public works shall be replaced.
The trees which must be replaced shall be replaced with larger trees. The size of the replacement shall increase in diameter one inch (1") for each
growing season after the initial planting.
F. Environmentally Sensitive Areas: Environmentally sensitive areas (ESA) are those areas which have significant natural features such as large trees or
wetlands. These areas require special care be taken during any development. Wetland mitigation shall be in accordance with chapter 8 of this title.
1. Purpose: It is the standard public policy of the village to maintain, to the greatest extent possible, existing trees within the village.
2. ESAs Established And Defined: ESAs shall be established for all new construction in areas where significant numbers and/or sizes of trees exist.
The ESA is further defined as an area or stand of trees consisting of six (6) or more individual trees having a diameter of ten inches (10") or larger
per acre. The development plan shall include the preservation of a minimum of seventy percent (70%) of the significant trees on the site. Significant
trees are generally hardwoods, such as oak and hickory, but may include other species as determined by the village to be significant.
3. Existing ESAs: Existing ESAs are hereby established and located on the village ESA map. These areas are subject to all the requirements of this
section.
ESA Replacement Credit: The developer of properties where woodlands exist may develop or clear more area than may otherwise be permitted by
this section in accordance with the following table:
Percent Cleared For
Development Zoning District
80% Industrial and commercial
70% Multi-family
55% Single-family
However, where this option is utilized the developer shall comply with the following:
a. The developer shall designate a new woodland area on a part of the site not forested within the corporate limits of the village. A reforestation plan
shall be submitted showing the locations, size and type of all plant materials to be installed. Such material shall be of a suitable type and
compatible with the existing or native vegetation of the site.
b. The new woodland area shall consist of one and two-tenths (1.2) times the surface acreage of the woodland area disturbed pursuant to this
subsection. For purposes of calculation, the area to be mitigated shall be the total acreage of the wooded area less the area preserved and not
disturbed.
c. The number of replacement trees shall be determined by the total diameter of the significant trees removed or destroyed. All replacement trees,
including all off site mitigation trees, shall be guaranteed for two (2) years after final acceptance of the project. The acceptance trees are burr oak,
swamp white oak, red oak, sugar maple, approved hickory and other native trees as approved by the village.
If the development proposes to preserve more than eighty percent (80%) of the significant trees on site, then no replacement will be required.
If the development proposes to preserve more than seventy percent (70%), but less than eighty percent (80%), then one hundred percent (100%) of
the significant trees shall be replaced at 1.0 times their total diameter with trees of the same species ranging in size from one and one-half inch
(11/2") to four inches (4").
If the development proposes to preserve less than sixty percent (60%) of the significant trees then one hundred percent (100%) of the significant
trees removed shall be replaced at 1.5 times their total diameter with trees of the same species ranging in diameter from one and one-half inch
(11/2") to four inches (4").
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 365/498
If the development proposes to preserve less than sixty percent (60%), but more than fifty percent (50%), then one hundred percent (100%) of the
significant trees removed shall be replaced at two (2) times their total diameter with trees of the same species ranging in diameter from one and onehalf
inch (11/2") to four inches (4").
If the development proposes to preserve less than fifty percent (50%) of the significant trees, then one hundred percent (100%) of the significant
trees removed must be replaced at three (3) times their total diameter with trees of the same species ranging in diameter from one and one-half inch
(11/2") to four inches (4").
Any trees removed during construction will be replaced based on the percentage of trees preserved at the start of construction.
4. Building Activity Area: The building activity area shall be the area where building activity may take place and shall be as small as possible.
5. Trees Saved: All trees designated to be saved shall be protected by erecting and maintaining a six foot (6') chainlink fence at or beyond the drip line
of the tree. No construction operations, traffic or grade changes will be allowed within the drip line. In the event that any tree designated to be saved
is damaged, or the area within the drip line is damaged, the developer, as directed by the director of public works, shall immediately repair the
damage in accordance with standard horticultural practice for such work. If replacement of the tree is necessary the developer shall furnish, deliver
and plant a tree of the same species and variety and of the same size or furnish, deliver and plant at the locations designated by the director of
public works a number of trees of the same species and variety having a minimum diameter of two and one-half inches (21/2") planted as indicated
above, whose total size equals the size of the tree to be replaced.
6. Tree Protection: The procedure shall generally be: a lot stakeout plan at a scale of one inch equals twenty feet (1" = 20') shall be prepared and
submitted for approval. The location and grade of the dwelling unit, the actual building shape must be shown, type of foundation (i.e., walkout, slab,
etc.), all trees six inches (6") and larger, all easements, the existing lot contours. This stakeout plan shall be field checked by a village representative
and the project manager.
At the time of this inspection all the building corners shall be staked in the location proposed. The stakes shall include the proposed finished grades.
The village shall have final approval of the location, and grade and foundation details of the structure.
After the stakeout diagram and building locations and grades have been approved, the village and developer shall mark those trees to be removed.
A competent, licensed tree service shall remove only those trees marked for removal.
The building footprint plus a maximum of ten feet (10') shall be fenced as soon as the tree removal is completed. The limits of the fence shall be as
directed by the village. No equipment, material, spoils or construction vehicles are permitted in the tree preservation area. No work may be done on
the lot until the fence is installed. The fence shall remain in place until the building is completed.
The village shall have the authority to stop work on the lot if the fence is not maintained in a manner which protects the trees. If a subcontractor or
material supplier removes the fence at any location on the project three (3) times, then that subcontractor or material supplier will be permanently
removed from the project.
7. Conservation Easements: The village shall designate the limits of a conservation easement on the subject property. This conservation easement
shall prohibit the removal of any vegetation or grading without village approval.
8. Utility Improvements: The village may require utility easement in front yards for Commonwealth Edison, IBT, NIG and cable TV. Water, sewer and
storm sewer lines may be required to be located under the street. The service lines and driveway shall be located within the same corridor into the
lot.
9. Special Landscaping: Special landscaping on the lots and ROW may be required due to the special grading requirements on the lots. The
requirements include: wildflower mixes, ground covers, additional parkway trees of similar species to the existing trees in the ESA, prairie mixes and
other plant materials.
10. Special Grading Requirements: Mass earthmoving operations are prohibited in ESA. Each structure may be required to have a special or custom
foundation to meet the existing grades. All efforts will be made to conform the structure to the existing lot grade.
11. Tree Maintenance: During construction, the developer shall engage a licensed, competent tree expert for tree trimming and special care of trees
impacted by the construction. Tree care shall extend for three (3) years after completion of the work on the lot. The tree expert shall furnish yearly
reports to the village concerning the condition of the trees. In addition, the developer shall provide each initial purchaser of any lot within an ESA
established for trees a detailed explanation for the care and maintenance of those trees. Said explanation shall be reviewed and approved by the
director of public works.
12. Variations From Design Standards: In order to assist in the preservation of trees the village will consider: no sidewalk, reduced ROW width, varying
building setback requirements, and lot grading requirements, bio swales, permeable pavement, and underground stormwater storage.
13. Open Space Requirements: The village will require larger than standard areas to be donated or set aside as open space in the ESA. Whenever
possible, tree conservation areas will be tied into wetland mitigation plans. Access from a village street must be provided to any designated tree
conservation area, and said access shall be at least twenty feet (20') wide where the access abuts the village street.
14. ESA Mitigation: If an ESA must be damaged, removed, or adversely impacted the damaged area shall be mitigated by the construction of an ESA
at generally the rate of one and one-half (11/2) acres for each acre damaged. The actual size required will depend on the damage and the quality of
the damaged tree.
G. Nomenclature: The plants indicated to be provided shall be true to name and the nomenclature shall generally conform with that accepted in the
nursery trade.
H. Substitutions: Substitutions for species will not be permitted. If proof is submitted that any plant specified is not obtainable, a proposal will be considered
for use of nearest equivalent size or variety. Such proof shall be substantiated in writing to the village. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)

10-6-11: MARKERS:
Iron pipe or steel bars not less than one-half inch (1/2") in diameter and twenty four inches (24") long shall be set at the intersection of street centerlines
and at all corners of lots. Markers shall be set level with the finished grade. The subdivider shall replace all or verify the existence of the iron pipes of all lot
corners and all bends in property lines after the completion of all construction and before time of final acceptance of the subdivision by the village board of
trustees. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-12: WATER RETENTION OR DETENTION FACILITIES:
Stormwater storage facilities shall be constructed. Stormwater storage facilities may be either detention or retention ponds. All facilities shall be in
accordance with the following guidelines:
A. Drainage Plan Submitted Requirements: Each applicant shall submit the following information, depending on development size, to ensure that the
provisions of this title are met. The submittal shall include sufficient information to evaluate the environmental characteristics of the property, the
potential adverse impacts of the development on water resources both on site and downstream, and the effectiveness of the proposed drainage plan in
managing stormwater runoff. The applicant shall certify on the drawings that all clearing, grading, drainage, and construction shall be accomplished in
strict conformance with the drainage plan. The following information shall be submitted for both existing and proposed property conditions.
Properties smaller than ten (10) acres shall submit only the basic drainage plan called for in subsection B of this section. Properties larger than ten (10)
acres shall comply with the submittal requirement of both the basic drainage plan and the advance drainage plan of subsection B of this section.
B. Basic Drainage Plan:
1. Topographic Map: A topographic survey of the property at one foot (1') contours under existing and proposed condition, and areas upstream and
downstream, necessary to determine off site impacts of the proposed drainage plan. The map shall be keyed to a consistent USGS datum.
2. Drainage System: Mapping and descriptions, where relevant, of existing and proposed drainage system features of the property and immediate
vicinity including:
a. The banks and centerline of streams and channels;
b. Shoreline of lakes, ponds, and detention basins;
c. Farm drains and tiles;
d. Subwatershed boundaries within the property;
e. Watershed soils classifications;
f. The property's location within the larger watershed;
g. Locations, size and slope of stormwater conduits and drainage swales;
h. Sanitary sewers;
i. Depressional storage areas;
j. Delineation of upstream and downstream drainage features and watersheds which might be affected by the development;
k. Detention facilities;
l. Roads and streets and associated stormwater inlets;
m. Base flood elevation, and regulatory floodway where identified for the property; and
n. Basis of design for the final drainage network components.
3. Environmental Features: A depiction of environmental features of the property and immediate vicinity including the following:
a. The limits of wetland areas;
b. And designated natural areas; and
c. Any proposed environmental mitigation features.
4. Advanced Drainage Plan: The same information as required in this subsection B is required for properties larger than ten (10) acres along with the
following additional information for the minor drainage system's design runoff event and the 100-year runoff event of critical duration:
a. Elevations and maps of 100-year flooding;
b. Cross section data for open channel flow paths and designated overland flow paths;
c. Direction of storm flows;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 367/498
d. Flow rates and velocities at representative points in the drainage system; and
e. A statement by the design engineer of the drainage system's provisions for handling event greater than the 100-year's runoff.
C. Design Criteria, Standards And Methods:
1. Release Rates: The drainage system for a property shall be designated to control the peak rate of discharge from the property for the 2-year, 24-
hour and 100-year, 24-hour events to levels which will not cause an increase in flooding or channel instability downstream when considered in
aggregate with other developed properties and downstream drainage capacities. The peak 100-year discharge shall not be greater than 0.042 cfs
per acre of property drained.
2. Rainfall: Unless a continuous simulation approach to drainage system hydrology is used, all design rainfall events shall be based on the Illinois state
water survey's bulletin 70. The first quartile point rainfall distribution shall be used for the design and analysis of conveyance systems with critical
durations less than or equal to twelve (12) hours. The third quartile point rainfall distribution shall be used for the design and analysis of detention
basins and conveyance system with critical durations greater than twelve (12) hours and less than or equal to twenty four (24) hours. The fourth
quartile distribution shall be used in the design and analysis of systems with durations greater than twenty four (24) hours. The first, third, and fourth
quartile distributions described by huff are presented in table 37 of bulletin 70. The SCS type II distribution may be used as an alternate to the huff
distributions.
Antecedent Moisture: Computations of runoff hydrographs which do not rely on a continuous accounting of antecedent moisture conditions shall
assume a conservative wet antecedent moisture condition as a minimum.
3. Use Of Detention And Retention Areas And Design:
a. Backwater on the outlet structure from the downstream drainage system shall be evaluated when designing the outlet.
b. Adequate overflow channels or structures shall be provided and designed as simply as possible to require no attention for proper operation.
Design shall be for a storm of the 100-year frequency.
c. An overland flood route system shall be designed with adequate capacity to convey the stormwater runoff from the upstream tributary area and the
development itself through the development to the receiving stream for a 100-year storm. The design of this system shall assume the upstream
tributary is fully developed, all stormwater storage areas are completely full, the storm sewer system has totally failed or is obstructed and the
entire watershed is completely saturated.
The lowest finished floor of any structure, including the basement, shall be a minimum of two feet (2') above the overflow flood route. If the soils
between the stormwater storage area or overland flood route and the structure are compacted, impervious clay and structure is not a walkout or
English basement, the village engineer may approve structures with basement floors below the overflow or overland flood route water surface
elevation. However, the lowest opening must be a minimum of two feet (2') above the overflow elevation and in no case can the lowest floor,
including the basement, be below two feet (2') above the FEMA 100-year flood elevation. The village engineer may require soil borings to
determine the condition of the clay. Where the flood route passes between buildings, there shall be no window wells adjacent to the flood route.
All developments shall have positive overland drainage to provide for the total failure of the storm sewer system.
The lowest finished floor of any structure, including the basement, shall be a minimum of two feet (2') above the FEMA 100-year flood elevation.
The basement floor elevation shall also be a minimum of two feet (2') above the elevation of the 100-year flood elevation as defined in chapter 8 of
this title.
d. The detention facility shall completely drain within seventy two (72) hours. Under drains are required and shall be six inches (6") perforated plastic
pipe wrapped in fabric and surrounded by four inches (4") of washed river gravel.
e. Velocity dissipation measures shall be incorporated into all basin designs to minimize erosion at inlets and outlets.
f. In detention areas, the minimum bottom slopes shall be one percent (1%). An approved "flow through" practice shall be provided for low flows in all
detention basins. Paved ditches cannot be used as a low flow channel.
g. The entire detention area shall be able to support mowing equipment.
h. All detention or retention areas shall have a minimum of one hundred feet (100') of village street frontage.
i. As an alternative to the specified design elements, stormwater storage facilities can, if approved by the director of public works, be constructed as
wetland areas. These areas must be designed in accordance with section 10-6-17 of this chapter. The maximum allowable difference in elevation
between the normal water surface and the high water line shall be not more than two feet (2') in ponds constructed as wetlands.
j. Detention areas shall be designed so that the bottom area shall have no standing water after seventy two (72) hours for any storm less than the
100-year event.
k. All incoming storm sewers shall have either a concrete head wall, or a concrete flared end section with a trash rack constructed in accordance with
IDOT standards and shall be supported by two (2) timber piles.
l. Where possible, a mechanical drain shall be connected to the storm sewer to allow complete drainage of the retention facility. Armco or approved
equal control gate shall be used. Access to the control gate shall be paved.
m. The depth of a retention facility shall be not less than ten feet (10') over at least thirty percent (30%) of the pond.
n. The maximum allowable difference in elevation between the normal water surface in retention areas and the bottom of detention areas to the high
water line shall be five feet (5') and the side slope in this maximum five foot (5') area shall not be greater than four to one (4:1).
o. All retention areas shall have permanent erosion protection at the normal water surface.
p. Retention facilities shall have a water surface area not less than two (2) acres at the normal water level. Detention areas shall be a minimum size
of two (2) acres.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 368/498
q. The entire area of a facility shall be graded and seeded. A minimum of fifteen (15) trees per acre sized and planted in accordance with the
requirements of section 10-6-9 of this chapter shall be installed.
r. The distance from the normal water surface to the nearest lot line shall not be less than one hundred feet (100') for a minimum of fifty percent
(50%) of the lake shoreline. High water line may reach the nearest lot line but shall not encroach on the lot and shall not be closer than thirty feet
(30') to any building.
s. All embankments used to create detention or retention areas shall be designed by a registered professional engineer. The construction of all
embankments shall be certified by a registered professional engineer with a specialty in geotechnical engineering.
t. Storage in floodplain or flood fringe areas is allowed only with compensatory storage equal to one and five-tenths (1.5) times the volume below the
base flood elevation occupied by the storage area, including any berms.
u. The applicant shall demonstrate the operation in all streamflow and backwater conditions. Compensatory storage shall be opposite or adjacent to
the area occupied by detention.
v. The minimum outlet restrictor size shall be three and one-half inches (31/2"); however, the pond size shall be as determined by the release rate as
specified in subsection C1 of this section.
w. The elevation of the rim of all storm sewer structures tributary to any detention or retention pond shall be a minimum of one foot (1') above the
high water elevation, or the elevation of the hydraulic grade line, whichever is higher.
4. Stormwater Plans: Plans, specifications and all calculations for stormwater control shall be submitted for review and approval as part of final
engineering. The estimated cost of the improvements shall be included in any required guarantee as part of the storm sewer system.
5. Groundwater Recharge: The ability to retain and maximize the groundwater recharge capacity of the area being developed is encouraged. Design of
the stormwater storage system shall give consideration to providing groundwater recharge. Design calculations and details shall be provided with
final engineering. The use of natural gravel deposits in storage areas, flattening of drainage slopes, and the retention of existing topography are
examples. A detailed analysis of the downstream system may be required.
6. Compliance; Release Rates: All work shall be in accordance with the requirements of the metropolitan reclamation district and the Illinois department
of transportation standard specifications. In addition, the controlled release rate shall not exceed the safe capacity of the downstream storm sewer
system. A detailed analysis of the downstream system may be required.
7. Deposit Of Funds: In developments where less than one acre- foot of storage is required, the developer shall deposit with the village the funds
necessary to construct the required storage off site or construct the stormwater storage facility, as directed by the village engineer. The cost shall be
based on an estimate approved by the director of public works. The funds become the property of the village and if not used within ten (10) years,
may be transferred to the general fund.
8. Acceptance Of Storage Facilities: Storage facilities not in dedicated rights of way or on other village property must be either accepted by a park
district, lawful homeowners' association or conveyed to the property owner.
9. Maintenance Of Facility: If the facility is conveyed to a homeowners association, a covenant in the declaration creating such an association shall
provide that the association shall maintain the facility and if not, the village will maintain the facility and the cost of such maintenance and repair will
constitute a lien on the development.
D. Retention Area Stocked With Fish: Upon the completion of any retention area and as approved by the director of public works, the developer shall have
the area stocked with fish, the type and amounts of which shall be recommended by the state of Illinois department of conservation. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-
2-2010)
10-6-13: IMPROVEMENT OF EXISTING STREAMS AND WATERCOURSES:
In certain sectors of the village, existing streams or watercourses are dominant topographic features and are important to the drainage patterns and
system of the village. When an area to be subdivided includes a stream or watercourse, the following work shall be completed by the subdivider.
A. Preservation Of Natural Character: The natural character of the stream or watercourse shall be disturbed as little as possible unless such character is
contributory to flooding or ponding conditions within the area that affects the usability of the land.
B. Cleaning And Dredging: All rubbish, junk, dead trees or other extraneous matter shall be removed from the stream or watercourse and the channel shall
be altered as necessary to permit the natural flow of water.
C. Bank Stabilization: The banks of all streams or watercourses shall be stabilized, where there is danger of erosion, with plant materials or other materials
as required by the village board.
D. Dedication And Design: Dedication and design of areas immediately adjacent to both banks of Poplar Creek shall be approved by the director of public
works. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-14: INSPECTION OF SURFACE IMPROVEMENTS:
A. Inspection Required: All grading, paving, landscaping or other improvements as required by this title shall be inspected during the course of
construction and upon completion by the director of public works of the village. All retaining walls shall be inspected and approved by a licensed
professional engineer provided by and paid for by the developer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 369/498
B. Notification Required: During the course of construction of the improvements, the subdivider shall notify the village forty eight (48) hours before any
required inspection.
C. Inspection Fees: The subdivider shall pay the cost of all inspection services to the village collector. The fee shall be the cost plus two and one-half
percent (2.5%) of the guaranteed amount or one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the public improvements in a shopping center. The minimum
charge for inspection of commercial or industrial areas shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). There will be additional fees for special inspections,
such as soil or concrete or structural engineering. Any costs to the village for inspections outside normal village hours, or by consulting engineer or
specialists will be paid for by the developer. All reinspections required will be paid for by the developer at the current hourly rate charged by the village.
(Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-15: FEES FOR REVIEW OF DEVELOPMENT PLANS, AGREEMENTS:
A. Submittal: Whenever any person submits any development plans, agreements and related documents, applications for zoning or zoning amendments
and subdivision plans for review or approval by the village, all fees as established by ordinance and all direct hourly costs incurred by the village in
connection with the review by professional advisors and consultants and any legal fees in connection therewith, of said plans, agreements and related
documents, application for zoning or zoning amendments or subdivision approvals, shall be reimbursed to the village by the party, or parties, seeking
said reviews or approvals. In addition, the developer shall pay 1.5 percent of the total letter of credit, bond or cash deposit as a review fee.
B. Implementation: For the purpose of insuring the implementation of the aforementioned policy, the village manager shall cause separate and current
accounts to be kept of any such costs incurred by the village with respect to any of the aforesaid application.
C. Payment: No permits shall be issued for any development or no agreement signed, or, no final approval of any annexation or zoning amendments or
subdivision approval shall be granted until and unless the applicant has reimbursed the village for all such costs incurred in connection with the review
of said application.
D. Time Of Payment: All fees billed under this section shall be payable within thirty (30) days after submittal to the person by the village.
E. Statement: Any person making application to the village for review of plans, agreements and related documents, annexation, zoning changes or
amendments and subdivision approvals, shall sign a statement which shall read substantially as follows:
I/We , do hereby certify that I/We have read Ordinance No. of the Village of Streamwood, and do hereby agree to be bound by the
conditions of said Ordinance and to pay all fees in connection therewith, prior to any final approvals of any plans, agreements and related documents,
annexation agreements, zoning changes or zoning amendments or subdivision approvals.

ATTEST:
(Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-16: LANDSCAPING FOR RESIDENTIAL CONSTRUCTION:
A. Sod Required In All Residential Areas: Sod shall be required in all front yards, corner side yards, interior side yards and rear yards. Conservation
easements and ESA may be substituted for sod requirements.
B. Restrictions: Sod shall be of a Kentucky bluegrass mixture or with such other grass mixture as approved by the village board. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-
2010)
10-6-17: WETLAND STANDARDS:
A. Wetland Standards: All wetland areas on a site must have a landscaping plan and a buffer area plan. All direct impacts require a complete mitigation
plan with 1.5 to one (1.5:1) mitigation. All impacts will require a maintenance and monitoring plan. The purpose here is to require the developer to
"mitigate" or compensate for the impacts the development will have on the wetland, such as changes in drainage or filling parts of the wetland.
Native Illinois plants should be used including wildflowers, shrubs, prairie grasses and trees. The seed base for these plants must be within seventy
five (75) miles of the village. All plant materials shall be suitable for the soil types and hydric conditions present in the wetland. All of the following plant
species must be included in the buffer area. The plants for the wetland mitigation must be approved on a case by case basis and must fit with the
hydrology and soil type present in the area to be mitigated.
Prairie Forb Plugs (4" Plugs)

B. Water Depth: Fifty percent (50%) open water - fifty percent (50%) dry land water depth can vary from one foot (1') to ten feet (10'). To provide suitable
fish habitat, thirty percent (30%) of the surface area of the open water must be ten feet (10') deep or greater.
C. Stormwater Storage: The mitigation plan can allow for stormwater storage. The regulations of section 10-6-12 of this chapter generally apply except as
modified in this section.
D. Side Slopes: Side slopes from high water into the wet area may not exceed ten to one (10:1) up to eighteen inches (18") of water depth; below eighteen
inches (18") the maximum slope shall not be greater than five to one (5:1) or the angle of repose of the area soils whichever is a flatter slope.
E. Storm Sewer Inlets: The number of storm sewer inlets must be as low as possible. All storm sewer inlets must include forebays, silt traps or basins, and
be designed to reduce the energy of the incoming water. The outlet control structure must be capable of allowing the normal water level to be lowered
by two feet (2').
F. Soil Borings: Soil borings are required. Organic soils removed from the wetland must be used or returned into the mitigation area.
G. Buffer Strip: A one hundred foot (100') buffer strip is required. The buffer strip is to provide a transition from the wetland to the surrounding areas. This
strip must be planted with a large variety of species and types, including three (3) trees, five hundred (500) square feet of forb plugs for every four
thousand five hundred (4,500) square feet of buffer strip. The remaining area is to be planted with prairie grasses. The buffer strip shall have a
minimum of twelve inches (12") of organic topsoil. The topsoil must be placed so that it is not compacted. The buffer strip slope may not exceed five to
one (5:1). A path must be installed around the perimeter of the buffer strip. Said path must follow the same standards for path construction as in all
other areas of the village and outlined in section 10-6-18 of this chapter. A two (2) rail, split rail fence must be installed along the property line.
H. Conservation Easement: A conservation easement shall be established for the entire area including the buffer strip. The conservation easement shall
provide protection against any regrading or alteration and require a U.S. army corps of engineers permit for any major work.
I. Wildlife Habitat: Suitable wildlife habitat shall be provided and encouraged through the use of protected areas, islands and vegetation. The developer
shall provide wood duck nest boxes at the rate of three (3) boxes per acre for water wetlands. All suitable permanent ponds must be stocked with fish
as provided in subsection 10-6-12D of this chapter.
J. Mitigation Plan: All wetland area to be mitigated shall have one and five-tenths (1.5) acres of wetland for each one (1.0) acre damaged or destroyed. All
wetland areas on a project must have a mitigation plan.
K. Village Approval Of Mitigation Plan: The wetlands mitigation plan must be prepared by qualified professionals with considerable experience in this type
of work. The wetland mitigation plan must be approved by the village prior to approval by the corps of engineers. Any revisions made by the corps of
engineers must be approved by the village.
L. Maintenance By Developer: The developer shall provide all necessary maintenance for a period of three (3) years after completion of all work. This
maintenance shall include any necessary burning, cleaning, reseeding, silt removal, mowing or plant replacement. The developer shall annually submit
to the village, a detailed report by a qualified professional concerning the effectiveness of the mitigation plan. This report shall include number and
names of species present, percent coverage of proposed species, general growth rate and location and water depth.
M. Inventory Of Existing Plants: The mitigation plan must include a complete inventory of the existing plants and animals present on the site.
N. Compliance With State Requirements: The project must comply with the requirements of the Illinois endangered species protection act and any
recommendations made by the IDOC as part of the IESPA. All undeveloped property must have an IESPA report completed by the IDOC.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 372/498
O. Seeded Areas: All seeded areas must be mulched.
P. Wetlands Covered In This Section: The wetlands covered under this section are those as defined by the 1989 U.S. army corps of engineers "Wetland
Delineation Manual".
Q. Guarantee: All plants shall be covered by a two (2) year guarantee after final acceptance. A guarantee equal to ten percent (10%) of the original cost
shall be maintained for the entire guarantee period.
R. Mitigation Rate: Wetlands that do not require mitigation by the U.S. army corps of engineers must be mitigated at a rate of 1.5 acres to one acre.
S. Mitigation Banks: In cases where the U.S. army corps of engineers does require mitigation and the developer desires to mitigate off site, the developer
will be required to use an off site mitigation bank approved by the village, in conformance with acceptable standards for off site mitigation banks as
established by the army corps of engineers. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-18: BICYCLE PATHS AND WALKING TRAILS:
A. All materials used shall conform to IDOT standards for hot mix asphalt and crushed limestone and filter fabric.
B. All paths shall conform to American Association Of State Highway And Transportation Officials (AASHTO) standards.
C. All off road paths and trails shall be a minimum of eight feet (8') wide and shall consist of four inches (4") of crushed stone and four inches (4") of hot
mix asphalt. However, the director of public works may approve reduced widths, and eliminate the asphalt surface in areas of poor soil or in wetland
areas. All paths and trails shall be constructed over filter fabric which weighs a minimum of four and five-tenths (4.5) ounces per square yard.
D. All on road paths shall be a minimum of five feet (5') in width. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-6-19: DRIVEWAY CULVERTS:
A. Permit Required: Driveway culvert permits are required in all areas of the village where the street, whether public or private, does not have curb and
gutter. The applicant shall install a culvert under the proposed driveway to any new residential structure or upon the replacement or improvement of an
existing driveway.
B. Construction Requirements: The size of the culvert shall be determined by the village engineer, but in no event shall the size of the driveway culvert be
less than twelve inches (12") in diameter. The culvert shall be constructed of reinforced, concrete pipe. A reinforced, concrete, flared end section shall
be installed on each end of the culvert. The top opening of the flared end section shall be at least two feet (2') beyond the edge of the driveway. If the
applicant desires to extend the culvert completely across the lot frontage, a four foot (4') diameter manhole must be installed at both lot lines unless
otherwise approved by the village engineer. Connection to an existing manhole is permitted.
C. Drainage Plan Required: The applicant shall submit for review any necessary calculations and drainage plans as required by the village engineer to
determine the correct culvert size. The culvert shall be capable of transmitting a rainstorm in accordance with section 10-5-2 of this title.
D. Drainage Ditch; Grading; Retaining Walls: The drainage ditch which the culvert serves shall be graded with maximum side slopes of three to one (3:1)
(3 horizontal to 1 vertical). No retaining walls shall be constructed within the right of way. For drainage ditches adjacent to public streets, the entire right
of way, from the edge of the pavement to the property line, must be filled with a minimum of four inches (4") of topsoil and must be sodded. For
drainage ditches adjacent to private streets, the entire area, from the edge of the pavement to five feet (5') beyond the ditch bottom toward the
residence side of the ditch, must be filled with a minimum of four inches (4") of topsoil and must be sodded. The minimum slope of the ditch bottom is
two percent (2%). If the ditch slope is less than two percent (2%), the ditch must be piped across the lot by the applicant. Parkway trees must be
installed in accordance with section 10-6-9 of this chapter.
E. As Built Drawing: The applicant shall submit an as built drawing signed by a registered land surveyor showing the ditch grades and culvert grades
before paving the driveway.
F. Maintenance In Right Of Way: In the event the culvert and ditch are in the right of way, the applicant shall remain responsible for the condition of the
culvert and the grading of the culvert until final acceptance of the subdivision, or for two (2) years after the occupancy permit is issued, whichever is
later. The village shall maintain the driveway culvert beginning at a date two (2) years after final acceptance of the subdivision or two (2) years after the
occupancy permit is issued for the home, whichever is later.
G. Maintenance On Private Property: In the event the culvert and ditch are on private property, the grading and maintenance of the culvert and ditch shall
be the responsibility of the property owner. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
Chapter 7
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 373/498
10-7-1: ORGANIZATION:
The following offices of the government of the village are concerned with the administration of this title:
A. Village Board: The village board is vested with the following responsibilities in regard to subdivision control: (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
1. Plans And Plats: Approval or disapproval of all preliminary plans and final plats referred to it by the planning and zoning board.
2. Variations: Approval or disapproval of all variations and exceptions recommended by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010;
amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
3. Amendments: Amendment of the regulations of this title when found necessary and desirable, as hereinafter provided.
4. Enforcement: Initiation of appropriate proceedings to enforce the provisions of this title. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
B. Village Planning And Zoning Board: The village planning and zoning board shall hold public hearings and meetings for the purpose of making
recommendations to the village board regarding a proposed subdivision project. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
1. Plans and plats.
2. Variations and amendments to this title.
C. Community Development Department: The community development department shall administer the provisions of this title, and in furtherance of said
authority shall:
1. Maintain Regulations: Maintain permanent and current records of this title, including amendments thereto.
2. File Plans And Plats: Receive and file all preliminary plans and final plats (together with applications).
3. Liaison With Concerned Agencies: Forward copies of the preliminary plan to other appropriate offices and agencies for their recommendations and
report. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
4. Liaison With Village Board And Planning And Zoning Board: Forward, with recommendations, to the village board and planning and zoning board all
preliminary plans. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
5. File All Checked Plats: Receive and file all final plats, and check their compliance with the preliminary plan.
6. Forward Plats To Village Board: Forward with recommendations to the village board all final plats.
7. Other Determinations: Make all other determinations required by the regulations herein.
D. Village Engineer:
1. Review Of Plans: The village engineer shall review all preliminary and final subdivision and engineering plans and make determinations and
recommendations in the areas of design standards and engineering specifications, as stipulated herein.
2. Inspection Of Work: The village engineer shall inspect all improvements required by this title both during construction and after completion to ensure
compliance with this title and with good construction practice.
3. Conflict Of Interest: The village engineer or director of community development shall not be retained by a subdivider or other interested party to
perform engineering work in any subdivision subject to the application of this title. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-7-2: ENFORCEMENT:
A. Village Manager To Administer Provisions: It shall be the duty of the village manager to administer this title and to bring any violations or lack of
compliance herewith to the attention of the village attorney.
B. Compliance Required Before Sale Of Lots Or Issuance Of Building Permit: No owner, or agent of the owner, of any parcel of land located in a proposed
subdivision shall transfer or sell such parcel, nor shall any public official issue a building permit for the construction of buildings or structures within a
proposed subdivision, before the final plat of said subdivision has been approved by the village board, in accordance with the provisions of this title,
and filed with the recorder of deeds of Cook County, Illinois.
C. Use Of Metes And Bounds Measure Prohibited: The subdivision of any lot or any parcel of land by the use of metes and bounds for the purpose of sale,
transfer or lease with the intent of evading this title will not be permitted. All such described subdivisions shall be subject to all of the requirements and
regulations contained in this title.
D. Compliance Required Before Plat Approval: No final plat of subdivision shall be approved which does not comply with all the provisions of this title.
(Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-7-3: VARIATIONS AND EXCEPTIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=392 374/498
A. Hardships: Where the planning and zoning board finds that extraordinary hardships or particular difficulties regarding the physical development of land
may result from strict compliance with these regulations, it may recommend variations or exceptions to the regulations so that substantial justice may
be done and the public interest secured, provided that such variation or exception shall not have the effect of nullifying the interest and purpose of this
title; and further provided, the planning and zoning board shall not recommend variations or exceptions to the regulations of this title unless it shall
make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that: (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
1. Public Welfare Protected: The granting of the variation will not be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare or injurious to other property or
improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located.
2. Unique Conditions: The conditions upon which the request for a variation is based are unique to the property for which the variation is sought and
are not applicable, generally, to other property.
3. Particular Physical Conditions: Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved, a
particular hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of the regulations were carried out. (Ord.
2010-27, 12-2-2010)
B. Conditions: In recommending variations and exceptions, the planning and zoning board may require such conditions as will, in its judgment, secure
substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements of this title.
C. Procedure: A petition for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time the preliminary plan is filed for consideration by
the planning and zoning board. The petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner.
D. Recommendations: Such variations and exceptions as may be recommended by the planning and zoning board shall be forwarded to the village board
in writing, substantiating the recommended variations and/or exceptions. The village board may approve such variations or exceptions from the
requirements of this title in specific cases as listed on the final plat, which in its opinion do not adversely affect the adopted comprehensive plan or the
interest and purpose of this title. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010; amd. Ord. 2015-9, 5-7-2015)
10-7-4: APPEALS:
Any person aggrieved by an objection to a plat, or a failure to approve a plat, may appeal therefrom to the village board and then may appeal within sixty
(60) days of notification of such objection or rejection of the plat, by presenting to a court of record a petition for a writ of certiorari directed to the village
board. The court shall direct that the plat be approved if it finds that the action of the village board is arbitrary, unreasonable, or discriminatory. (Ord. 2010-
27, 12-2-2010)
10-7-5: AMENDMENTS:
For the purpose of promoting the public health, safety and general welfare, the village board may from time to time amend the regulations imposed by this
title. (Ord. 2010-27, 12-2-2010)
10-7-6: FEES:
A. Submission Of Application And Fees: At the time of submittal of the preliminary plan, the plan and required documents shall be submitted to the
community development director with a completed application and the appropriate application fee as listed below.
B. Deposit Fee:
1. In order to cover the costs of plan examination, which include, but are not limited to, staff costs, outside consultants, attorney costs, legal
stenographers, administrative costs, etc., and other expenses incidental to the approval process of a subdivision or development, the applicant or
petitioner shall deposit a fee at the time of application for approval of a preliminary plan. Such fee shall be based on the projected number of lots or
dwelling units to be created. All expenses incurred by the village in the process of the preliminary review process will be deducted from the deposit.
There shall be no refund of any portion of the fee if the applicant fails to apply for final approval within one year of the granting of the preliminary
approval. There shall be no fee for the preliminary consultations prior to the application for preliminary approval.
2. At the time of application for approval of the final plat, the applicant's deposit account will be reviewed. If the deposit account has a negative balance,
the applicant will be required to deposit an amount sufficient to satisfy the negative balance and ensure a surplus exists to cover the village expenses
to be incurred in the final plat and final engineering review. After final approval by the village board of trustees, the deposit account will again be
reviewed. If the account has a negative balance, that negative balance must be paid prior to recording of the plat. If the account has a positive
balance sufficient to cover all recording fees, the surplus will be refunded to the applicant.
C. Development Fees Schedule: The development fees schedule is updated by the village periodically by ordinance. The current development fees for the
village are as follows:
